title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions on Sunday about religious leaders' turn to environmentalism misidentified the clergyman shown blessing an elephant during the feast of St. Francis at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York City. He was Bishop Craig Anderson, the Dean of the General Theological Seminary in New York. The caption also referred incorrectly to the Dean of the cathedral, whose name erroneously appeared. He is the Very Rev. James Parks Morton.

title: Magma Power Co.(MGMA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV News Magazines Falter
description: In the latest sign that television news magazines have lost favor as prime-time programming, both ABC and Fox are backing away from commitments to such programs.

title: Erwin E. Kelm, Cargill Chief, Is Dead at 83
description: Erwin E. Kelm, who led Cargill Inc. through a period of rapid growth in the 1970's that helped propel the agribusiness giant to its position as the nation's largest family-owned company, died on Sunday at his home in Minneapolis, the company said yesterday. He was 83.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Committee to Protect Journalists, an organization that promotes freedom of the press and monitors abuses against journalists, will present its Burton Benjamin Memorial Award tonight to GEORGE SOROS, the financier and philanthropist, at the Grand Hyatt Hotel. Mr. Benjamin, a former vice president and director of CBS News and a documentary producer, died of a brain tumor in 1988 at the age of 70.

title: Insanity Plea Expected in Boys' Drownings
description: With a handwritten confession tucked away in the evidence file and an angry, betrayed town clamoring for her execution, Susan Smith is expected to plead that she was insane when, as charged, she drowned her two sons in a lake and then told the people in her hometown of Union, S.C., that the boys had been abducted.

title: West
description: ALASKA

title: Upstart Lakers Control the Tempo
description: It was midway through the second quarter and Cedric Ceballos was still waiting. When would the Knicks put a stop to the Lakers' wild runs up and down the court? When would they no longer be able to go to the net with such impunity? When would that infamous New York defense kick in?

title: Off the Menu
description: Movable Feasts

title: In America; The Soap Opera Machine
description: The national soap opera apparatus has shifted (temporarily) from the left coast to the right because the story of a woman who would drown her own babies is too colossally exciting to pass up, even in the era of O. J.

title: Publicity Firm Expands Base
description: Dan Klores Associates, a Manhattan-based public relations company, said yesterday that it was forming a new division, Dan Klores Entertainment, to expand the company's activities with entertainment industry clients.

title: Medieval Marketing: A Rare-Book Copy For a Mere $16,425
description: Act now while the supply lasts, and you can buy a rare facsimile of an 11th-century, illuminated German manuscript for only $16,425. After March 15, the price will rise to $19,205.

title: Daniel Seacord, 73, Nuclear Physicist
description: Daniel Freeman Seacord, a nuclear physicist who took part in atomic tests at Los Alamos, N.M., and in the Pacific in the early 1950's, died on Saturday at Milford-Whitinsville Regional Hospital in Milford, Mass. He was 73 and lived in Medway, Mass.

title: Microsoft and Visa in Software Deal
description: Staking another claim in the emerging market for electronic commerce, the Microsoft Corporation said today that it had entered an agreement with Visa International to provide technology for secure electronic bank-card transactions across public and private computer networks.

title: Making Peace With Death, Going On With Life
description: The dance floor was once a symbol of pleasure and possibilities: a place to flaunt physicality and meet new partners. The AIDS epidemic has changed that, lending every new encounter an element of danger, bringing a sense of loss to clubs that once were carefree. Seal, the English singer and songwriter who started a two-night engagement at the Beacon Theater on Monday, captures that new mood of somber revelry, a mixture of hope and mourning. His songs struggle to make peace with mortality, yearning for "life without the pain" and insisting that for the living, "It's time to move on."

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: From Madrid, Flamenco Put to Dramatic Effect Lehman College

title: Insatiable Hunger for Cookbooks
description: ONCE considered the wayward stepchildren of publishers, cookbooks have achieved the status of glamorous and highly visible offspring. Carefully priced, often elaborately packaged and sometimes aimed at specific audiences, they are no longer geared just to the kitchens of gastronomic strivers. Moved by every conceivable medium into the mainstream, they have become vehicles for celebrity and, sometimes, for mind-boggling sales.

title: G.O.P. WINS CONTROL OF SENATE AND MAKES BIG GAINS IN HOUSE; PATAKI DENIES CUOMO 4TH TERM
description: The Republican Party seized control of the Senate and moved within a few seats of capturing the House yesterday, winning eight Democratic seats in the Senate and at least 38 in the House. The gains were the Republicans' strongest in decades and put them in position to thwart President Clinton and his legislative proposals for the next two years.

title: Black Investors Buy Franchises From Denny's
description: The Denny's restaurant chain, which for years has been accused of widespread prejudice against black customers, announced yesterday that a black-owned company in Atlanta had agreed to buy and operate as many as 47 Denny's restaurants in New York and New Jersey.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CIRCUS
description: Grandma and the Mimes Open the Big Apple Season Damrosch Park

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Computer Glitch Stalls Federal Express
description: The Federal Express Corporation, which built its reputation by promising timely delivery of packages, stumbled on its pledge yesterday when a computer glitch interrupted pickup services for some of its customers.

title: The Giants Stare Across Talent Gap
description: Dallas wide receiver Alvin Harper, who injured his knee against the Giants Monday night after a freakish end to the first half, had a warning for the Giants. "He cheap-shotted me," Harper said of Giants cornerback Tito Wooten. "All I've got to tell them is the last game of the year somebody is going to get hurt."

title: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries(TEVIY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are in American Depositary Receipt (A.D.R.). Each A.D.R. represented 10 ordinary shares.Per share data are fully diluted.Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Texas Elects George W. While Florida Rejects Jeb
description: George W. Bush, the eldest son of former President George Bush, ousted Gov. Ann W. Richards on Tuesday, heralding historic Republican gains in the nation's second-largest state. But his younger brother Jeb, hoping for a similar coup in Florida, was turned back by the Democratic incumbent, Lawton Chiles.

title: Carrying Today's Ideas To 14th-Century World
description: Withdrawing from the medieval world to devote herself to the Virgin Mary, a young woman named Christine happily chooses to be forever walled into a tiny room adjoining the church. As the last stone is put in place, "Anchoress" creates a chilling sense of entrapment while making the young woman's sense of relief and escape clear. Now she won't have to marry the reeve, the belligerent overseer of the manor where Christine, her sister and their parents sleep in a single bed in their thatched cottage. At times "Anchoress," an eccentric, beautifully photographed black-and-white film, offers an eerie immersion in a distant world.

title: Manager's Dream Is Lost In the Sun
description: Mike Easler came to Puerto Rico a couple of weeks ago to nurture his managerial aspirations in this island's winter leagues much the way he had nurtured his playing career during 10 winters of play here.

title: New Faces In the Senate
description: MISSOURI John Ashcroft

title: Defying Anti-Incumbent Mood, Moynihan Wins Easily
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a three-term incumbent who is among the most influential members of Congress, was re-elected by a wide margin yesterday over his Republican challenger, Bernadette Castro, according to unofficial returns early this morning.

title: Judges Err on Whitewater
description: The behavior of Judge David Sentelle, which put a cloud over the appointment of a new independent prosecutor in the Whitewater case during August, was bad in itself. But the justification for that behavior now offered up by Chief Judge Harry Edwards of the U.S. Court of Appeals is equally appalling.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: An Indian Classical FormTailored to Its Interpreter Asia Society

title: Mason Feels Unloved As Starks Signs Pact
description: In a surprising development that threatens the Knicks' chemistry this season, John Starks was signed to a three-year, $13.1 million contract extension yesterday, and Anthony Mason's bid for a new deal was denied.

title: Dollar General Corp.(DOLR,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share amounts for 1993 are restated to reflect the April 1994 5-for-4 stock split.

title: Cablevision Systems Corp.(CVC,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: (Loss)

title: 2 Medical Companies To Merge
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Scimed Life Systems Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $870 million.

title: Cuomo Loss Hands Mayor Unsure Future In Own Party
description: Having staked his political future on a gamble that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would win a fourth term, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suffered an enormous defeat last night as the Republican he had assailed as a captive of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and a menace to the downstate region was elected as New York's next governor.

title: Governor, Philosophical, Concedes and Soldiers On
description: He never prayed for victory on his final Election Day, the most sorrowful day in a career that had known few such moments of defeat. Instead, said Mario M. Cuomo, he fashioned a different prayer.

title: French Police Arrest 95 Suspected of Links to Algerian Militants
description: In the largest crackdown to date on Islamic militants active within France's Muslim population, the French police today arrested 95 people reportedly linked to Algeria's Armed Islamic Group in raids on homes and Muslim associations in and around Paris.

title: For Mail-Order Food Gifts, Sweets Top the Wish List
description: THIS year, this annual mail-order column has almost twice as many sweets as savories. That is in part because there are many more mail-order desserts than there are mail-order vegetables, meat, cheese or grain dishes.

title: Simpson Industries(SMPS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 3 million, or 17 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago per-share amounts restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 28, 1994.

title: U.S. Robotics Inc.(USRX,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-After a gain of $ 215,000, or 2 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Aristide's Cabinet Is Sworn and Pledges to Get to Work
description: After nearly a month of highly publicized consultations with friends and foes and a bit of old-fashioned politicking behind closed doors, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide finally has a Prime Minister, a full Cabinet and a Parliament-approved plan of action.

title: Let Them Eat Cake. Yours.
description: Since Mayor Rudolph Giuliani announced his plan to end New York City's financing for emergency food assistance programs, he has been accused of insensitivity, cruelty, even immorality. John Cardinal O'Connor wrote that the act raised the issue of "moral right." The leaders of the anti-hunger movement pointed out that the city has more than half a million poor children whose food supply will be threatened.

title: All Dressed Up: Turkey and Stuffing Rolled Into Shape
description: NOVEMBER, the month of Thanksgiving, is truly "turkey month" for me. This is when I can usually find terrific deals on fresh turkey in all forms, including whole turkey, breasts, legs and thighs, as well as turkey cutlets and ground turkey. If there are special sales on fresh turkey in your area, buy it now, then double-wrap and freeze it for use over the next several months, when the price of turkey will double or triple at the market.

title: New York Results - The Race for Comptroller
THE 1994 ELECTIONS: MAN IN THE NEWS -- John Grosvenor Rowland; Behind the Issues, a Yearning for Lost Innocence
description: In his victory speech on primary night two months ago, John G. Rowland talked about the good old days in his hometown of Waterbury, a time not so long ago when children had the run of not just their neighborhoods, but the entire city.

title: Other Highlights
description: VIRGINIA In Brutal Battle, Robb Defeats North

title: Knicks Sign Starks, and the Lakers Pay the Price
description: The Knicks got more than they bargained for in their home opener last night, but they got a victory -- if just barely.

title: Restraints for Elderly
description: In a pioneering program begun several years ago, the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged in Manhattan and the Bronx showed that it was rarely necessary to restrain nursing home patients who suffered from mental confusion or extreme physical weakness. Use of restraints is commonplace in nursing homes and at one time homes were cited for neglect when frail or agitated patients were not restrained.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: A Comedy of Manners, Barely Aged After 3 Centuries Theater 80

title: Mandatory H.I.V. Testing of Babies Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Minorities and Women Win Airwave Licenses
description: In a further sign that the nation's airwaves are worth plenty on the open market, the Federal Government received bids today totaling nearly $400 million in its third set of auctions of wireless-radio licenses.

title: Lautenberg Edges Out Haytaian For 3d Term
description: Frank R. Lautenberg won a third term as a United States Senator from New Jersey yesterday by defeating Assembly Speaker Chuck Haytaian in a campaign that focused on abortion, gun control and taxes.

title: Bronx Officer And a Man Seeking Help Are Both Shot
description: An off-duty New York City police officer and a man who went to him for help, saying someone was trying to kill him, were wounded yesterday by a gunman in the South Bronx, the police said.

title: Even the Experts Love a Good Read
description: A NUMBER of food experts were asked to name a cookbook they find indispensable. Following are their answers, which were as varied as salsas on supermarket shelves.

title: When Cold Remedies Harm the Young
description: FOR parents, there is no greater impulse than the desire to make their children well when they are sick. And no illness has parents reaching for medicine more often than the common cold, a recent national survey found. More than a third of 3-year-olds had been given an over-the-counter cough or cold drug in the month before the survey, The Journal of the American Medical Association reported earlier this fall.

title: For Squatters, Options Are Few in a Costly City
description: To the Editor:

title: McCall's Gets New Editor
description: Sally Koslow, editor of Mary Emmerling's Country, was named editor in chief of McCall's yesterday. She replaces Kate White, who became editor in chief of Redbook last month.

title: World Bank Approves Loan to Help Russia Clean Up Pollution
description: The World Bank today approved its first loan to Russia aimed at cleaning up some of the country's contaminated rivers, polluted industrial sites and toxic waste dumps, and said it was the first step in a broad program to undo seven decades of environmental mismanagement.

title: Nothing Devilish In Halloween Origins
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Profits from higher-rate loans to low-income home buyers.
description: FOR a profitable mortgage-lending business, consumers with low incomes and checkered credit records marred by delinquent payments are not the usual prospects. But they are the bread and butter for the United Companies Financial Corporation of Baton Rouge, La., and some other finance companies, which have found that low-income homeowners will mortgage their houses at relatively high interest rates to obtain loans unavailable from other sources.

title: Northeast
description: CONNECTICUT

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: New Sopranos Take Over Lead Roles in 'Arabella' Metropolitan Opera

title: Archie San Romani, A 1930's Miler, 82
description: Archie San Romani, a Kansas coal miner's son who overcame a severe childhood accident to become one of the world's leading milers in the 1930's, died Monday at a nursing home in Auberry, Calif. He was 82 and a resident of Fresno, Calif.

title: Wine Talk
description: A YOUNG couple stop for a drink in a wine bar.

title: Campus Journal; Ex-Farrakhan Aide Speaks at N.Y.U.
description: BACK on the campus lecture circuit after recovering from a shooting last spring, Khalid Abdul Muhammad, the former spokesman for the Nation of Islam, strode onto a New York University stage Monday night and warned whites in the audience that "it's going to be a rough ride, buddy."

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sluggish Sampras Wins Playing on antibiotics, Pete Sampras awoke from a slumber when pride was on the line and beat the local favorite, Johan Van Herck, to advance yesterday in the European Community Championship in Antwerp, Belgium. The top-seeded Sampras allowed the 157th-ranked player to take him to a first-set tie breaker, but then Van Herck could not handle the pressure play of Sampras. After winning the tie breaker, 7-2, the sluggish defending champion did just enough to take the second set at 6-4. "I've had my better days," said Sampras, the world's top-ranked player, who is suffering from a throat infection. "I feel depleted and I haven't eaten too much." Tomorrow, he will face Richey Reneberg, who defeated David Wheaton, 7-6 (7-1), 6-7 (7-9), 6-1. Jaime Yzaga of Peru, seeded eighth, beat the German qualifier Arne Thoms, 6-2, 7-6 (7-1), ending a string of upsets that had sent two seeded players home on the first day. The tournament lost two top 20 players Monday when Richard Krajicek of the Netherlands, seeded fourth, and Jason Stoltenberg of Australia, No. 5, lost in straight sets. (AP)

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Elenore Hangley, Ad Executive, 63
description: Elenore Hangley, a former executive vice president of the Advertising Council, died on Saturday at the Englewood Hospital and Medical Center, in Englewood, N.J. She was 63 and lived in Cliffside, N.J.

title: Penguin Owner Peeved By the Puck-Dragging
description: Bargainers for the National Hockey League and its locked-out Players Association will meet again tomorrow in Toronto. Although it is a positive sign that the two sides are meeting twice in the same week, it's not often enough or soon enough for Howard Baldwin, owner of the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Songs From Vienna
description: The New York Festival of Song is to present a program called "Vienna: Turn of the Centuries," on Saturday at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Cheryl Parrish (soprano), Susanne Mentzer (mezzo-soprano) and William Sharp (baritone), accompanied by Steven Blier and Michael Barrett, are to sing works from the years just before and after 1900, with a few samples of Haydn and Beethoven from the turn of the preceding century. Works by Mahler, Richard Strauss, Schoenberg, Berg, Wolf, Pfitzner and Zemlinsky are on the program. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 916-1100.

title: 'Bell Curve' Critics Say Early I.Q. Isn't Destiny
description: Are children who score poorly on standardized tests of ability fated to lives of poverty, crime and social squalor?

title: It's Not 125th Street: A Vendor Sweep in Brooklyn
description: Without fanfare or uproar, a police precinct in Brooklyn has moved hundreds of street vendors away from a bustling commercial strip over the last 10 months. And, in the process, crime has decreased, store owners are pleased and some vendors are working with the police on a plan to set them up as legitimate merchants in city-owned space nearby.

title: Nets Return, But Bulls Await
description: The favorite early season opponent for the state of Texas has come home 0-3, groggy and disheveled. In search of an awakening, the Nets will play in their own building for the first time in six months.

title: California Pregnancy Study Finds Healthier Outcomes for Refugees
description: SUPERIOR educations and higher family incomes do not necessarily result in healthier pregnancies and healthier babies. A new study in San Diego County has found that immigrants and refugees from Mexico and Southeast Asia have better pregnancy results than native-born American women, despite their often extreme poverty and difficulties adjusting to a foreign culture.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 1 about the management divisions at the Warner Music Group included an erroneous sales figure supplied by Epitaph Records for "Smash," an album by the Offspring, a punk band. The "Smash" album has sold 1.4 million copies through Oct. 30, according to Soundscan Inc., a company that tracks record sales; it has not sold 100 million copies.

title: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: Connecticut Congressional Races-- SECOND DISTRICT; Gejdenson's Fate Is in Doubt
description: The fate of Representative Sam Gejdenson, a seven-term Democrat running in a rematch against a Republican who almost beat him in 1992, was uncertain early today.

title: Spielvogel Will Run United Auto Group
description: Carl Spielvogel, the longtime advertising executive, yesterday was named chairman and chief executive of United Auto Group Inc., a fast-growing private operator of multiple-franchise auto dealerships.

title: Saks Cleared Of Customers As Fire Erupts In Basement
description: A fire that firefighters described as suspicious broke out in the basement of Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon, filling the building with smoke and forcing the evacuation of the 70-year-old department store.

title: Maurice Robert Smith; Balloon Unit Commander, 100
description: Maurice Robert Smith, who commanded an Army balloon unit in World War I, died on Oct. 30th at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He had turned 100 on July 4.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $400 million of 8.625 percent debentures due in 2004. Redeemable on or after Nov. 10, 1999, the issue is priced at 99.984375 to yield 8.627 percent.

title: Hall of Fame Nominees
description: KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR, whose skyhooks and dunks helped him become the N.B.A.'s leading career scorer, was among nine men and two women nominated yesterday for the Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: New Jersey Congressional Races
description: 2d DISTRICT Lobiondo, the Republican, Wins Over Democratic Newcomer

title: Turning a Clutch of Recipes Into a Genre
description: IN 1959, Julia Child took a revised version of what was to become "Mastering the Art of French Cooking," Volume 1, back to Houghton Mifflin, which had asked her and her co-writers, Simone Beck and Louisette Bertholle, to rewrite the first draft. The revision was rejected and the contract was canceled because the editor thought the book might have proved too formidable for the American housewife.

title: Generation X Makes Its Mark
description: IN this season of heightened cynicism, how will today's young and relatively innocent first-time voters come to remember their political initiation?

title: Dillard Department Stores Inc.(DDS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: F.A.A. Considering Limit On Plane in Indiana Crash
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it would consider a recommendation that the make of commuter aircraft that crashed last week in Indiana be prohibited from flying in icy conditions.

title: Israeli Talks On Self-Rule Speeded Up
description: Moving to defend Yasir Arafat against a challenge from his Islamic foes, Israel agreed today to pick up the pace of its sluggish talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization on expanding self-rule beyond the Gaza Strip and the Jericho enclave to include the entire West Bank.

title: Sealright Co.(SRCO,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago periods' share earnings were reduced by 5 cents a share relating to new tax rate changes.

title: Results - New York: The Race for Governor
Midwest
description: ILLINOIS

title: Vacco Comes From Behind To Win Against Burstein
description: Dennis C. Vacco narrowly beat out his Democratic opponent yesterday in the New York State attorney general's race after waging a law-and-order campaign in which he promised to lobby for the death penalty.

title: INSIDE
description: A Boost for Israel Talks

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: New York Results - The Race for Attorney General
New York Voters End a Democratic Era
description: George Elmer Pataki, a lanky lawyer-legislator from the Hudson Valley who has promised to slash income taxes and restore the death penalty, was elected the 53d Governor of New York yesterday, ending 20 years of Democratic rule in Albany and toppling Mario M. Cuomo, a legendary figure in state and national politics.

title: Twyla Tharp to Perform
description: Twyla Tharp and her dancers are to perform at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in mid-January in a program called "Twyla Tharp Red, White and Blues New Works." The new dances were recently presented as works in progress at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. They are performed to 1950's doo-wop, excerpts from the soundtrack of "The Civil War" and music by Duke Ellington, Bartok, Gluck, the Drummers of Burundi and Wynton Marsalis. The company of eight dancers is to perform at the academy's Opera House on Jan. 16 to 21 and 23 to 28. Tickets are $15, $20 and $25. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-4100. Information: (718) 636-4129.

title: Cincinnati Milacron Inc.(CMZ,N) reports earnings for 16wks to Oct 8
description: b-Net loss and included $ 18.1 million pretax charge for writedown of the company's Sano operation, which was subsequently sold in both the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included an after-tax charge of $ 4,407,000, or 14 cents a share, for debt extinguishment and an after-tax charge of $ 52,125,000, or $ 1.64 a share, for cumulative effect of accounting changes.(Loss)

title: CRYSTAL OIL SHARES RISE ON ASSET SALE PLAN
description: Shares of the Crystal Oil Company surged yesterday, after the company said late Monday that it had agreed to sell all its United States oil and gas fields to the Apache Corporation for about $101 million. Crystal Oil, based in Shreveport, La., said the investor George Soros's Quantum Fund N.V., which owns 66 percent of Crystal Oil's voting stock, would approve the transaction. Shares of Crystal Oil rose $3.50, to $32, on the American Stock Exchange. Joe N. Averett Jr., president of Crystal Oil, said the company did not plan to reinvest the money from the transaction or dissolve the company.

title: Architecture Historian Linked Us to Lost Era
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: "The candidates are unworthy because they run simply by attacking each other instead of saying what they will do." BOB MAKEY, a Chicago real-estate developer. [ B2:3. ]

title: Republican Gains and Obligations
description: "I need help, folks," said President Clinton during his final, desperate burst of campaigning. He did not get it. The result was a historic shift of power to the Republicans, in Washington and in statehouses throughout the nation.

title: Rev. Philip Dobson, 85, Is Dead; Fordham Business School Dean
description: The Rev. Philip E. Dobson, an expert on industrial relations and a former dean of the Fordham University School of Business, died on Sunday at Fordham's Murray-Weigel Hall, a Jesuit infirmary in the Bronx. He was 85 and lived in Linden, N.J., most of his life.

title: Dollar Is Lower on Concern Clinton May Be Weakened
description: The dollar fell against most leading currencies in cautious trading yesterday.

title: Harper And Knee Listed as Doubtful
description: The desperation pass that the Cowboys launched on the final play of the first half against the Giants on Monday night turned out to be riskier than expected.

title: G.O.P. Wins County Job
description: A Republican was elected Essex County Executive tonight after the Democrats were unable to recover from a divisive primary that left them with little time and money to battle for a powerful post that had traditionally been theirs.

title: Voters Cry: Enough, Mr. Cuomo!
description: In the end, even his friends agreed, Mario Matthew Cuomo simply strutted and fretted too long on the great stage of his state, and yesterday, with the pungent irrevocability of the Latin he loves to quote, the voters finally ordered: "Exit."

title: Limited Inc.(LTD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; In Bitter Cola War, Coke Takes a Less-Sweet Tack
description: For almost a year, the Coca-Cola Company has talked up the return of its familiar contoured bottles as part of efforts to differentiate its flagship soft drink from competitors. Now Coca-Cola is talking up what's inside those bottles, too.

title: U.S. Bids Rise For Italy's GFT
description: A bidding contest for GFT S.p.A., Italy's third-largest apparel maker, is developing, with two United States bidders each offering $275 million in cash for the financially troubled company.

title: Skating and Ratings
description: Figure skating, which dominates the television ratings at the Winter Olympics and never more so than at the '94 Games in Lillehammer, Norway, gets much of the drama from the individual rivalries that develop. Team competitions are rare. But tonight, a team of skaters from the United States takes on an international squad in an event known as the Ice Wars.

title: Rich and Poor in Cuba as Castro's Sun Sets
description: Fidel Castro's condition must be verdaderamente desesperado if public television can't find a good word for him. "Last Days of the Revolution" depicts a nation in despair. The loss of Cuba's Soviet patrons, the continuance of the United States embargo and the bunglings of its Communist masters have sent the country's economy into free fall and thousands of its people on perilous voyages to Florida.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Dual Focus In Concert of Remembrance Cathedral of St. John the Divine

title: Justice Breyer Takes Ethics Seriously
description: To the Editor:

title: Fred (Sonic) Smith, 44, Guitarist With Rock Bands of 3 Decades
description: Fred (Sonic) Smith, a guitarist for the influential rock band the MC5, died on Friday at St. John's Hospital in Detroit. He was 44 and lived in St. Clair Shores, a suburb of Detroit.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: PIPER JAFFRAY COS. (PJC,N)
description: Shareholders of the Piper Jaffray Companies saw their dividend cut yesterday as the securities firm prepared to defend itself against lawsuits stemming from its management of bond mutual funds. Piper Jaffray also said earnings fell almost 70 percent in its fourth quarter.

title: As Talks Near, an Ad Stirs Unrest
description: Just as baseball's negotiators were headed back to the table to talk peace, a new phase of the war broke out yesterday between the owners and the striking players.

title: P.&G. Official Joins Microsoft
description: William H. Gates turned to an expert in computers and consumer-products marketing today to fill a longstanding opening in the top management ranks of the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Otter Tail Power (OTTR,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago periods restated to reflect change in method of electric revenue recognition for North Dakota from billing dates to energy delivery dates.

title: A Newspaper Labor Dispute Spawns an On-Line Rivalry
description: The strike blocking deliveries of both of San Francisco's major daily newspapers has provided an unexpected but revealing test of electronic publishing.

title: Milton Taylor, 86, Co-Owner Of Caswell-Massey Pharmacies
description: Milton Taylor, who with his brother Ralph took over the venerable Caswell-Massey pharmacy on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan in 1936 and helped build it into an international purveyor of fashionable toiletries, died on Saturday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Pentagon Aide On Secret Visit To Tour China
description: The director of the Defense Intelligence Agency is in China, but United States officials will not say whom he is meeting or which defense sites he is visiting.

title: The Pop Life
description: Strange Clubfellows

title: U.N. Debates an End to Bosnia Arms Embargo
description: The Security Council began a debate tonight on a resolution calling for an end to the arms embargo against the Muslim-led Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Public & Private; Polls, Not Passion
description: A funny thing happened on the way to the midterm elections. Abortion rights, the stepchild issue of campaigns past, became a stepping stone to elected office. While once candidates wanted the whole subject to simply go away, in 1994 it was a linchpin of both gubernatorial and Congressional campaigns, for those who had previously soft-pedaled the incendiary issue -- and those who had once shown little or no support for legal abortion at all.

title: Real Estate; A new mall in downtown Indianapolis is a monument to public-private partnerships.
description: PASSERS-BY could easily miss the $325 million Circle Centre mall in downtown Indianapolis. Halfway through construction, it looks more like a turn-of-the-century streetscape than the standard mall found in suburbia.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 2 about a drive to help schools take advantage of a Federal program that provides breakfast for needy children misidentified the school in lower Manhattan where the picture, which showed the actress Rosie O'Donnell playing with children, was taken. It was Public School 63, not Public School 3.

title: In Chicago (Truly!), Many Stay Home
description: Precinct captains stood outside nearly empty polling places. They looked at their lists and checked off names. They got people rides to the polls. They got babysitters for voters' children. They slipped reminders on front porches and palm cards in people's hands. They got doors slammed in their faces and weak promises from voters who vowed they would vote but did not.

title: New Sensations Cross Path of an Old One
description: Talk about a coincidence.

title: Conversing With Hampson
description: The baritone Thomas Hampson is to be the first artist to appear in Lincoln Center's Off Stage series of conversations with performers, tomorrow at 6 P.M. in the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse of the Rose Building, 165 West 65th Street. The one-hour discussion is to be followed by an informal wine-and-cheese reception with Mr. Hampson. Others in the series are to be the actor Dom DeLuise (Dec. 14), the actor and musician Clifton Davis (Jan. 10) and the violin teacher Dorothy DeLay along with a student, Sarah Chang (Feb. 21). Tickets to the entire series are $45; single tickets are $14. Information: (212) 721-6500.

title: Vengeful Glee (and Sweetness) at Gingrich's Victory Party
description: At the Newt Gingrich victory party tonight at a mall outside Atlanta, the air was filled with vengeful glee.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17 ISRAEL TO SPEED SELF-RULE TALKS Moving to defend Yasir Arafat against challenges from his Islamic foes, Israel agreed to pick up the pace of its sluggish talks on expanding self-rule beyond the Gaza Strip and the Jericho enclave to include the entire West Bank. A10 CIVILIANS KILLED IN SARAJEVO Four civilians died and six were wounded in the heaviest artillery bombardment of the Bosnian capital since February. United Nations commanders ruled out military retalation by NATO. But they noted that tensions in Sarajevo seem once again dangerously high. A8

title: Hal Ellson; Novelist, 84
description: Hal Ellson, a prolific writer of novels and short stories, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 84.

title: Voters Favor Plan to Create A Legislature
description: Nassau County voters tonight approved a plan to create a new Legislature to replace the county's 50-year-old Board of Supervisors, which a Federal judge found to be unconstitutional.

title: Concession and Victory: Words of Pataki and Cuomo
description: Following are excerpts from the concession speech of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last night, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: A Vote Against Clinton
description: It was an immoderate campaign, coarse in its tone and unedifying in its substance, and the nation's politics are likely to stay that way for the next two years and beyond.

title: BARNETT'S DEAL WITH GLENDALE FEDERAL IS APPROVED
description: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates national banks, approved applications yesterday by four units of Barnett Banks Inc. to acquire 34 Florida branches of Glendale Federal Bank of Glendale, Calif. The approval came even though a Justice Department internal investigation found that two of Barnett's banking units had engaged in lending discrimination from 1991 to 1993. The bank is in settlement talks with the department, Deval Patrick, the assistant attorney general for civil rights, said yesterday. Barnett agreed in April to buy Glendale's Florida franchise, which includes $3.6 billion in deposits and 60 offices in 10 counties, for $243.5 million.

title: Pulitzer Publishing (PTZ,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 719,000, or 6 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for postretirement benefits.c-After a gain of $ 350,000, or 3 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.The latest three quarters included operations of WESH, Daytona Beach/Orlando, acquired June 30, 1993, and KCCI-TV, Des Moines, acquired Sept. 9, 1993. After deducting acquisition-related depreciation and amortization ($ 3.5 million in the latest quarter and $ 10.5 million for the latest 9 months) and interest charges ($ 1.9 million for the latest third quarter and $ 5.8 million for the latest 9 months), the negative after-tax effect on earnings was $ 310,000 for the latest quarter and $ 1.4 million for the latest 9 months.

title: McCall Becomes First Black Elected to Statewide Office
description: H. Carl McCall, who rose from a childhood on welfare to become a state legislator, ambassador and bank vice president, won the combative race for state comptroller early this morning, making history as he became the first black candidate elected to statewide office in New York.

title: G.O.P. Takes 2 Senate Seats, and More
description: The Republicans swept both of Tennessee's seats in the United States Senate today and, for good measure, took the governor's office from the Democrats and seized a majority in the state's delegation to the House of Representatives.

title: Dissatisfaction Guaranteed
description: We know what the voters didn't like about President Clinton's health reform proposals -- more control by the Federal Government, employer mandates, higher taxes to cover the poor and, above all, price controls. The question is how long the voters will remain satisfied with what they have now.

title: As G.O.P. Gains, Clinton Mood Dampens
description: President Clinton did not stop campaigning until midafternoon today. But even as he urged radio listeners around the country to get out and vote, there was an air of resignation in his voice, and at the White House tonight the mood edged toward despair.

title: Net Up 23.6% At News Corp.
description: The News Corporation, the global media giant, said today that its first-quarter profit rose 23.6 percent after one-time adjustments, largely on gains from the company's film operations. Newspaper earnings slumped.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Sept. 20 about new Federal requirements for drug and alcohol tests for transit workers included a statement, attributed to a New Jersey Transit official, suggesting that new alcohol tests will probably turn up a substantial number of people working under the influence, especially in rail operations.

title: Barry Rebounds From Disgrace to Win Again in Washington
description: Former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. last night regained the office he had left in disgrace almost five years ago, but not without widespread defections of black voters to his Republican opponent, Carol Schwartz.

title: Let's Not Rush Into World Trade Agreement
description: To the Editor:

title: At Salomon, Trader Earns $30 Million
description: Even though Salomon Brothers is losing more money than any other large securities firm, one of its traders is perhaps the highest paid on Wall Street.

title: Algo Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: MICROSOFT'S CO-FOUNDER INVESTS IN TRILOBYTE
description: Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, is taking a minority investment in Trilobyte Inc., a software game company in Medford, Ore. Mr. Allen, who is on Microsoft's board, owns the Portland Trailblazers basketball team and has a controlling interest in Ticketmaster. Trilobyte, which was established in 1991 as a spinoff of Virgin Software and has 35 employees, introduced its first game, "The 7th Guest," in April 1993. It plans a sequel called "The 11th Hour," for introduction next year.

title: Fila Holding SpA (FLH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings represented American Depositary Shares (A.D.S.); each A.D.S. represents 5 ordinary shares.Fila is an Italian company.Figures in U.S. dollars are based on the average exchange rate for each period.

title: Economic Data Help To Lift Bonds
description: A successful start to a quarterly refinancing and two weaker-than-expected economic reports helped to lift bond prices yesterday for the first time in seven sessions.

title: U.N. Approves Tribunal on Rwandan Atrocities
description: The Security Council voted today to create an international tribunal to try people accused of atrocities in Rwanda even though the Rwandan delegate voted against the measure, complaining that it lacked a death penalty and only covered crimes committed in 1994.

title: Downtown Artist Goes Uptown, but Not Her Art
description: Kiki Smith sits cross-legged on the living room floor in her sunny Lower East Side apartment, calmly cutting doily shapes from yards of gossamer-thin paper and talking about life. She ignores her cat, Ginzer, curled up on a corner of the paper she is cutting, snoring. She is also oblivious to the churning of the fax machine, the constant ringing of the telephone and the loud cooing of the doves and finches that live in cages along one windowsill.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section last Wednesday about low-price restaurants in the Los Angeles area referred incorrectly to the Bistro Garden in Beverly Hills. It remains open.

title: Sarajevo Is Hit by Artillery Fire in Worst Attack Since February
description: In the worst bombardment of the Bosnian capital since a NATO ultimatum in February, Sarajevo was hit by 10 to 15 artillery rounds late this afternoon, probably fired from Bosnian Serb positions, a United Nations spokesman said here tonight.

title: United Cos. Financial Corp.(UCFC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss, which included loss of $ 17,585,000, or $ 1.87 a share, from disocntinued operations.(Loss)

title: Corrections
description: The Peripherals column in Science Times yesterday, about an integrated software program called Clarisworks, misstated the telephone number of its maker, the Claris Corporation. The number is (800) 325-2747.

title: Albany's Kingmaker Now Sets Sights on Giuliani
description: Even before the voters' verdict was in and his success sealed in New York's shadow slugfest of political surrogates, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato was viewing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as a driven enemy certain to persist beyond their bruising gubernatorial conflict.

title: EMC Bets on a PC Storage System
description: When the EMC Corporation, a leading maker of computer data-storage equipment, recently expanded its manufacturing operation, employees at the new site in Milford, Mass., discovered signs on the walls still bearing the name of the building's former owner, Prime Computer, a once-hot computer maker that is no longer in business.

title: South
description: ALABAMA

title: In Mozambique and Other Lands, Children Fight the Wars
description: In the rebel camps where Alberto Matevui spent five years of his childhood, he says the commanders usually called upon the young boys to perform the executions.

title: Nationalist, in U.S., Nice in U.S.
description: Buttoned grimly into a suit for his visit to America, the Russian nationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky insisted that all those nasty things people said about him just were not true.

title: News Corp.(NWS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 2 million from an abnormal item.c-After a charge of $ 11 million, or 5 cents a share, from an abnormal item.Share earnings are in American Depositary Receipts (A.D.R.).On Sept 30, the company announced that it would issue, as a bonus to shareholders, one share of limited voting preference stock for each two ordinary shares held by shareholders. The record date for the issue is Nov. 11 (Nov. 14 for A.D.R. holders).In addition, it was announced that, effective Nov. 14, the current outstanding ''ordinary'' A.D.R.'s will split on a one-for-one basis and on going each ''ordinary'' A.D.R. will represent four ordinary shares.

title: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK GOVERNOR MAN IN THE NEWS: George Elmer Pataki; Soft but Forceful Steps Lead to Paradoxical Victory in the Governor's Race
description: State Senator George E. Pataki, who was elected New York's 55th Governor last night, is almost a millionaire, yet he comes off as homespun and unpretentious: He says "gosh" a lot and is so forgetful of his appearance that on a recent campaign trip he mismatched one suit's blue jacket with another's gray trousers, and then had to change pants in a hotel alcove.

title: ANN TAYLOR SHARES FALL ON INVENTORY AND COST REPORT
description: Shares of Ann Taylor Stores Inc. fell yesterday, as investors reacted to increases in the retailer's inventory and costs in the third quarter. Shares of the company, which is based in New York, fell $1.875, to $41.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Ann Taylor said on Monday that its third-quarter earnings rose 92 percent, in line with analysts' forecasts. But an increase of 31 percent in its merchandise inventory per square foot from a year earlier and general costs that were higher than expected prompted the decline in the stock, said Maura Byrne, an analyst with J. P. Morgan Securities.

title: Rogers Signs for 9 Years
description: CARLOS ROGERS, a 6-foot-11-inch forward-center, signed a nine-year contract with the Golden State Warriors yesterday, leaving only one first-round National Basketball Association draft pick unsigned. Financial terms were not available, but the agreement provides Rogers with an option to become a restricted free agent after his third season.

title: Guatemala: Change the Message
description: For 40 years Guatemala has endured a civil war that, like many Central American conflicts, has been part cold-war proxy battle, part genuine social revolution, marked by disappearances, extrajudicial killings, torture, secret prisons and impunity for hideous human rights abuses. As in other such conflicts, the United States' intelligence services have played a highly questionable role.

title: PAGE BY PAGE
description: CONGRESS

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONAGRA INC., Omaha, said its Beatrice Cheese Inc. subsidiary had bought most of the assets of Dorman-Roth Foods Inc., Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., a maker of processed cheese products, for undisclosed terms. LABARGE INC., St. Louis, which makes electronic systems and devices and complex interconnect assemblies, said it would sell its operations in Flippin, Ark., to Avnet Inc., Great Neck, L.I., for an undisclosed amount.

title: Michigan State Fires Perles as Football Coach
description: GEORGE PERLES, wiping away tears, was fired as Michigan State's football coach yesterday by a university president tired of losing.

title: Who Won Where - The Races for Governor
description: Results at 1:35 A.M.

title: Ailing Klaus Tennstedt Puts Down His Baton
description: The conductor Klaus Tennstedt has announced his retirement from the concert stage because of poor health. Mr. Tennstedt, 68, has fought throat cancer and has had two hip replacements in recent years. He canceled performances frequently because of his health problems. But his probing interpretations of the 19th-century repertory -- Mahler in particular -- made his increasingly rare appearances notable events.

title: Gasoline Prices to Rise in Many Areas
description: New Federal clean-air rules will force drastic changes in the recipe used for gasoline in most urban areas in the next few weeks, and refiners and distributors are struggling to get supplies of the reformulated gasoline into place. Some analysts are predicting spot shortages and sudden price surges.

title: Personal Health; The real problem with children's scalp ills.
description: WITH school in full swing, lice and ringworm have once again gone to the heads of the class. But while the families of affected children are most distressed by what they regard as embarrassing if not repulsive infestations, dermatologists say the real problems lie in misdiagnosis and inappropriate and sometimes hazardous treatments. Ringworm Re-Emerges

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Fostering Intimacy In Folk and Art Songs Kaye Playhouse

title: Tense Times for France-Africa Tie
description: Rather than a fond summing-up of nearly half a century of deep involvement in African affairs, the 18th so-called Franco-African summit meeting was marked by unusual soul-searching on the part of French commentators and African officials.

title: U.S. Blamed for Soul's Wait in Limbo
description: In August, when Yang Yimei finally paid off his $30,000 debt to the smugglers who got him here from China, life was full of possibilities. He would work hard and buy a restaurant and bring his wife and 7-year-old daughter from Fujian Province to join him.

title: HASBRO PLANS CUTS IN NEW JERSEY AND RHODE ISLAND
description: Hasbro Inc. said yesterday that it planned to close its plant in Wayne, N.J., and cut 400 manufacturing jobs at its operation in Rhode Island. The company, a toy maker based in Pawtucket, R.I., said the layoffs were being made in an effort to balance plant capacity with manufacturing needs. Of the 400 workers in Rhode Island who will lose their jobs, about 280 are already on a traditional seasonal layoff, Hasbro said. Hasbro, which makes Milton Bradley and Parker Brothers games, said it employed 2,000 people at its plant in Rhode Island. The plant in Wayne, which employs 85 workers, makes infant care products.

title: Chrysler Switch to New Mini-Vans
description: The Chrysler Corporation expects to lose about 60,000 sales of its highly profitable mini-vans in 1995 because it will temporarily shut two assembly plants to prepare for new models, company officials said today.

title: Who Won Where - Connecticut Congressional Races
description: Results at 1:40 A.M. District 1 -- Reporting: 83 % x-Barbara Kennelly, D * 120,254 - 73 % Douglas Putnam, R 42,092 - 25 % John Forry, Oth 2,893 - 2 % District 2 -- 80 % Sam Gejdenson, D * 65,722 - 43 % Edward Munster, R 65,744 - 43 % David Bingham, Oth 22,624 - 15 % District 3 -- 86 % x-Rosa DeLauro, D * 96,689 - 63 % Susan Johnson, R 55,999 - 37 % District 4 -- 85 % Jonathan Kantrowitz, D 30,318 - 23 % x-Christopher Shays, R * 97,753 - 75 % Terry Nevas, Oth 570 - 0 % Irving Sussman, Oth 1,717 - 1 % District 5 -- 87 % James Maloney, D 72,402 - 46 % x-Gary Franks, R * 82,509 - 52 % Rosita Rodriguez, Oth 3,593 - 2 % District 6 -- 95 % Charlotte Koskoff, D 53,320 - 32 % x-Nancy Johnson, R * 105,636 - 63 % Patrick Danford, Oth 8,196 - 5 % x - Winner # - Winner and change in party control * - Incumbent

title: Strong-Side Linebacker With a Soft Side
description: Bobby Houston stood beside his locker at Jets camp here Monday, looking over a teddy bear somebody had sent to him as a present for his infant daughter, Taylor.

title: Officials Fear Budget Cuts Will Slow Transit Repairs
description: Few New Yorkers doubt their transit system has gotten better since the early 1980's, when the fiscal crisis of the previous decade turned the city's bus and subway lines into a shambles and left riders plagued by derailments, track fires and breakdowns.

title: Elusive Price Cuts Intrigue Japan
description: In a country where shoppers are used to paying double and triple what an American might for everything from computers to cosmetics, the emergence of widespread discounting has hit Japan like a revolution. The Japanese press has termed this happy trend "price destruction," declaring that it shows the economy is finally opening.

title: Simon Property Group Inc.(SPG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charges of $ 6,117,000 in the quarter and $ 15,272,000 in the 9 months from the prepayment of debt. Before the extraordinary item, net income was 26 cents a share, in the quarter and 70 cents a share, in the 9 months.Year-ago 9 months' share earnings included a nonrecurring gain from an anchor store sale. Before the gain, net income was 47 cents a share.Year-ago periods are pro forma as if the initial public offering had occurred Jan. 1, 1993.

title: Food Notes
description: Ordering for Thanksgiving

title: New York Congressional Races
description: 14th DISTRICT Campaigning on Her Experience, Maloney Defeats Millard

title: Girl Reports Rape In School Bathroom
description: A 14-year-old girl reported that she was raped on Monday in a bathroom of George Washington High School in upper Manhattan, the police said yesterday.

title: Union Pacific's Santa Fe Offer Uses a Trust
description: The Union Pacific Corporation stepped up its battle for the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation last night, proposing a two-step transaction in which shareholders stand to get less money, but more security, from the Union Pacific deal.

title: High Court Considers Limits of Congress's Power
description: Congress was on the defensive in arguments before the Supreme Court today as the Justices expressed doubt about the constitutionality of two recent Federal laws. One prohibits Federal civil servants from accepting pay for single speeches or articles, whether or not connected to their work. The other bans the possession of guns within 1,000 feet of a school.

title: EQUITABLE COS. (EQ,N)
description: The Equitable Companies said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 25 percent, as life insurance sales continued to cushion the company from higher interest rates that hurt its brokerage business.

title: For Those Who Are Keeping Count
description: FOLLOWING is a list of cookbooks still in print that have had spectacularly large sales.

title: After a Bitter Campaign, Voters Stick With Robb
description: Senator Charles S. Robb beat back a ferocious challenge yesterday by his Republican opponent, Oliver L. North, after one of the bloodiest and most closely watched campaigns in the country.

title: Telxon Corp.(TLXN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: For Rangers, the Cup Wasn't a Pot of Gold
description: Winning the Stanley Cup did not make the Rangers profitable last season.

title: Wolohan Lumber Co.(WLHN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1 million, or 9 cents a share, from selling a closed facility, in the quarter and 9 months.c-After a gain of $ 516,000, or 7 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Mets Promote Dave Howard
description: As part of a reorganization that represents a reduction in upper management, the Mets announced yesterday that they are promoting Dave Howard, the club's general counsel, to the position of vice president for business affairs.

title: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: Connecticut Congressional Races -- FIFTH DISTRICT; Franks Re-elected to Third Term After a Bitter Personal Campaign
description: Representative Gary A. Franks, a Republican from Waterbury who was seen as vulnerable in his bid for a third term, handily won re-election tonight after a lackluster campaign that focused on personal attacks and complaints even by the candidates that they weren't talking about the issues.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: George D. Sands, 75, A Scientist at NASA
description: Dr. George D. Sands, a NASA project scientist who was the spokesman for the Viking spacecraft missions to Mars in 1976, died on Nov. 2 at his home in Williamsburg, Va. He was 75.

title: Salomon Says It May Take Charge Against Its Earnings
description: Salomon Inc. announced yesterday that it may be forced to take an unspecified charge against earnings in the fourth quarter because of "certain unreconciled balances" on its books. But the charge, if taken, will not have any appreciable affect on its overall financial position, the company said.

title: Muscovites Fume Over New Import: Gas Lines
description: Motorists, gas station attendants and Government officials all agreed. The 10-day gasoline shortage that created mile-long lines, drove up black-market prices tenfold, and left cars stranded all over Moscow was no accident.

title: Republican Leaders: Setting Congressional Agenda With 'Contract' in Mind
description: NEWT GINGRICH

title: Toronto Sun reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.(Loss)

title: His Head Held High, Very High, Cuomo Is Done In His Way
description: Searching through the millions of glistening words that constituted Mario M. Cuomo's final campaign for governor, it is difficult to find more than a handful in which he explained how his fourth term would have been different from the previous three.

title: INSIDE
description: Dread Strands Rwandans

title: Mr. Pataki and the Albany Gang
description: Like the rest of the nation, New Yorkers voted for change on Tuesday. They stand to get lots of it at the top of state government, but if they are lucky and insistent the ascension of George Pataki could represent something more important. Mr. Pataki, a little-known State Senator, has an opportunity to reshape the cloistered political culture of Albany.

title: Another Epic, With 4 Plays in 6 Hours

They have been asked by the White House to return to Washington in less than a month to consider one final measure, the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs.

title: Delta's Terminals at Kennedy to Be Fixed
description: Kennedy International Airport, always crowded but rarely popular, will get an infusion of $150 million to fix up the Delta Air Lines terminals, the Port Authority announced yesterday. The money is part of a projected $5 billion in improvements planned for the next few years to deal with the obvious decay in terminal buildings as well as less visible problems, like deteriorating sewers and roofs.

title: Dr. Fell's Election
description: Tuesday's vote produced a political upheaval of historic proportions. It decimated the top ranks of the Democratic Congressional leadership, awarded the Republicans control of both houses of Congress and most of the big-state governorships, and confronted President Clinton, who was elected as a minority President, with a stark problem of political survival. Whether he can get any legislation passed and whether he is re-electable now depend largely on the strategic calculations of the likely Republican leaders, Representative Newt Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, and such obstreperous ideologues as Senator Phil Gramm.

title: Ketchum Protests Political Ads
description: Ketchum Communications has declared war on negative political advertising. In print advertisements that ran yesterday in The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal, Ketchum characterized negative ads as "political filth that is not advertising and shouldn't be dignified by being called advertising."

description: Six years ago, the Army had to fly in 17,500 soldiers from the United States and deploy 7,000 armored vehicles and nearly 1,100 tanks to practice the kind of epic battles the NATO alliance would have to fight if World War III broke out.

title: PNC BANK TO CLOSE UP TO 30% OF ITS BRANCHES
description: The PNC Bank Corporation will close up to 30 percent of its 612 branches in the next three years and open a national telephone banking center in Pittsburgh in mid-1995 that will meet the growing demand for services by phone, the company said yesterday. The branch closings in the five states where PNC operates -- New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana and Kentucky -- are part of a continuing effort by the company to cut costs, a spokesman said. The company announced last month that it would cut 286 jobs, or 1.2 percent of its work force of 23,000, but declined to say how many jobs would be cut when the branches were shut. PNC, based in Pittsburgh, is the nation's 11th-largest banking company.

MAXXAM CUTS STAKE IN KAISER ALUMINUM
description: Maxxam Inc. and its affiliates cut their stake in the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation of Houston to 4.8 percent of the outstanding depository shares and said further sales might take place. Maxxam, which is controlled by the investor Charles E. Hurwitz, sold 1.2 million depository shares at $8.12 to $8.62 each between Sept. 27 and Nov. 8, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The transactions left Maxxam with 1.2 million depository shares. Maxxam, which also holds 50 million common shares of Kaiser, said in the S.E.C. filing that it controlled 60.1 percent of Kaiser's voting rights. The common stock of Kaiser was unchanged at $11.875 on the New York Stock Exchange, while shares of Maxxam fell $1.50, to $36.25, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Turning Back the Clock in Slovakia
description: Although he outpolled his rivals in Slovakia's elections last month, Vladimir Meciar remains unable to stitch together a government and get himself formally named prime minister. But last week the Moscow-trained, rabble-rousing Mr. Meciar proved once again that while he cannot rule, he can still wreck. Just moments after the previous government resigned, he joined with parties from the far right and far left to railroad 13 measures through an all-night session of Parliament that sent Slovakia reeling back to the bad old days.

title: The Election's Fallout for the Economy; Trade Vote Is First Test For Victors
description: Newly victorious Republicans and a humbled Clinton Administration face their first big test even before the new Congress takes over in January, in a scheduled vote after Thanksgiving on whether to approve a long-delayed world trade pact.

title: QUAKER OATS DELAYS PROGRAM TO BUY BACK STOCK
description: The chief executive of the Quaker Oats Company, William Smithburg, said yesterday that the company would not buy back any more of its outstanding shares for the fiscal year that ends June 30. Speaking to reporters after the company's annual meeting in Orlando, Fla., Mr. Smithburg said the $1.7 billion in debt the company was taking on to acquire the Snapple Beverage Corporation would delay the company's buyback program. Last week Quaker Oats announced a definitive agreement to purchase all of Snapple's outstanding stock for $14 a share. Quaker Oats, based in Chicago, bought back three million of its own shares last year. Shares of the company fell $1.375 yesterday, to $67.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: PATAKI BEGINNING BID TO TRANSFORM STATE GOVERNMENT
description: After a late night of celebration, Governor-elect George E. Pataki set about transforming his campaign into a government yesterday, pledging to move quickly to enact the death penalty and a deep tax cut.

title: F.A.A. Restricts Some Icy-Weather Flying
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today barred airlines that fly planes like the one that crashed last week in Indiana from using automatic flight controls, or autopilot, during icy conditions.

title: Productivity In Business Shows Rise
description: Business productivity rose in the third quarter as American workers put in long hours and labor costs held steady, Labor Department figures showed today.

title: VIACOM AND COMCAST ORDERED TO PROVIDE REFUNDS
description: The Federal Communications Commission ordered Viacom Inc. and Comcast Cablevision Inc. yesterday to provide customer refunds totaling about $500,000, saying the companies had not complied with new rate regulations. The refunds would be the first since the commission introduced new rate regulations two years ago. The refunds were ordered in Baltimore County, Md., where Comcast Cablevision is the cable operator, and in Nashville and Goodlettsville, Tenn., where Viacom operates cable systems. The companies have 21 days to come up with a plan to make the refunds or to appeal the decision, an F.C.C. spokesman said.

Treffinger was able to capitalize on the problems of a Democratic machine that was tainted by corruption and rancorous infighting to capture the Essex County Executive's race on Tuesday.

title: Dealers Buying Again At Impressionist Sales
description: There's been a sea change in the market for Impressionist and modern art. At this week's auctions, which ended last night at Christie's, buyers tended to be either serious connoisseurs or dealers. Gone are the days of impulse buying. Gone, too, is a market so inflated that dealers and old-time collectors were priced out.

Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: ALCATEL UNIT PREDICTS BIGGER LOSS FOR 1994
description: Alcatel SEL A.G., the German unit of Alcatel Alsthom S.A. of France, said yesterday that it expected to report a larger loss for 1994 than previously forecast. In response, the company said it would cut an additional 1,800 jobs, bringing the total job cuts announced this year to 5,300, or more than 24 percent of its work force. After the cuts, which are scheduled to be completed in 1995, Alcatel SEL will have 16,000 employees. Alcatel SEL also plans to shut two factories, in Mannheim and Rochlitz. The unit is expected to be a drag on the profits of Alcatel Alsthom, the world's largest telecommunications equipment company. Alcatel SEL accounts for about 20 percent of the parent company's telecommunications revenue.

title: Glencore Buys Out Founder
description: Glencore International, the commodities trading and industrial company, has ended a 21-year relationship with its billionaire founder, the tax fugitive Marc Rich, by buying the remaining 25 percent stake he held in the group.

title: After a Strong Start, Capriati Loses Steam
description: Resurfacing from a 14-month sabbatical from professional tennis that turned out to be more debilitating than exhilarating, Jennifer Capriati made a spirited return tonight to the sport she abandoned in despair after it broke her spirit last year.

title: G.O.P. CELEBRATES ITS SWEEP TO POWER; CLINTON VOWS TO FIND COMMON GROUND
description: Republicans today declared a political revolution, promised to balance the Federal budget and generally reveled in winning control of both the House and the Senate for the first time in 40 years.

title: Primadonna Resorts Inc.(PRMA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Pro forma. Before deferred tax reinstatement in 1993.Latest share earnings for the quarter and 9 months excluded preopening costs, net of tax, of $ 2,280,000. Including preopening costs, the company reported earnings of 22 cents a share in the quarter and 70 cents a share in the 9 months.

title: Bridge
description: Choosing between a 5-3 fit and a 4-4 fit can be a difficult problem at the slam level. Study the North-South cards on the diagramed deal, with the East-West cards covered, and decide what contract you would wish to play.

title: Trico Products Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss, which included pretax restructuring expenses of $ 4,818,000.(Loss)

title: George Moskowitz; Arbitrator, 87
description: George Moskowitz, a labor lawyer and arbitrator who served on a number of statewide panels in New York, died Nov. 2 in Beth Israel Hospital North in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Israeli Soldiers Who Must Not Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: 'It's Like a Call to Arms, Which the Democrats Will Ignore at Their Peril'
description: Howard Baker Former Republican senator from Tennessee, who is now a lawyer in private practice.

title: Recycled Products: The 'Ugly' Factor
description: IT'S been a long time since "Don't, don't, don't be a litterbug," a jingle associated with the Keep America Beautiful movement of the 1960's, wormed its way into our collective consciousness. Recycling today is a lot more complicated and has gone far beyond merely tossing trash into the nearest garbage can. Now, it's de rigueur to sort, tie and leave it neatly stacked at the curb. The next step is to actually buy products made of trash, bringing our refuse back indoors.

title: Paper Accuses Goalie of Fix
description: Bruce Grobbelaar, one of the most flamboyant goalies in British soccer, was accused today by the mass circulation tabloid The Sun of accepting bribes to throw matches.

title: A Loner Is in Federated's Hot Seat
description: With the merger of Federated Department Stores Inc. and R. H. Macy & Company roughly one month away, the task of melding two fiercely independent armies of merchants who have spent the last 65 years as bitter rivals has fallen to a little-known department store executive.

title: Russian Nationalist Tells U.N. It Shouldn't Meddle in World
description: Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the Russian nationalist politician touring the United States, stopped by here today and immediately chastised the United Nations for interfering in international affairs.

title: A Daughter's Death, a Father's Guilt
description: Out by the noisy sawmill, the trailer parks, the taxidermist and the scrubby bait shops where Bobby Crabtree lives, there is very little mystery why he shot the daughter he doted on early Sunday morning.

title: Dr. James Watts, U.S. Pioneer In Use of Lobotomy, Dies at 90
description: Dr. James W. Watts, a neurosurgeon who performed the first frontal lobotomy in the United States, died on Monday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 90 and lived in Washington.

title: Not Just in Kansas Anymore; A Crop Artist Debuts on Manhattan's Unlikely Terrain
description: In Kansas, where Stan Herd is known for making art by planting arrangements of crops and flowers, pretty much all he needs is a tractor. Trying to replicate the process in Manhattan, he found he needed Donald Trump and two homeless people as well as the tractor.

title: Northeast
description: CONNECTICUT

title: Californians Pass Measure On Aliens; Courts Bar It
description: Californians overwhelmingly approved a new law cutting off most government services to illegal aliens on Tuesday, but Gov. Pete Wilson's orders to begin enforcing some of its provisions today were immediately blocked by Federal and state judges.

title: Burlington Industries Inc.(BUR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-After an extraordinary charge in connection with early repayment of debt of $ 621,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 4,261,000, or 6 cents a share, in the year.c-Net lossd-After an extraordinary charge in connection with early repayment of debt of $ 29,164,000, or 43 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 29,445,000, or 43 cents a share, in the year. The year also included a charge of $ 4,482,000, or 6 cents a share, which represents cumulative effect of accounting change.Latest quarter and year's income from continuing operations of $ 12,426,000, or 18 cents a share, and $ 99,299,000, or $ 1.46 a share, respectively, are after pretax restructuring charges of $ 7.5 million in the quarter and a pretax gain of $ 12.5 million on the sale of the company's decorative prints business less reserves established for certain other nonrecurring expenses; a $ 7.5 million pretax charge for restructuring and a $ 3.8 million pretax gain on the sale of an asset held for investment in the year.Year-ago quarter and fiscal's income from continuing operations of $ 3,448,000, or 5 cents a share, and $ 68,445,000, or $ 1.00, respectively, are after pretax restructuring charges of $ 19.5 million in both the quarter year, the year also included a $ 7.4 million pretax gain on the sale of an asset held for investment.Year-ago results are restated to reflect the cumulative effect of accounting changes for income taxes.(Loss)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Critic's Notebook article last Thursday about sexual permissiveness on television misidentified the host of the HBO program "Hardcore TV." He is Dave Konig; Dave Kolin, shown in the related photograph, is a performer on the program.

title: Bernstein Songs Survive in 1953 Musical
description: The truth about the New York City Opera's new production of Leonard Bernstein's "Wonderful Town" on Tuesday night lay somewhere between the opinions of those who left during intermission muttering about how awful it was and those who stood and cheered the celebrated lyricists, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, during the curtain calls. Bernstein's songs from this 1953 musical are as spirited as they ever were; the question is whether the show was always as campy and cliched as it was on Tuesday.

title: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS

title: Pope's Book Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Suncor Inc.(SU,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: ON THE ROAD WITH: Brooke Shields; Coping, From Toe to Head to Heart
description: THE morning after her opening night here in the road show of "Grease!" finds Brooke Shields padding around her hotel suite in bare feet, which, thanks to bunion surgery, are now as lovely as the rest of her. "I had to have both feet broken," she says, wincing, "but now I can wear high heels without three Tylenols."

title: Journal; On the Bright Side
description: "This is not the end of the world -- it's the end of a campaign," said a wise woman, Ann Richards, in conceding defeat Tuesday night. Others on the losing side in this election should follow her example and take a reality check. The world didn't end, the news isn't all bad, and, in any case, yesterday was the first day of the rest of the next campaign.

title: Tennant Co.(TANT,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 600,000 restructuring charge.

title: Researchers Ask Whether Prenatal Care Truly Saves Money
description: Prenatal care is often described as preventive medicine that pays for itself by averting future costs, but a new analysis says the savings have not been substantiated.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a Federal decision to end some clinical trials for AIDS patients in New York City misstated the name of an organization that runs one program. It is the Clinical Directors Network, not the Community Directors Network.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 85,000 in the quarter and $ 278,000 in the 9 months.Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: b-Net lossc-Included a reorganization charge of $ 210,855,000 and $ 219,855,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which were offset by an extinguishment of debt gain of $ 212,139,000. The 9 months also included a charge of $ 13,994,000 for an accounting adjustment.Year-ago share earnings are pro forma. Company's stock was not publicly traded at this time.

title: Nets' First Victory Features Benjamin In a Starring Role
description: Maybe it was the criticism directed at him by Coach Butch Beard. Maybe it was Beard's insistence that he join the team huddle with 2 minutes 16 seconds left; something about "sitting down and shutting up." Maybe it was the idea of not starting, a real possibility if he continued to produce at a pace consistent with the hatching of larvae.

title: Eritrea Didn't Expel Ethiopian Civilians
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEW FACES IN THE SENATE
description: ARIZONA Jon Kyl, 52, Republican

title: As Washington's Old Order Gives Way, No Clear Signs From the New
description: For American business, the immediate post-election impact from the Republican Party victories is the new faces coming to the fore in Washington as committee chairmanships change hands. Even so, the shift in control may not result in radical departures from current Congressional policies.

title: LDDS Communications (LDDS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
How to Save a Wright
description: To The Home Section:

title: On Capitol Hill, a World Is Turned Upside Down
description: The Capitol was an eerie place today, quiet and void of its usual bustle and the famous faces who orchestrate it. They are home either nursing wounds or nurturing new-found importance.

title: Walbro Corp.(WALB,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 2.9 million, or 34 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Enduring a Disease That Steals the Soul
description: I DID not laugh at the Ronald Reagan witticisms when they erupted this week, as they had to. I suppose I can understand the impulse; how else but with mordant humor to cope with the terror of an unpredictable and fatal illness that corrupts the memory and steals the soul?

title: Roving the Boroughs With Rover
description: "IT'S possible to own a dog in New York and still have a life," said Martha Kaplan, a writer for The New Yorker and mother to Clara, an animal-shelter mutt "who looks like a basenji on growth hormones."

title: In Stock: Design du Jour; Peeling Paint and More Trends at 3 Stores
description: LEAVES scattered to the wind, overturned baskets, weather-beaten signs, prairie kitchen tables with layers of peeling paint, banged-up watering cans, trailing ivy and rusted urns. These are a few of the favorite things in the city's most stylish stores.
