title: Parolee Charged In 12 Robberies Of Customers At A.T.M. Sites
description: Seized after a wild, crash-punctuated car chase by investigators who linked disparate clues and patiently staked out his stolen vehicle, a paroled holdup man was charged yesterday with 12 robberies in five days in which patrons were terrorized by a gunman at automated teller machines in Queens.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend LAR LUBOVITCH DANCE COMPANY, Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea. Through Sunday. Performances: Today at 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $30. Information: (212) 242-0800.

title: IRAQIS TO ACCEPT KUWAIT'S BORDERS
description: Iraq said today that it would recognize the independence and current borders of Kuwait, a major step apparently intended to allow at least some United Nations sanctions against Baghdad to be lifted.

title: Art in Review
description: Willie Doherty, Mona Hatoum and Doris Salcedo Brooke Alexander Gallery 59 Wooster Street (at Broome Street) SoHo Through Nov. 19

title: Mayor Forms Special Committee to Investigate Youth Services
description: Acknowledging that one of his agencies had fallen into disarray, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was creating a committee to investigate the city's Department of Youth Services and possible mismanagement in its awarding of contracts to community organizations.

title: Article 796808 -- No Title
description: If ever a restaurant were a one-man band, it would be Chez Bernard. Bernard Eloy -- butcher, baker, omelet maker and more -- presides over his empire as a warm, beaming paterfamilias, welcoming diners, recommending his specialties and offering the joyous invitation to eat, eat, eat.

title: Clinton Picks New Director of AIDS Policy
description: President Clinton today named Patricia S. Fleming, a former assistant to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to be White House director of AIDS policy.

title: In Small but Sure Ways, the Art Market Shifts
description: There were subtle changes this fall in the complexion of the market for contemporary, Impressionist and modern art in Manhattan. Both Sotheby's and Christie's edited their auctions, making them leaner and more carefully thought out than the spring sales. Catalogues were smaller, and the art was generally of better quality.

title: The Ghosts of Vietnam
description: This Veterans Day marks a turning point in our nation's recovery from the trauma of Vietnam. The last official prisoner of war, Col. Charles Shelton, an Air Force pilot, was declared dead this fall after having been kept administratively "alive" by the Pentagon for 30 years.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: PATAKI VOICES SHOCK AT GAP IN BUDGET

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Microsoft takes a user-friendly approach to selling its image in a new global campaign.
description: MICROSOFT'S first worldwide image campaign is so extensive, so expansive and so expensive, maybe the company ought to rename itself Macrosoft.

title: N.H.L. Union Awaits Response After Offering a Concession
description: Two months ago, before the beginning of the six-week-old National Hockey League lockout, a top league executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, told how the players could signal that they were ready to make a deal.

title: Producer Prices Fell Last Month
description: Producer prices dropped by five-tenths of 1 percent in October for the second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported yesterday, providing more evidence that inflation remained mild despite strong economic growth for more than a year.

title: Curb on Aliens Dims Dreams in Hollywood
description: The names of former students on the Wall of Fame at Hollywood High School unscroll like credits from the movie of all movies.

title: The Outlook For Tax Cuts, G.O.P. Style
description: The Republican action plan, known as the Contract With America, calls for tax relief for millions.

title: Only Futures Are Traded In Treasury Bond Market
description: Futures trading in an abbreviated session was the only activity yesterday in the Government securities market, with the cash market closed in observance of Veterans Day.

title: Dollar Ends Little Changed In Quiet Holiday Trading
description: The dollar was little changed in quiet trading yesterday as most American banks operated with limited foreign exchange staff because of the Veterans Day holiday.

title: United Asset Plans Its Biggest Acquisition
description: The United Asset Management Corporation said today that it planned to make its biggest purchase ever by buying Provident Investment Counsel, a money-management firm based in Pasadena, Calif.

title: In Venezuelan Dancers, Shades of Soviet Style
description: The Ballet Metropolitano de Caracas, which performs again tonight with its engaging and sleekly schooled junior ballerinas, is the equivalent of an American regional ballet troupe. Visibly the outgrowth of the school in which most of its young dancers have been trained, it aspires just as obviously to the top ranks it has yet to reach.

title: Undefeated Knicks Get A Road Test
description: After winning their first three games, the Knicks will find out more about themselves during the next week, when they embark on a challenging four-game trip.

title: Whitney Holding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 3,990,000 gain for recovery of charged-off loan in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included extraordinary income of $ 6.5 million, or 45 cents a share, for reduction in reserves for loan losses.c-Included extraordinary income of $ 6.5 million, or 45 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 39.5 million, or $ 2.74 a share, in the 9 months, for reduction in reserves for loan losses.Whitney Holding said that all per-share amounts are adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock splits effective February and November 1993.

title: REPUBLICAN TIDE BRINGS NEW LOOK TO LEGISLATURES
description: Mirroring the party's huge gains in Congressional and gubernatorial elections on Tuesday, Republicans made striking advances in state legislatures, taking control of at least 15 chambers that had been in Democratic hands.

title: A Virulent Potato Fungus Is Killing the Northeast Crop
description: Nearly 150 years after the Irish famine of the 1840's, new virulent strains of the fungus that devastated the potato crop in Ireland are spreading across New York and many other states, plant pathologists say.

title: From MSG to Sabres
description: DOUG MOSS, president of the MSG Network since 1992, was named president of the Buffalo Sabres yesterday. Moss's departure is the first among top MSG executives since Cablevision and ITT agreed to buy Madison Square Garden. Moss takes over the Sabres' management two years before the opening of Crossroads Arena. "They want to sell and market the team very aggressively," Moss said.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 3 and Wounds 12 at Israeli Post in Gaza
description: A Palestinian suicide bomber on a bicycle blew himself up today at an Israeli Army checkpoint in the Gaza Strip, killing 3 soldiers and wounding at least 12 other people, including both Israelis and Palestinians.

title: Giuliani Tries to End Feud, But His Phone Isn't Ringing
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called his fellow Republicans petty, ungracious and dangerously overconfident yesterday for the retaliation they are inflicting on him for supporting Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and he warned them that if in trying to punish him, they hurt New York City, they would only hurt themselves, too.

title: Esco Electronics Corp.(ESE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Girl Flees After Clash Of Cultures On Illness
description: Officials in this Central Valley town are not sure whether to look for Lee Lor, a 15-year-old Hmong girl with cancer who ran away from home two weeks ago with a backpack full of herbal medicines but no money.

title: Continental Planning Cost Cuts
description: Continental Airlines, which said earlier this week that it would cut 1,640 jobs, will take steps to eliminate about $150 million in costs in 1995.

title: A Wealth Of Facts On Shuttles
description: There's almost too much information packed into "Space Shuttle" to absorb in two hours. It comes in fancily photographed bits and pieces, from scientists, engineers, administrators, astronauts and others of the 30,000 people involved in the care and launching of space shuttles and their passengers. None of it is uninteresting (I learned that astronauts wear diapers), but the documentary, powered by a persistent musical beat, moves along so fast that a serious issue mentioned along the way is nearly lost in the quick cuts and odd angles.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7 U.S. BOSNIA STANCE CAUSES ALARM

title: Prodigy Is Sued for Libel
description: The Prodigy Services Company is being sued for libel by a closely held investment bank that contends a subscriber to Prodigy, an on-line service, defamed the bank in a chat line.

title: Reeves's Vocabulary Now Includes 'Playoffs'
description: O.K., so the season is far from over.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DRUG EMPORIUM INC., Columbus, Ohio, said it would sell seven Drug Emporium stores in the Washington, D.C., area to Melville Corp.'s CVS drugstore unit for an undisclosed amount. It will close an additional 14 stores in Washington.

title: Atkinson (Guy F.) Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charge of $ 739,000, or 8 cents a share, for cumulative effect of accounting changes.c-Net income and the 9 months included gain of $ 7.2 million on sale of the company's headquarters property and the effect of implementation of new accounting standards.Guy F. Atkinson said revenue figures do not include revenues from the company's discontinued operations, which are being sold.The company also said, ''Net income in the third quarter was less than the comparable period in 1993 primarily due to resolution of an old contract dispute resulting in a loss of $ 2.5 million; increased healthcare costs; and losses on foreign exchange totalling $ 1.1 million; and cost overruns amounting to $ 1.2 million on certain construction contracts.''(Loss)

title: Homeless Sleeping in City Office: Last Resort Is Now Part of System
description: Despite a decade of rulings barring the city from keeping the homeless overnight in offices and millions in fines levied for violating those orders, there was 1-month-old Nicholas Brian Gonzalez asleep in his stroller, packed in among the human steerage of New York City's overloaded homeless system.

title: Allou Health & Beauty Care Inc.(ALU,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings for the quarter have been restated to reflect comparable dilution.

title: Westinghouse Ratings Cut
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday lowered its ratings on Westinghouse Electric's $4 billion of publicly traded debt and preferred stock, citing the company's aggressive acquisition strategy.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN ADDS TO CRYSTAL BRANDS BID
description: The Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation said yesterday that it had increased its offer to buy Crystal Brands Inc. to $120 million from $105 million in cash. Phillips-Van Heusen first bid on Monday for the remaining assets of Crystal Brands, including Gant Sportswear and the Izod men's wear businesses. Crystal rejected the offer the next day.

title: SHARES OF CISCO SYSTEMS CLIMB BY ALMOST 8%
description: The stock of Cisco Systems Inc. climbed almost 8 percent after the company's first-quarter profit increase brought praise on Wall Street. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., designs and makes electronic equipment enabling computers to exchange information across the room or around the globe. Shares of Cisco closed at $33, up $2.375, in Nasdaq trading of 11.3 million shares. After the market closed on Thursday, the company reported a 56 percent increase in net income for the quarter ended Oct. 30, prompting Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. to praise the stock yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BASKETBALL SuperSonics Topple Suns Shawn Kemp scored 26 points and Detlef Schrempf got 12 of his 22 points in the fourth quarter to help the Seattle Supersonics defeat the Phoenix Suns by 129-123 at Tacoma, Wash., last night. The Sonics led 118-109 with 5 minutes 57 seconds left, but the Suns came back with three consecutive 3-pointers, two by Elliot Perry, to tie the score. Danny Manning scored 27 points and Dan Majerle 23 for Phoenix, which played without Charles Barkley and Kevin Johnson and Danny Ainge. Rockets 102, Celtics 82: Houston, which began last season with 15 victories, ran its record to a National Basketball Association-best 5-0 as Hakeem Olajuwon scored 26 points at Boston. The defending champions led by at least 11 points all the way after Kenny Smith's jumper from the top of the key with 5:29 left in the first quarter made the score 17-6. (AP) Mavericks 107, 76ers 100: Jamal Mashburn and Jim Jackson scored 22 points apiece as visiting Dallas held off a late Philadelphia rally. The rookie point guard Jason Kidd added 19 points and 9 rebounds for the Mavericks. Clarence Weatherspoon had a game-high 29 points for Philadelphia. Shawn Bradley had 17 points, 12 rebounds and 8 blocks for the 76ers. (AP) Warriors 112, Jazz 104: Tim Hardaway hit six 3-pointers and scored 30 points as visiting Golden State stayed undefeated by handing Utah its first home loss of the season. Hardaway connected on 10 of 15 shots from the field, including 6 of 10 from 3-point range. (AP) Hornets 123, Bucks 115: Dell Curry had 28 points as visiting Charlotte won for the first time this season. Marty Conlon hit the first basket of the final period to give Milwaukee a 95-94 lead, but the Hornets ran off 9 straight points, going ahead by 103-95 on a basket by Larry Johnson with 8:47 left. Alonzo Mourning had 24 points and 13 rebounds for the Hornets. The Bucks rookie Glenn Robinson scored 12 points in 21 minutes. Coach Mike Dunleavy said Robinson, who missed all of training camp, isn't ready to play a whole game. "He's played pretty good," Dunleavy said, "but the conditioning hurts." (AP) Bulls 112, Timberwolves 100: Scottie Pippen scored 22 points and visiting Chicago used a smothering defense in the third quarter to beat Minnesota, keeping the Timberwolves without a victory. Despite its best effort of the season, Minnesota has lost 15 straight. (AP) TENNIS Sampras Gains Semifinals Pete Sampras outplayed Byron Black of Zimbabwe, 6-1, 6-3, yesterday to reach the semifinals of the $1.1 million European Community Championship in Antwerp, Belgium. Seventh-seeded Magnus Larsson survived his second deciding tie breaker in two days to set up a surprise semifinal against Olivier Delaitre of France. Larsson struggled through three tie breakers to end the challenge of the Canadian qualifier Sebastien Lareau, 7-6 (7-3), 6-7 (5-7), 7-6 (7-5). Delaitre defeated Jonas Bjorkman of Sweden, 6-3, 6-3. (AP) Pierce, Zvereva, Sabatini Advance: Second-seeded Mary Pierce jumped to big leads in the each set and beat the newcomer Meilen Tu, 6-2, 6-4, to reach the semifinals of the $750,000 Virginia Slims of Philadelphia. Also advancing to the semifinals were No. 5 Natalia Zvereva, who beat Brenda Schultz, 6-1, 7-6, Anke Huber, a 6-3, 6-2 winner over Kimberly Po, and Gabriela Sabatini, who defeated Chanda Rubin, 6-3, 6-0. (AP) MARATHON Marklein Sets Race Record It took a while to double-check the results, but the winner of the handicapped division of the 25th New York City Marathon on Sunday was made official yesterday. Errol Marklein, a 35-year-old elite wheelchair competitor from Germany, completed the 26.2-mile course in 2 hours 8 minutes 36 seconds.

title: What Splits Up Groups? (It's Not Performance)
description: INVESTMENT clubs are forming at a rate of just under a hundred a week despite a troubled investment climate. But not all will survive, much less prosper.

title: World News Briefs; American in Guatemala Ends Her Hunger Strike
description: A month after an American lawyer began a hunger strike to force the Guatemalan Government to tell her what happened to her husband, a guerrilla leader, she sipped some diluted papaya juice this morning and called off her strike but vowed to continue to search.

title: Unsolved Rwanda Mystery: The President's Plane Crash
description: The death of Rwanda's President in a plane crash last April touched off a frenzy of killing: several hundred thousand people, most of them Tutsi, were slaughtered, mostly by Hutu soldiers and militia.

title: HARRIS TO CUT 700 JOBS AT ELECTRONIC UNIT
description: In a move to reduce costs, the Harris Corporation said yesterday that it planned to cut 700 jobs at its electronic systems unit. Harris, a supplier of information-processing and communications systems, said it would not take a charge for the layoffs. The electronic systems unit employs 7,500 people, mostly in Palm Bay and Melbourne, Fla. As part of the layoffs, about 35 percent of the unit's executive positions will be eliminated and certain functions in the unit will be consolidated.

title: City Official Is Charged Over a Deal
description: After an official of the Department of Finance applied for a $1 million city contract without mentioning that he was employed by the city, he perhaps should have reconsidered announcing his job title on a television news program.

title: Beatrice Kneeland Hartford College Trustee, 99
description: Beatrice Kneeland, who helped to establish the Hartford College for Women in 1939 and had served as a trustee since then, died on Sunday at the Cherry Brook Health Center in Canton, Conn. She was 99 and lived in Bloomfield.

title: What Do I.Q. Tests Measure? Not Intelligence
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ
description: Jubilant Music to Dance By, Produced by Actual Humans S.O.B.'s

title: CHRONICLE
description: A. LEON HIGGINBOTHAM JR., a former judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, will receive the first Spirit of Raoul Wallenberg Humanitarian Award there tonight. The award is to be given by the American Swedish Historical Museum, in Philadelphia, and the Elizabeth Ellis Foundation Trust.

title: Technology Group Rules the Roost So Far
description: Technology stocks had a smart third-quarter rally that made up for a rough second quarter. As a result, technology funds continue to outpace other fund categories for the year. But Laura Lallos, an analyst at Morningstar Mutual Funds, Chicago, said that many portfolio managers expected the group to slow down next year.

title: INSIDE
description: Asia Trade Differences

title: Topics of The Times; Parents Get Their Say
description: Parents, who could make a positive difference in New York City's neglected schools, are themselves a neglected resource. That can be corrected during Open School Week, which runs from next Monday through Thursday. It is important for the schools and for employers to make it as easy as possible for parents to participate.

title: Giuliani Sends Contract Offer To Legal Aid
description: Six weeks after steamrolling over a strike by staff lawyers for the Legal Aid Society and threatening to stop doing business with them altogether, the Giuliani administration has offered the organization a new contract with strict terms like a no-strike clause, monthly and quarterly audits, a taut budget and creation of a bureau to handle new cases more expeditiously.

title: Cable TV: Finally, Getting It Right
description: The Federal Communications Commission agreed this week to loosen some of the price controls it imposed earlier this year on cable operators. Critics charged that the F.C.C. had knuckled under to a powerful industry and cheated consumers. But the decision is welcome; it is consumers who suffer most from punitive rate caps.

title: What Do I.Q. Tests Measure? Not Intelligence; Recenter Grades
description: To the Editor:

title: Impersonators Bearing Badges of Dishonor; Police Begin a Crackdown on a Rising Tide of Impostors
description: It was literally a rude awakening for Steven Greenberg early one fall morning when he stumbled out of bed to loud banging at the door of his Park Avenue penthouse. The two men on the other side told him they were the police with search warrants and ordered him to open up. He did.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in some editions on Wednesday about a woman waiting to vote in Harlem misstated the location of the polling place. It was at Public School 28, on 155th Street at St. Nicholas Avenue, not at the Riverton Houses.

title: Serbs Recover Land Lost to Bosnian Army
description: Nationalist Serbs from Bosnia and Croatia advanced against Government units today in the northwestern enclave around Bihac, regaining some villages, local news reports and United Nations officials said.

title: Topics of The Times; Rollins Redux in New Jersey
description: Ed Rollins, manager of Christine Todd Whitman's successful campaign to be governor of New Jersey, stunned the political world last year by boasting that his staff had paid opposition Democratic workers not to work on Election Day. It turned out to be a lie -- according to Mr. Rollins himself -- but for weeks political conversation buzzed with talk of "street money."

title: Sports of The Times; A Beacon Of Light In Charlotte
description: WHEN Bill Simms talks about life, he often talks about "steps." Probably because he was a hurdler, well-versed in the importance of measuring each stride: too many or too few can be the difference between barely winning, narrowly losing.

title: Inter-City Products (IPR,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 100,000 in the quarter and $ 1,900,000, or 7 cents a share, in the 9 months, and the quarter included an after-tax provision for environmental costs of $ 1.9 million and after-tax restructuring costs of $ 400,000. The 9 months included an after-tax provision for environmental costs of $ 2.2 million and after-tax restructuring costs of $ 1 million.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 200,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 700,000, or 3 cents a share, in the 9 months. The 9 months also included an after-tax restructuring charge of $ 300,000, or 4 cents a share.(Loss)

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Attwoods Moves to Thwart Offer
description: Attwoods P.L.C. of Britain has proposed selling its waste management operations piecemeal in an effort to persuade shareholders to reject an unsolicited takeover offer of $570.3 million in cash from Browning-Ferris Industries.

title: Public & Private; Two Class Acts
description: The talking heads can argue about whether it was a vote against the President, against the party, against liberalism, about whether it was the revenge of the white male voter or the reaction of the middle class. And the Republican pols can spout pieties about working together for the American people while Newt Gingrich goes straight for the neck flesh, calling names, talking trash, practicing his patented brand of "I'm-O.K.-You're-Scum" attack politics.

title: 'Lady Macbeth,' Hated by Stalin, Finally Has Its Debut at the Met
description: Stalin was right. Shostakovich's "Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk," which received its long-overdue Metropolitan Opera premiere on Thursday night, is indeed "crude, primitive, vulgar." That was what Pravda proclaimed in 1936 after the Soviet tyrant walked out on a performance of the work, inspiring the most famous and most devastating music review ever published. As Pravda noted, a bed is at the center of the action, and there is nothing subtle about the music that accompanies the squeaking of its springs; Shostakovich nearly lost his life over his sound effects.

title: Bridge
description: One of America's wealthiest and most generous citizens died in Manhattan on Sunday at 92. He was Milton Petrie, the founder and chairman of Petrie Stores, who gave substantial sums to many victims of fate.

title: Europe's Insulation Market Is Target of Owens-Corning
description: The Pink Panther is coming.

title: Slater Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss(Loss)Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said that the increase in earnings reflects the impact of higher pricing, increased capacity utilization at the major divisions and continuing implementation of initiatives to improve profit margins. The decline of the U.S. and Canadian dollars against world currencies has increased competitiveness.

title: Move on Bosnia By U.S. Alarms Allies in NATO
description: European allies expressed alarm today over the Clinton Administration's decision to end Washington's role in enforcing an arms embargo against the Bosnian Government, warning that the unilateral move undermined NATO and could diminish the chances for peace in the Balkans.

title: Berg Electronics Holdings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 9 months results included ''two months ownership under DuPont and seven months under current ownership.''Berg Electronics Holdings said its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, or EBITDA, for the latest third quarter was $ 24.7 million, a 63 percent increase from the same period a year ago. The company said its EBITDA for the latest 9 months was $ 65.5 million, a 43.3 percent increase from the same period a year earlier.

title: Normal Like Me
description: Mr. Gingrich was stung before the election when remarks he made in a private session with lobbyists were publicized. The House Republican whip had said his campaign strategy was to portray Clinton Democrats as "the enemy of normal Americans" and the proponents of Stalinist measures.-- The Times, Noc. 10

title: A Beautiful Reservoir Needs an Elegant Fence
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,000 TO LOSE JOBS IN CHIP AND SOFTWARE OPERATIONS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 1,000 employees in its chip and software operations as part of its previously announced cutback program. I.B.M., the world's largest computer maker, said it would cut 700 jobs within the next several weeks in its microelectronics division, about 5 percent of the division's work force. In the software solutions division, 300 employees were told their positions would be eliminated. The reductions are part of a turnaround program that has slashed I.B.M.'s costs by $5.6 billion since the end of 1992.

title: Article 805149 -- No Title
description: Shares of the Chiron Corporation soared today on speculation that the company might be acquired in a deal worth more than $3 billion.

title: Bally's Grand Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2,103,000 from the sale of equity securities in both the quarter and 9 months.The company said the 1993 figures are not comparable because in August 1993, the company completed its reorganization pursuant to its Chapter 11 Plan and emerged from bankruptcy, thus implementing fresh-start reporting on Aug. 31, 1993.

title: Reactors Offer Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Flower Glower: Paterno Isn't Ready to Stop and Smell the Roses
description: Joe Paterno was making a point.

title: Q&A;
description: Rental Car Insurance Q. Should I take the liability insurance supplement that car rental companies are now offering for about $7 a day? I don't own a car and don't have any other insurance that covers liability to others when driving a rental car. The credit card I use to pay for car rentals provides insurance to cover damage to the car I'm renting, but I'm more concerned about adequate coverage for liability if I cause an accident. I rent cars six to ten times a year for periods of one or two days to one week for nonbusiness reasons.HARVEY BLECHER, Manhattan A. "I've been asked this question many times," said Stuart Kessler, a lawyer and financial planner in New York. "The $7 a day is cheap when you consider what you might be liable for."

title: Looming Budget Gap Was No Surprise, Cuomo Tells Pataki
description: Responding to criticism from Governor-elect George E. Pataki about a projected $4 billion budget gap, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo told Mr. Pataki on the phone this morning that the shortfall should have come as no surprise.

title: American Mantra: Blame the Black Man
description: The episode made a sweet-voiced old Southern lady I saw on TV more wary of black people. The ordeal of the young mother who claimed that a black man had abducted her children in a carjacking frightened this good woman. And for good reason. After all, you hear constantly what a menace black men are. They do make up more of the U.S. prison population than their per capita share. Books insisting on their genetic inferiority get published and accorded the respect of serious refutation.

title: REST OF SPELLING ENTERTAINMENT MAY BE BOUGHT
description: Viacom Inc.'s chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, said yesterday that his company would consider buying the rest of Spelling Entertainment in the next two months. Spelling is majority-owned by Blockbuster Entertainment, which recently merged with Viacom. Viacom's extensive media operations include cable television, broadcasting, book publishing and entertainment production. Spelling's stock closed up $1, at $11.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Redstone also said Viacom would consider buying a broadcast television network. In another development, Paramount Pictures, a Viacom unit, said it would extend medical and dental benefits to same-sex domestic partners of its employees, beginning with the new year.

title: Spelling Entertainment Group Inc.(SP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomec-Included a loss of $ 3,710,000, or 7 cents a share, from discontinued operations.(Loss)

title: Grits and Glitter Campaign Helps Actor Who Played a Senator Become One
description: In an election year when voters all but screamed their displeasure with Democratic incumbents and Big Government, here came Fred Thompson in his canvas work shirt and a rented Chevrolet pickup truck, looking more like a man who would stuff and mount a largemouth bass than like the lawyer, lobbyist and big-time Hollywood character actor that he is.

title: Benzonia Journal; Deer Season Is Back, But It Isn't What It Was
description: This time of year in northwestern Michigan, it seems as if there are two kinds of people: those who hunt, and those who don't.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 4 about a reduction of American companies' interest in Japan referred incorrectly to the Asian offices of Merrill Lynch & Company. The headquarters for the Merrill Lynch's Asian operations have long been in Hong Kong; they are not being moved to Hong Kong from Tokyo, where the company maintains an office for Japan.

title: Dr. Robert Henry Strotz, 72, Chief of Northwestern University
description: Dr. Robert Henry Strotz, an expert in economic theory and econometrics who served as president of Northwestern University from 1970 to 1985, died on Wednesday in a nursing home in Deerfield, Ill. A resident of Wilmette, Ill., he was 72.

title: Shock Treatment for the Budget
description: Governor-elect George Pataki finds it "shocking" that New York State faces a huge budget gap next year. But people who keep an eye on the state's finances have known for months that the situation was bad and getting worse. The gap will make it that much harder for Mr. Pataki to deliver his promised tax cuts.

title: Sorry, Ernie. TV Isn't Teaching.
description: Twenty-five years ago this week, "Sesame Street" made its debut. Although it has always been a reliably sweet hour of Muppets and music, educators have long debated whether it really helps kids learn to read or merely habituates them to watching TV.

title: Wesco Financial Corp.(WSC,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included loss of $ 187,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and a gain of $ 236,000, or 3 cents a share, in the 9 months, for sales of securities and foreclosed properties.c-Included increase in income-tax rate on deferred taxes of $ 2,132,000, or 30 cents a share, in the quarter, and the 9 months included gains of $ 1,023,000, or 14 cents a share, for change in accounting for income taxes, and $ 1,156,000, or 16 cents a share, for sales of securities and foreclosed properties, offset by losses of $ 1,617,000, or 23 cents a share, on the sales of New America Electrical Corp. and $ 2,132,000, or 30 cents a share, for an increase in income-tax rate on deferred taxes.

title: ALCOA DECLARES STOCK SPLIT AND RAISES CASH DIVIDEND
description: The Aluminum Company of America declared a 2-for-1 stock split yesterday and raised its quarterly cash dividend by 12.5 percent effective next year. Alcoa's shares have risen 27 percent since April. The surge reflected renewed confidence on Wall Street about aluminum stocks in general because of rising aluminum ingot prices and steadily declining inventories. Pittsburgh-based Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum producer, said the stock split would double the number of Alcoa's common shares to about 179 million. The new shares will be distributed on Feb. 25 to shareholders of record on Feb. 3. Alcoa also raised its quarterly dividend to 22.5 cents a share on a post-split basis, effective next year. The dividend was 40 cents a share before the split.

title: A Politician At the Rubicon
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani bolted his own party and endorsed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, he knew something the public did not: that Mr. Cuomo's campaign polls had begun to show him moving ahead of State Senator George E. Pataki.

title: Village to Vote on Whether to Keep a Notorious Police Force
description: Now that the elections are over, people in this square-mile village near the end of Long Island's North Fork are gearing up for the real contest. On Tuesday, they will vote on whether to abolish their nine-member police force.

title: What Do I.Q. Tests Measure? Not Intelligence; Preschool Study
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID BOULEY, the chef and owner of the four-star TriBeCa restaurant bearing his name, is also on the awards circuit. He will be honored tomorrow by the Michigan State University School of Hotel, Restaurant and Institutional Management at the Righa Royal Hotel in Manhattan. The school has named him its "Industry Leader of the Year."

title: Viking Star Shipping Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of assets of $ 3.7 million in the quarter and 6 months.c-Net income, which included gains on the sale of assets of $ 3.4 million.Year-ago periods ended Oct. 31.Viking Star Shipping changed its fiscal year-end to March from April, effective March 31, 1994.

title: Most Markets Open in U.S.
description: Most financial markets in the United States were open yesterday, although the cash market for Treasury securities and some banks were closed in observance of Veterans Day, a Federal holiday. The commodities markets were also open and futures on Treasury securities were traded.

title: Amerco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Amerco Inc. is the holding company for U-Haul International Inc.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Pairing Modern Works With Early Antecedents Alice Tully Hall

title: N.Y.R.A. Cuts Week to Five Days
description: The streamlining of New York racing took a step forward yesterday when the five-day week was approved, starting in December. Kenneth Noe, the new chief executive officer, pledged, "We may carry it further, too, including Sundays in the pro football season."

title: Jeanne Newman, 65, Public Health Expert
description: Jeanne Sumner Newman, a public health specialist who worked to improve medical services in developing countries, died on Oct. 24 at West Virginia University Hospitals in Morgantown, W.Va. She was 65 and lived in Baltimore.

title: Religion Journal; For School Storyteller, a Task of Biblical Proportions
description: Rosemary Lea admires the village people. For sure it's a retro fondness, but not for the macho men of disco fame. Her admiration is for the folks she knew growing up in the English countryside 67 years ago.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies Chiron said it was in talks on a strategic alliance with another company. The disclosure came after takeover speculation had sent its stock soaring. [ Page 39. ] In a shift, Santa Fe Pacific said it would consider a hostile takeover offer from Union Pacific. Santa Fe, which has agreed to a friendly takeover from Burlington Northern, rejected Union Pacific's first offer barely 24 hours after it was made. [ 39. ] Owens-Corning Fiberglas is trying to make inroads in Europe's $75 billion home improvement market. The American company is using the Pink Panther cartoon character in its marketing to help make it a worldwide brand. But many a brand introduction has turned on the unpredictability of foreign markets. [ 39. ]

title: When Considering Cuomo, Upstate Voters Saw Revenge
description: The human toll of upstate New York's lingering recession, and the motives for the revenge visited upon Gov. Mario M. Cuomo by its voters this week, can be sensed most mornings in the sun-washed dining room of Buckman's Bakery.

title: Union Offer Creates Little Stir By Owners
description: The National Hockey League didn't accept or reject the latest proposal by its players' association today as the second round of the union tournament was played at Copps Coliseum.

title: ANALYSTS' RECOMMENDATIONS ON SHARES PUSH STOCK UP
description: Shares of Pepsico Inc. rose strongly yesterday after two analysts recommended the stock. The stock rose $1.625 to close at $36.875 on volume of 2.5 million shares. It was Pepsi's highest closing price since May, before the company predicted that second-quarter profit would be flat. Yesterday, Emanuel Goldman, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc., raised his recommendation to "buy' from "neutral," and Andrew Conway, a Salomon Brothers analyst, upgraded the stock to "buy" from "hold." Mr. Goldman said he had upgraded the stock because Pepsi put Roger Enrico, vice chairman, in charge of its struggling international restaurants, which include Taco Bell, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut. "He's the Joe Montana of Pepsi," Mr. Goldman said.

title: Coach Beard Is All Hot Because Nets Are Not
description: Halftime in the Nets' locker room tonight came and went with a bang. Butch Beard, the first-year coach, gave a terse discourse on the merits of playing with effort and courage. "He blew up like a volcano," said P. J. Brown.

title: Graf a Question Mark
description: STEFFI GRAF said she was unsure whether her recurring back problems will allow her to play in next week's Virginia Slims Championships. Graf, seeded No. 1 in the $3.5 million event at Madison Square Garden, practiced yesterday with MARTINA NAVRATILOVA at the Pennsylvania Convention Center in Philadelphia. (Reuters)

title: Autumn Warning: Beware of Careless Hunters
description: To the Editor:

Universal Foods said that due to ongoing negotiations associated with the final valuation of the closing balance sheet and receipt of additional proceeds, it has not reflected any gain or earn-out income in its reported results.

Both periods' losses from discontinued operations included third-quarter charge of $ 9,398,000 for loss on discontinuance, and the quarter included a $ 788,000 loss from unit's operations, and the 9 months a $ 1,945,000 loss from unit's operations.Both latest periods also included extraordinary charge of $ 554,000, or 6 cents a share, related to accumulated postretirement benefits.c-Net incomed-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 470,000, or 8 cents a share, in the quarter, from unit's net, and $ 1,892,000, or 33 cents a share, in the 9 months, which included $ 1,278,000 gain from unit's net income and $ 614,000 gain from discontinuance of operations.Year-ago periods ended Sept. 25.(Loss)

title: At the Patent Office, a Digital Dawn
description: Gerald Goldberg has a dream: to plow through the Patent Office's backlog of 17,000 software patent applications. But he may also have a nightmare: somewhere in the heap lies another Compton's New Media case, ticking like an unexploded bomb.

title: Poet's Accountant Scans Bottom Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Issues of Race and Pollution Trouble L.I. Town
description: For years, residents of this predominantly black and Hispanic working-class community have held their noses, shut their windows and tried hard not to dwell on the smells and the unsightliness of the 170-acre industrial site just across the railroad tracks.

title: DANCE
description: The Japanese Art Of Speaking in Metaphors La Mama Annex

title: Health Care Plan Out; Health Care Stocks In
description: HEALTH care stocks enjoyed an election bounce this week as the Republican victory dashed any hopes of reviving President Clinton's ambitious health care plan.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball National League COLORADO ROCKIES -- Promoted Paul Egins, assistant director of player development, to assistant director of player personnel. Eastern League NEW HAVEN RAVENS -- Named Chris Canetti director of operations; Diana Kuen assistant director of merchandising; Mark Tomey marketing assistant; and Lori McCarthy administrative assistant. Basketball National Basketball Association MINNESOTA TIMBERWOLVES -- Placed Micheal Williams, guard, on the injured list. Signed Winston Garland, guard. TORONTO RAPTORS -- Named Glen Grunwald assistant to the vice-president of basketball. Football National Football League NEW YORK GIANTS -- Waived Jeff Mills, linebacker. Signed Darren Reese, guard, from their practice squad. Hockey National Hockey League BUFFALO SABRES -- Named Douglas Moss president and chief executive officer. Central Hockey League WICHITA THUNDER -- Activated John Vary, defenseman, from the suspended list. Waived Jason Hines, defenseman. Colleges MARYLAND -- Signed Gary Williams, men's basketball coach, to a seven-year contract extension.

title: Reaching Out, Bad Shoulder and All
description: Juan Nieves, who has made his living as both a pitcher and a pitching coach, one day plans to resume his education, most likely in sports medicine.

title: Observer; Tempers Hot and Tarry
description: Recent lunatic attacks on the White House had the President's Secret Service guards in an unusually keen state of alert. The public knew it, so hesitated to tar and feather the President and ride him out of the White House on a rail.

title: So Friendly: Chinese and Christopher
description: What a difference eight months make.

title: Tredegar Industries(TG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $ 2.43 a share, related to the company's Aug. 16 divestiture of Elk Horn Coal subsidiary for $ 71 million. The company said the gain was partially offset by a charge of 29 cents a share, in connection with a goodwill write-off in Tredegar's molded plastics business, and an after-tax charge of 12 cents a share, related to the planned shut-down of a molded plastics plant in Alsip, Ill.c-In addition to the third-quarter charges and gains, year-to-date results included a net gain of 67 cents a share, related to divestiture activities and associated deferred income taxes. This gain was offset by a net charge of 70 cents a share, in connection with write-offs of certain goodwill and other intangibles.d-After a net charge of five cents a share, related to the adjustment of deferred income tax balances for the 1 percent increase in the federal income tax rate.e-Included a net gain of eight cents a share, for debt refinancing and deferred income tax adjustments.

description: The net income in the latest year would have been $ 417 million had it not been for accounting charges taken this year to reduce future operating expenses.Revenue represented operating revenue.

title: Selling Homes: Is the Agent Getting Too Big a Cut?
description: People are paying real estate agents too much for selling their homes, the Consumer Federation of America says.

Preferred-share dividends in the latest 9 months totaled $ 30 million, against $ 39.6 million in the period a year earlier.The company's stock ticker symbol of TA is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The New York Stock Exchange reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The New York Stock Exchange said that the average daily volume in the latest third quarter was 274 million shares, up from 255 million shares in the year-ago period. For the latest nine months, average daily volume increased to 288.1 million shares, from 261.1 million shares, in period a year earlier.The Big Board said that 44 new companies were listed on the exchange in the latest quarter, bringing the total to 171 new listings in the first nine months.

The 9 months also included an extraordinary charge on debt prepayment penalty of $ 2,861,000, or 17 cents a share, and a charge of $ 393,000, or 3 cents a share, which reflects cumulative effect of changes in accounting for income taxes.c-Net loss and included a gain of $ 285,000 which reflects cumulative effect of changes in accounting for postemployment benefits and a loss of $ 1,448,000 which reflects cumulative effect of changes in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions.(Loss)

title: Life of 22 Years Ends, but Not Before Many Heard Message on AIDS
description: Tonight was the homecoming football game at Pedro Zamora's alma mater, Hialeah High School, his stomping grounds when he learned he was infected with H.I.V. and the place he returned to as a public speaker to warn young people like him to be careful.

title: Gingrich Queried By Ethics Panel
description: The House ethics committee has notified Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia that a number of questions have been raised about his use of a Republican fund-raising organization to develop and finance a college course he taught last year.

title: Owners' New Voice Is Peddling Same Line
description: Maybe if it were Willy Loman selling his wares or Professor Harold Hill selling trombones, replacing him with a better salesman could produce a greater volume of sales. But John Harrington doesn't figure to have any better fortune than Richard Ravitch selling striking baseball players a salary cap.

title: Leonardo Notebook Sells for $30.8 Million
description: A rare Leonardo da Vinci notebook containing more than 300 illustrations and scientific writings by the artist was sold for $30.8 million at Christie's yesterday. The price set a record for a manuscript sold at auction.

title: Getting Back on Track After Investments Go Sour
description: Julia and Richard Jordan, residents of the San Francisco bay area, sold a second home for a net profit of $224, 000 in 1987, about the time that Mr. Jordan took early retirement, "It wass scary, "Mrs Jordan said. "We didn't hav a clue about what to do with it."

title: POP
description: A Veteran of Gospel In Songs From Then and Now Tramps

title: Kuwait Journal; To the Disasters of War Add Defiled Desert
description: In the desert south of here are two glistening ponds about the size of football fields. But there is nothing inviting about them.

title: Walter Ward, 83, Ex-Member Of City Council From Queens
description: Walter Ward, a former Democratic member of the New York City Council who fought for clean beaches and against airplane noise, died on Wednesday at his home in Howard Beach, Queens. He was 83.

title: POP
description: A Pop Landmark Closes On a Mildly Nostalgic Note The Knitting Factory

title: Stocks Fall as Traders Await Rate Move by Fed
description: In light trading, the stock market declined for the second straight day as anxious traders awaited Tuesday's policy-making meeting of the Federal Reserve.

title: Latin America's Privatization Path
description: Arching over oceangoing freighters and stretching for 10 miles, the bridge across Rio de Janeiro's bay symbolized Latin America's state-led economic development when it was inaugurated here 20 years ago.

title: Jess Richards, 51, an Actor In Shows on Broadway and Off
description: Jess Richards, a versatile actor who appeared in 11 Broadway shows and numerous Off Broadway, touring and regional productions, died on Sunday at his home in Indianapolis. He was 51.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: A LAST RESORT IS NOW PART OF THE SYSTEM On many nights hundreds of people continue to take refuge in the city's after-hours homeless office in the Bronx, where straight-back plastic chairs or a plot of dirty floor are luxuries for the weary. The spectacle has become such a fixture that the city has budgeted $5 million to cover fines it owes to families dating back to 1991 and penalties it expects to pay through the end of year. And beginning next week, families left overnight in the office will be eligible for a $50 penalty payment the first night and $100 payment for each successive night. Page 1. CONSIDERING CUOMO, VOTERS SAW REVENGE Interviews with voters in five of the counties that turned against Mr. Cuomo with especial ferocity this week suggested that the main reason for their defection was their feeling that Mr. Cuomo had failed to fix their broken economy. Page 1. NEW YORK CITY GIULIANI FIRES BACK AT REPUBLICAN CRITICS Mayor Giuliani called his fellow Republicans petty, ungracious and dangerously overconfident for the retaliation they are inflicting on him for supporting Governor Cuomo, and he warned them that if in trying to punish him, they hurt New York City, they would hurt themselves, too. Page 24. When the Mayor gave his endorsement, he knew that Cuomo campaign polls had begun to show the Governor moving ahead. Page 24. BUDGET GAP WAS NO SURPRISE, CUOMO SAYS Responding to criticism from Governor-elect Pataki about a projected $4 billion budget gap, Cuomo administration officials issued a statement suggesting that if Mr. Pataki had done his homework before promising a 25 percent cut in personal income taxes, he would have realized that there was a problem. Page 24. THE ADORNED BODY CONSIDERED Once again the Old Guy didn't get it. Hipper people than himself told him that many women were having their belly buttons perforated so that they could attach rings. He went to see for himself. About New York, Page 25. OFFICIAL ACCUSED OF LYING TO GET A DEAL After an official of the Department of Finance applied for a $1 million city contract without mentioning that he was employed by the city, he perhaps should have reconsidered announcing his job title on television. Page 25. REGION POTATO FUNGUS IS KILLING CROP Nearly 150 years after the Irish famine of the 1840's, new virulent strains of the fungus that devastated the potato crop in Ireland are spreading across New York and many other states, plant pathologists say. Page 26. YOUTH FIGHTS REQUIREMENT TO VOLUNTEER Daniel Immediato is an unlikely litigant in a battle over the Constitution. Just 17, Mr. Immediato went to Federal District Court to fight his high school's requirement that students perform 40 hours of community service, on their own time, before they graduate. Page 26. VILLAGE TO VOTE ON OUSTER OF POLICE People in Greenport, a square-mile village near the end of Long Island's North Fork, are gearing up for a vote on whether to abolish their nine-member police force, which a grand jury report described as ill-trained, inactive and inept. Page 26. Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut is running for Senate minority leader. Page 11. Religion Journal.....27

title: AMR IS IN TALKS TO ACQUIRE STAKE IN AIR JAMAICA
description: The AMR Corporation is in discussions to acquire a minority stake in Air Jamaica Ltd., which is being sold by the Government of Jamaica. AMR, based in Fort Worth, is the parent of American Airlines, the largest airline operating in the Caribbean and a competitor on several routes with Air Jamaica. AMR is discussing obtaining a stake of about 5 percent to 10 percent in Air Jamaica, Air Jamaica officials said. The discussions are continuing, but no final decision has been made, said Horace Hord, American Airlines' director of marketing for the Atlantic and Caribbean. An equity stake could lead to use of AMR's Sabre airline reservations network by Air Jamaica, joint marketing or code-sharing.

title: John Volpe Is Dead at 85; A Nixon Ally
description: John Anthony Volpe, a former Governor of Massachusetts, Ambassador to Italy and United States Secretary of Transportation, died last night of natural causes in Nahunt, Mass., the police said. He was 85.

title: Today's Man reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Taiga Forest reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a new test for Alzheimer's disease misidentified the journal in which scientists reported their findings. It was Science, not The Journal of Science.

title: A Beautiful Reservoir Needs an Elegant Fence
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Saturday about suicides at Cornell University misstated the number of people who have jumped to their deaths in gorges on the Cornell campus in the last four years. It is four, not five.

title: Green Power
description: Ever since Popeye hoisted his first can of spinach, children have squirmed under the threat that "You're not going to leave this table until you eat those vegetables." O.K., so maybe there was virtue in kale and broccoli. But wasn't it possible that telling their progeny to swallow that stuff was just another way for parents to show who was boss?

title: Gingrich Claims A Victor's Spoils
description: Having traded his dusty Honda for a shiny new Cadillac, Newt Gingrich, the Speaker-apparent, made a triumphal entrance into Washington, inveighing against the "counterculture" and warning that "the question is whether or not our civilization will survive." Eschewing compromise with the White House, he asserted a mandate to reclaim old-fashioned values of hard work and swift justice.

title: With Thai Rebuff, U.S. Defers Plan for Navy Depot in Asia
description: The United States has put on hold a proposal to build a floating war depot in Southeast Asia that would strengthen American military readiness in both Asia and the Middle East, senior United States military officials said today.

title: Religious-Right Candidates Gain as G.O.P. Turnout Rises
description: Candidates aligned with conservative religious groups scored major gains on Tuesday in an election in which turnout increased among Republicans in every region of the country, two surveys showed today.

title: ONEX FOOD-SERVICE UNIT IN MARTIN-BROWER INVESTMENT
description: The Onex Corporation said yesterday that its Prosource unit would buy part of the Martin-Brower Company's food-service business for about $148 million. The acquisition, the second in as many weeks, will make Prosource one of the largest food-service distributors in the United States. On Nov. 2, Prosource, based in Coral Gables, Fla., bought Malone Products Inc. of Kansas City, Mo. When the Martin-Brower transaction is completed, Prosource's annual revenue will more than double to an estimated $3.6 billion from $1.6 billion. Martin-Brower's national account division, based in Downers Grove, Ill., is owned by Dalgety P.L.C., a British food-processing company.

title: Gingrich, Now a Giant, Claims Victor's Spoils
description: Once, Newt Gingrich was the man with the big agenda, small press entourage and slightly banged-up Honda Accord. Today, victorious and shining in the camera lights, he unfurled from the glinting black Cadillac Fleetwood Brougham that matches his new status as the big man in town, strode to a lectern, grinned and spurned any sort of compromise with the White House.

title: The Jets' Creativity Extends to Healing, Too
description: Mo Lewis's mother sent it to him in a brown bottle, from Peachtree City in Georgia.

title: A Singer Who Doesn't Play That Nice Girl Next Door
description: Diamanda Galas never does anything nice and easy. She pushes her voice to its limits, shrieking and cackling, rasping and swooping, howling and ululating. John Paul Jones helped make rock history with his walloping bass lines in Led Zeppelin. Together, the two connoisseurs of excess have made an album, "The Sporting Life" (Mute), and on Thursday night at Irving Plaza, they performed their new songs.

title: Gibson Greetings Inc.(GIBG,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 2.3 million reduction in the company's previously reported loss on derivative transactions.c-Included cumulative losses from interest rate derivative transactions, including a $ 2.3 million reduction in the third quarter.d-Net income(Loss)

title: World News Briefs; All That's Wrong: A Russian's Catalogue
description: Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the ultranationalist Russian politician, met with Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali here tonight and told him the United Nations should be broken up.

title: Frederick Kappel, 92, Ex-Chief Of AT&T and Former U.S. Aide
description: Frederick R. Kappel, a former chairman of the AT&T Corporation who later held posts in the Johnson and Nixon Administrations, died on Thursday in Sarasota, Fla., at 92.

title: After a Hole-in-One, 79-Year-Old Man Dies
description: Moments after shooting his first hole-in-one, Emil Kijek collapsed and died on the golf course Thursday. Emergency medical workers tried unsuccessfully to revive Kijek, 79, of North Attleboro, Mass., but he was pronounced dead at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. The hospital declined to release the cause of death yesterday. A funeral home said Kijek, who played golf as many as four times a week, suffered from hypertension.

title: Players Go to Europe
description: Calgary wing THEOREN FLEURY and Philadelphia forward MIKAEL RENBERG yesterday became the latest National Hockey League players to join teams in Europe. Fleury agreed to play on a game-to-game basis for Tappara of Tampere in the Finnish Hockey League, and Renberg was cleared to play for his former Swedish Elite League team, Lulea, during the N.H.L. lockout.

title: Carmen McRae Is Dead at 74; Jazz Career Spanned 5 Decades
description: Carmen McRae, the jazz singer known for her probing interpretations of lyrics and her bruised but unbowed point of view, died on Thursday evening at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 74.

title: Court Eases Restraining Order in Tobacco Document Case
description: The Kentucky Court of Appeals yesterday lifted an order preventing a paralegal aide who has been accused by a tobacco company of divulging confidential documents from speaking to his lawyers about the case.

title: Student Fights Requirement To Volunteer In Community
description: Daniel Immediato might seem an unlikely litigant in a battle over the Constitution. Just 17, and sporting a goatee and a Mickey Mouse tie, Mr. Immediato went to Federal District Court here this week to fight his high school's community-service requirement.

title: Many Unknowns in the Lineup Of G.O.P. House Panel Chiefs
description: On Wednesday morning, after the startling news that the Republicans will control the House of Representatives for the first time in 40 years, a Pentagon official told a colleague that the new chairman of the House Armed Services Committee is likely to be Floyd D. Spence of South Carolina.

title: No Headline
description: "I want to draw a distinction between two words. I am very prepared to cooperate with the Clinton Administration. I am not prepared to compromise. On everything on which we can find agreement, I will cooperate. On those things that are at the core of our contract, on those things which are at the core of our philosophy and on those things where we believe we represent the vast majority of Americans, there will be no compromise." -- NEWT GINGRICH. [ 11:1. ]

title: In Defeat, Clinton Aides Find Their Silver Lining
description: In the Pennsylvania Avenue home of the Comeback Kid, the talk to reporters since Tuesday has been about rising again from the canvas and rolling the stone back up the hill.

title: Men's Wearhouse Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Sacrifice Forms Part of Doctor's Training
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles H. Tenney, 83, Judge and Deputy Mayor
description: Charles H. Tenney, a senior judge in the Federal District Court in Manhattan and a former deputy mayor under Robert F. Wagner, died yesterday at his home in Islip, L.I. Mr. Tenney, who also had an apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, was 83.

title: The Adorned Body: Who? How? Why?
description: ONCE again, the Old Guy didn't get it.

title: Topics of The Times; With Friends Like This . . .
description: Guy Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President, who served as chairman of George Pataki's gubernatorial campaign in New York City, soared high on the insensitivity scale when he told a Columbus Day meeting of policemen that Karen Burstein, the Democratic candidate for attorney general, was unfit for the job because she is a lesbian.

title: U.S. Supports Asia-Pacific Free Trade, but Questions Timing
description: A meeting of representatives from 18 countries on both sides of the Pacific Ocean opened on Friday with signs that the United States had reservations about how rapidly different countries should move toward achieving free trade across the region.

title: TAKING HAITI
description: Alex Webb's photograph of the United States Army's "invasion" of Haiti, with soldiers in full battle gear, and the cameramen in the line of fire to get the best picture, will be ranked as a classic of the 1990's -- alongside pictures of the news media following the O. J. Simpson Bronco chase ("Taking Haiti," Oct. 23). However, journalists should use the correct adjectives when describing these events. The invasion was in reality an excursion, and the Bronco chase was more like a procession. JOHN O. HELGESEN Southold, L.I.

title: Strange Conduct Test for Justice Thomas
description: To the Editor:

title: Science Fiction
description: "Nan-" or "nano-": a prefix derived from the Latin word for dwarf. Used by scientists to denote the very, very small, as in "nanosecond," a billionth of a second. Used by science fiction writers in combination with the suffix "-tech" to refer to tiny machines that function on a molecular or even atomic scale.

title: The 'Third World' Is Dead, but Spirits Linger
description: NOT more than 60 miles down the highway from the Indonesian hill town of Bogor, where President Clinton will take part this week in an economic summit of Asian-Pacific nations, is a genteel city that once symbolized everything the third world believed in and hoped for when it was young. The city is Bandung. There, another generation of world leaders -- Nehru, Nasser, Nkrumah, Sukarno, Zhou Enlai -- met at another summit, the 1955 Afro-Asian Conference, a gathering full of post-colonial promise, with dreams of self-sufficiency, solidarity among newly independent nations and commitment to an anti-superpower international policy that became known as nonalignment.

title: Bright Light, Big Cacti, Top Models
description: Compared with Miami, Phoenix has a fairly anemic night life. There have been no reports of Versace or other designers buying real estate in Arizona, and no Madonna sightings yet, although it has been confirmed that Kate Moss was in Phoenix last month. But she wasn't there to work.

title: 'If I Were Younger I Would Make Myself Russian': Voltaire's Encounter With the Czars
description: "WHEN, toward the beginning of our century the czar Peter laid the foundations of Petersburg, or rather of his empire," Voltaire observed in the 18th century, "no one foresaw success." No one, he thought, could have imagined that arts and letters would flourish there, that the Russian empire, "almost unknown to us until then, would be civilized in 50 years," and anyone who predicted it would have been dismissed as a visionary. Voltaire spoke for the 18th century's amazement at the phenomenon of Russia, its revolutions and transformations, unforeseeable and unimaginable to those who watched from far away.

title: The Least Angry Man
description: WE'RE READY FOR YOU, MR. GRODIN Behind the Scenes at Talk Shows, Movies, and Elsewhere. By Charles Grodin. 320 pp. New York: A Lisa Drew Book/ Charles Scribner's Sons. $22.

title: BENNINGTON MEANS BUSINESS
description: There is a dimension that is missing from your intriguing examination of Bennington College and its president, Elizabeth Coleman. Your photographs played a phalanx of sympathetic-looking former faculty members against a stark, "the cheese stands alone" portrait of an embattled administrator. But there is another side of Coleman, as an educator.

title: The View From The Former Top
description: SPECIAL TRUST By Robert C. McFarlane with Zofia Smardz. Illustrated. 399 pp. New York: Cadell & Davies. $25.

title: Fulfilling a Dream at the Film Festival
description: FOR Steven Gilder of Roslyn the vehicle for his dream was the Hamptons International Film Festival.

title: POP BRIEFS
description: MC 900 Ft. Jesus: 'One Step Ahead of the Spider' American Records 945560-2; CD and cassette.

title: Capturing a New Sense of Freedom in Eastern Europe
description: THE walk-up apartment in which Mark Sadan lives here is not quite the artist's garret of "La Boheme," but the ambiance comes close.

title: To Dance In Veracruz
description: IN Veracruz, everyone dances.

title:
SOAPBOX;
Closed-School Week
description: I AM not given to maudlin nostalgia. Especially the New York variety. You can have the trolleys, the Dodgers, the egg creams. When I was growing up in the Bronx, neighborhoods and schools were often smelly and tough and brutalizing. I don't miss getting bottles of ink spilled on my pants nor being unable to leave my seat without papal dispensation. The universally fixed curriculum, bolted seats and desks, white shirts and blue ties on assembly days were relics of fear: of spontaneity, of change, of permission.

title: Echoes of a Lurid Murder In Fight Over Co-Op Sale
description: It was a lurid tale of gambling, prostitution, infidelity and murder worthy of a Penny Dreadful, and it happened on the Upper East Side. When Mark Fein, a wealthy executive who lived with his wife and three children at 1095 Park Avenue, was convicted of killing his bookie three decades ago, it earned headlines around the nation.

title: Profile; Utility Competition Is Coming! (He's Ready, of Course)
description: AS the 45-story stacks of the giant Gibson generating station loomed into view amid the cornfields and woods here in southwestern Indiana, James E. Rogers looked down from the helicopter and said, "Thank God I've got smart people running this."

title: Anita C. Levy, Robert S. Nelson
description: Anita Caren Levy, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morton G. Levy of Roslyn, L.I., and Robert Stuart Nelson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Z. Nelson of New York, were married last evening in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VALLAGE -- A Second Avenue Farewell, a Bowery Debut; Fillmore's Next Act: The Wrecking Ball
description: Say "Fillmore East," and many people think of the golden age of rock. Under the direction of the impresario Bill Graham, headliners on the stage at 105 Second Avenue included the likes of B. B. King, Jimi Hendrix, the Doors, the Grateful Dead and Otis Redding. Concerts often lasted till dawn; legend has it that Ike Turner once fired a pearl-handled pistol into the pavement to clear a way through the crowd for Tina and the Ikettes.

title: Behind the Macy Thanksgiving Parade
description: REMOVED from this city's trendy boutiques and sidewalk cafes is a warehouse, a former factory where once Tootsie Rolls trundled off an assembly line. Today the only clue of what might lie behind the building's massive roll-up door is some scattered confetti on the ground.

title: RICHARD FERBER
description: As a pediatrician, I was dismayed to see, beneath the photo of Ferber, a picture of a cuddly infant sleeping on his tummy. Excellent recent studies show an increased risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome in infants put to bed on their stomachs. The SIDS prevention motto is now "Back to Sleep." STEPHEN J. HARRIS, M.D. San Jose, Calif.

title:
MUSIC;
Pianist's Role at Institute Is a 'First'
description: THE last artist in residence at the Institute for Advanced Study here was T. S. Eliot, who had a one-year residency in 1948. The recent appointment of the pianist Robert Taub, a Princeton resident, is the first time a musician has been formally associated with the institute.

title: Exotica in a Chinese Banquet
description: LONG ISLAND has many fine restaurants, but few unusual ones. A good meal is not difficult to find but a very different one is. Interesting dining experiences are rare, and exotic ones are even rarer. But they do exist.

title: Jeannine Iverson, Glenn Strovilas
description: Jeannine Marie Iverson, a daughter of Gretchen and Jesse Iverson of Norwalk, Conn., was married on Friday to Glenn Charles Strovilas, a son of Jackie and Dr. Crist Strovilas of Toronto, Ohio. The Rev. John Wall performed the ceremony at Old St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Chicago.

title: Car Rental Companies Raise Their Rates
description: The Hertz Corporation recently raised its rates, leading to a scramble by other major rental-car companies to follow suit. A Hertz spokesman said the 8 to 10 percent increase was overdue, reflecting higher car prices. The rental increases are $3 to $5 in daily rates, $2 in weekend rates and $10 to $20 in weekly rates.

title: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'
description: To the Editor:

title: Aristide Under Pressure to Set an Election Date
description: Three years of military dictatorship left Haiti with no electoral commission, no reliable voter registration rolls, even a shortage of paper to print ballots.

title: DUMBING DOWN
description: I can't begin to convey my surprise and exhilaration on reading Henig's description of schools today. What a relief, in this age of political correctness, to see it told as it is. H. M. SMITH Fanwood, N.J.

title: On a Peaceful Sound, Memories of Normandy
description: MOST of the assembling passengers were unaware they were about to board a Green Monster. After all, it looked like a benign white whale, and it was, in fact, a ferryboat.

title: Cashing Checks
description: To the Editor: In September, on my first trip to Germany, I changed American Express traveler's checks into German marks at three banks with appalling results. In Bonn, I was charged a 16 percent service charge, in Rudesheim, 19 percent, and in Speyer, 26 percent. I asked the manager to return my traveler's checks and I would give back the money. He refused, saying that the transaction had already been made.

title: Jeannine Weimar, K. J. Fitzpatrick
description: Jeannine Ann Weimar, a research assistant at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, is to be married today to Dr. Kenneth John Fitzpatrick, a resident in urology at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia. The Rev. John C. Mulqueen is to officiate at St. Frances de Chantal Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'
description: To the Editor:

title: Compaq Storms the PC Heights From its Factory Floor
description: A YEAR ago, Eckhard Pfeiffer caused a stir in the personal computer industry when he predicted that the Compaq Computer Corporation would be No.1 by 1996.

title: Johnson & Johnson Sued Over Dismissal
description: A former senior research scientist at Johnson & Johnson is claiming in Federal court that he was dismissed when he resisted pressure to present "inadequate and misleading" test data to win quick Food and Drug Administration approval for a new treatment for cancer and other diseases, like AIDS.

title:
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE - A Second Avenue Farewell, a Bowery Debut;
Hot Bar Deemed Uncool by the Untrendy
description: They said they wanted a "soft opening," a chance to ease the staff and kitchen into stride and not upset the locals. So the owners of the long anticipated Bowery Bar told just a few friends. Of course, friends told friends, Page Six of The New York Post told everyone, and somehow, by midnight Oct. 21 on the first night, Cindy Crawford was seen in the back room and Lauren Hutton was sampling the fare. And as the Bowery Bar spins into its third week, Anna Wintour has already held a dinner there for Karl Lagerfeld, and Linda Evangelista, the model, has picked it for her birthday soiree.

title: Stephanie Hairston, Cornelius Martin
description: THE Rev. Cornelius Martin, 36, and Stephanie Hairston, 32, teach at Brown Academy, a public middle school in the Clinton Hills section of Newark, N.J., a forbidding, rundown neighborhood. "The homes are neat inside, but the buildings are falling apart," said Miss Hairston, who teaches seventh grade. "There's drugs in the stairwells, people getting shot and stabbed in the elevators. The violence goes on and on."

title: Climate Change Played a Role in India's Plague
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaking Of the Devil
description: IF you tromp around Moscow enough in winter, you'll want a bit of deviltry, or at least some decent hot tea. After you've done Red Square, seen the "smoked fish" (as young Russians call Mr. Lenin's corpse) and become tired of running into other foreigners in the hotels, take a walk through the lovely square around Patriarch's Pond.

title: SUNDAY, November 13. 1994; The Time of Life
description: A prime candidate for most useless piece of electronic nonsense to be marketed in 1994 -- the Timisis Lifeclock. The Zygon International catalogue copy reads: "Enter your name, gender and age. This microcomputer clock then counts down the actual hours, minutes and seconds remaining in your lifetime." Well, actually it counts the hours, minutes and seconds in the life of a statistically average person of your gender and age. Of course, that's not all. For a mere $99.95, it also looks like a personal organizer and provides you with 150 "motivational messages," if you have the time to read them.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Does This Book Go too Far?
description: A STRANGE thing happened at the top of the New York Times children's best-seller list last May. Leading the picture-book pack, outrunning time-honored classics like "The Tale of Peter Rabbit" (1902), "Where the Wild Things Are" (1963) and even the No. 2 "Goodnight Moon" (1947), was a long shot called "Love You Forever" (1986).

title: From Gym To Theater At Hackley
description: THERE may not be any second acts in American life, as F. Scott Fitzgerald claimed, but David P. Bridges was determined that there would be a second act for an antiquated building on the campus of the Hackley School here.

title:
Street Redeemer;
James Galipeau
description: IT'S 9:30 ON A HOT WEDNESDAY SUMMER night in South Central, the "backhood" of the Rolling 60's Crips, one of Los Angeles's most feared gangs. Darkness hides the graffiti and trash and highlights the neat outlines of small homes planted next to each other. Cars sit in driveways and outdoor lights illuminate front doors and porches. It could almost be a pleasant, downscaled suburban scene, except that overhead there is the flap flap flap of the police helicopter as it sweeps over the neighborhood. Jim Galipeau, a 29-year veteran gang probation officer, now with the Metropolitan Specialized Gang Unit, is out looking for a probationer who has missed his Monday call-in -- a bad sign. Though it's not late, the streets are deserted; there's an ominous stillness in the air. It's like Vietnam, says Galipeau, where the night belonged to the Vietcong. In this neighborhood, night belongs to the Rolling 60's.

title: Leadership, Equality and Violence on Bishops' Agenda
description: In their first meeting since Pope John Paul II "definitively" ruled out the possibility of female ordination, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops are convening in Washington this week for discussions on promoting church leadership and equality for women.

title: 2 Historic Lattingtown Mansions to Be Opened for Rare Tour
description: TWO years ago, when Denise Raquet moved into Lockjaw Ridge, a historic mansion in Lattingtown designed by Theodate Pope Riddle, one of the first female architects in the United States, she had one goal in mind: to make the 22-room 12,000-square-foot house that once had an elevator and still has 15 working fireplaces and a commercial boiler feel like home.

title: RICHARD FERBER
description: Richard Ferber sure has "tapped into an enormous need" -- the need of a culture addicted to a quick fix, yet terrified of dependence ("Richard Ferber: When Lullabies Aren't Enough," by David Blum, Oct. 9). His work may help those suffering from real sleep disorders, but a baby who wakes for comfort must not be considered a "problem facing almost every new parent." RENA SHEIN Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Alomar Has Knee Surgery
description: Cleveland Indians catcher SANDY ALOMAR underwent successful arthroscopic surgery on his left knee on Friday and is expected to return to full activity in about a month, the team said.

title: Darryl Shrock and Pamela Mandell
description: Pamela Lynn Mandell and Darryl Jay Shrock, marketers at American Express Travel Related Services in New York, were married yesterday evening in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi David Bateman performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Abraham.

title: Climate Change Played a Role in India's Plague; Action by New Delhi
description: To the Editor:

title: Stephanie Gruber And Peter Ross
description: Stephanie Ann Gruber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Gruber of Woodbury, L.I., was married last evening to Peter Jonathan Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Ross of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony at Harrison House in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Wengen Winter
description: AN Ogre, a Monk and a Virgin -- however unlikely a trio, the three great ascending peaks of central Switzerland stand guard over the snow fields of Wengen and Grindelwald, the chief ski stations of the Bernese Oberland high above the sedate resort of Interlaken. Wengen, which has only about 1,050 permanent residents, is much the smaller and prettier of the two villages, made all the more pleasant by the absence of cars. It was there I chose to go for a busman's holiday in the first week of March: after six weeks of working in a children's ski camp, I wanted to ski for myself.

title: Beth L. Smith, Joseph Mark Korn
description: Beth Lauren Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence E. Smith of Harrison, N.Y., is to be married today to Joseph Mark Korn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Korn of Washington. Cantor Bernard Dienstag is to officiate at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 19TH CAT SHOW

title: Manhattan Minute
