It's hard to spend any time there and not get caught up in a dizzy contemplation of what it all means. The city is really worse than Venice in this regard. You land at McCarran Airport, rent your nondescript, air-conditioned Lanugo or Aquire or Flabia, crack open a roll of quarters, and you're ready to surf the treacherous metaphorical waters of the capital of the American dream. The American dream, distilled, is to get rich by turning nothing into something, no place into someplace. Never has nowhere been transformed more rapidly, against more brutal odds, with such a monstrous payoff, than in the region known to geologists as the Las Vegas zone of deformation.

title: The Future Governor And the One He Beat
description: Pressed for anecdotes about the colorful side of the man chosen to lead 18 million New Yorkers, friends are -- well, pressed. They offer words like "plain," with no stigma attached. Indeed, Governor-elect George E. Pataki seems to have cultivated just such an image.

title: Raising Funds To Preserve A Way of Life
description: The Historic Hudson Valley group holds a dinner-dance at the Rainbow Room, Nov. 8.

title: Is Tracey for Real?
description: LETTERS FROM THE INSIDE By John Marsden. 146 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $13.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Tally in Feinstein-Huffington Senate Race Is Still a Week Away
description: The official tally in the hotly contested Senate race between Dianne Feinstein and Michael Huffington will take at least a week to finish as another 600,000 absentee ballots are counted, the California Secretary of State's Office said on Friday.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 Teaching history from the ground up, with photos of vermin and hogs, simulated smells, even a retired outhouse. NEW YORKERS & CO. 4 When Matthew Lee scans the South Bronx, he sees a host of budding businesses and few banks to help them. LETTERS 7 On sex shops and peep shows, Village politics, Times Square preachers. PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD 15 The Month of the Dead in Grand Central; Zimbabwean sculpture in Park Slope. GOOD EATING 18 Midtown east, in the lap of luxury: Lespinasse, the Four Seasons, Le Chantilly, La Cote Basque. SOAPBOX 19 When open-school week was open. Plus, Photographer's Journal and a cry of "Enough, already" in the East Village.

title:
STYLE;
Glamour Exhumed
description: As a plastic disk, it has no pretensions. On a tube top with 2,000 others like it, it's even quainter, more jejeune, just perfect shimmering on poly-silk palazzos for an evening at a) Studio 54 or b) the Burt Reynolds Dinner Theater in Jupiter, Fla. But wait! Sequins are chic again! Pass the smelling salts, please! They're on the cover of Vogue, and it says, right there, they're all about glamour, that new fashionable affliction.

title: A Tree Grows
description: Stay at a hotel and get a tree? Well, sort of. Through March 17, 1995, guests who book at the full rate at the Phoenix Park Hotel in Washington will have a tree planted in their name in the 1,752-acre Phoenix Park in Dublin. The new trees, which include ash, oak, lime, beech, sycamore and horse chestnut, are part of an effort to restore the park, home to deer and some 60 bird species. Dignitaries including George Bush and Pope John Paul II have already planted trees in the park. Guests will receive a certificate signed by the Lord Mayor of Dublin showing the site of their plantings. Rooms at the Phoenix Park Hotel, 520 North Capitol Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20001. (202) 630-6900, start at $169.

title: RICHARD FERBER
description: In the parents' support groups I lead, many parents are frustrated at the distance between themselves and their children as they grow older. Comforting and listening to an infant or toddler at night is one of the first steps to opening the lines of communication that parents will want to last a lifetime. SHARON C. PETERS Brooklyn

title: No Headline
description: "Why should people expect politics to be any different from the rest of culture? It's not as if politics is deteriorating but everybody's watching Shakespeare." BARNEY FRANK, Democratic Representative from Massachusetts, on the nature of campaigns. [ 20:6. ]

title: There's a Wall In the New Berlin; You Just Can't See It
description: THE Berlin wall came down on Nov. 9, 1989, for the same reason it went up on Aug. 13, 1961: to keep the people of East Germany from running away from Communism.

title: John A. Volpe, Nixon Supporter And Massachusetts Governor, 85
description: John Anthony Volpe, a former Governor of Massachusetts, Ambassador to Italy and United States Secretary of Transportation, died on Friday night. He was 85 and lived in Nahunt, Mass.

title: N.H.L. Players Consider International Tourney
description: Hoping for the best, but preparing for the worst, the National Hockey League Players Association is considering several major arenas across North America for an international tournament this winter if the labor lockout continues.

title: Denise R. Parietti, James L. Marketos
description: Denise Rose Parietti, an independent video producer in Washington, is to be married there today to James Lee Marketos, a partner in the Washington office of Lane & Mittendorf, a New York law firm. The Rev. John T. Tavlarides, the dean of St. Sophia Greek Orthodox Cathedral, is to perform the ceremony there.

title: Seminoles Win the Rematch That Wasn't
description: In a reverse of 1993's game of the year, the Seminoles used a running attack to defeat Notre Dame, 23-16, today before 72,868 at the Florida Citrus Bowl.

title: From Our 'Get a Life' Department
description: To the Editor:

title: It's 5, 4, 3, 2, Graham: Bring On the Cardinals!
description: Every Thursday until last week, Giants quarterback Dave Brown would meet the press. As a cast of seemingly hundreds crammed themselves in front of Brown's locker, Kent Graham sometimes could not help staring.

title: Beware the Kudzu Gang and All Its Kind
description: This is about outlaws. Not the gun-toting kind, but the kind with roots, leaves and stems. Invasive species, the professionals call them, and a rich field of study they offer.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Pondering Pandas
description: MR. CHAS AND LISA SUE MEET THE PANDASBy Fran Lebowitz.Illustrated by Michael Graves.60 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $15. (Ages 7 to 10)

title: Republicans Plan to Guide Foreign Policy by Purse String
description: In foreign policy, a domain traditionally run by the executive branch, Republican leaders in Congress say they plan to use the power of the purse to rein in President Clinton on several fronts, like cutting foreign aid or restricting funds for peacekeeping.

title: The Word From the Pope
description: AS LANGUAGE MAvens gathered at the New York Public Library recently to hear a panel discuss "Words in the Next Millennium," a crisis was building in the greenroom.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living In/Bellport;
Year-Round Village With a Summer Feel
description: JUTTING into Long Island's Great South Bay 65 miles from midtown Manhattan is the picturesque Village of Bellport with its own Fire Island beach, country club, parks, a summer stock theater and eclectic downtown shopping. Many residents call it "the Hamptons without the hassle."

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Giuliani administration's proposal for a new contract with the Legal Aid Society misstated a court procedure. Defendants who are not arraigned within 24 hours of their arrest are released to be arraigned later; their cases are not dismissed.

title: Vaulting Ambition
description: To the Editor:

title: Patricia Gozum, Celso Sanchez
description: Patricia Carmen Gozum, a daughter of Dr. Carmen Z. Gozum and Alfredo T. Gozum of Bethlehem, Pa., was married there yesterday to Celso William Sanchez, a son of Karen and Celso J. Sanchez of Highland Park, N.J. The Rev. Ronald Yarrosh performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church.

title: You're the Pops
description: ARTHUR FIEDLER Papa, the Pops and Me. By Johanna Fiedler. Illustrated. 268 pp. New York: Doubleday. $24.95.

title: Q and A
description: The S.S. United States

title: Begging for Crumbs
description: Be honest. Isn't stuffing a bird its raison d'etre? I've heard people say they wouldn't bother with the fat and mess of a goose, if it weren't for what a goose can hold. I've heard the same thing said about ducks, pheasants and capons. I've also wondered if modern poultry techniques would have survived given the sacrifices in flavor, if not for the larger, sturdier cavity that science has devised.

title:
Viewpoints;
To Fight Foreign Bribery, Try Charity
description: THE key to the growing problem of bribery in international business may be found in a surprising place: corporate philanthropy.

title:
The View From: Guilford;
At the Gibson Factory, Christmas Is a Wrap
description: IN a Guilford factory overlooking a sheep farm and sprawling pasture the business of Christmas is being played out. Machines roll, cut and box holiday products with a style and precision befitting any of Santa's workshops. But orders are slowing down, and as far as workers are concerned, this holiday is already a wrap.

title: Nets Miss The Point In Another Ugly Loss
description: No matter how often Coach Butch Beard berated and begged the Nets, no matter how many timeouts he called and no matter how many animated conversations the players had on the court and on the bench, nothing could make their shots fall tonight -- and nothing could prevent the Houston Rockets from trouncing them.

title: Moss's Lawyer Speaks of Deal
description: Wisconsin tailback BRENT MOSS might plead guilty to misdemeanor drug possession if prosecutors agree to recommend a lenient sentence, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Nov. 6-12; The News, Virtually
description: A newspaper strike that began Nov. 1 has not quite shut down The San Francisco Examiner and The San Francisco Chronicle. Within hours of the strike, both sides in the labor dispute had created electronic versions of their own newspapers on the the World Wide Web portion of the Internet.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
An Army of Child Laborers
description: KIDS AT WORKLewis Hine and the Crusade Against Child Labor.By Russell Freedman.Illustrated. 104 pp. New York: Clarion Books. $16.95.(Ages 9 and up)JACQUES-HENRI LARTIGUE Boy With a Camera.By John Cech.Illustrated. 32 pp. New York: Four Winds Press. $15.95. (Ages 6 to 9)

title: Clashing Styles or Bad Manners?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Relativity' Has Its World Premiere
description: "I DON'T even know why I'm here." That's Audrey's entrance line when she bursts into her brother Neil's tract house one snowy night. Now there's a nervy way to start up a play.

title: In America; A Simple Case of Fraud
description: The beauty of Ronald Reagan, Newt Gingrich and so many other Republicans is that they make it all sound so simple.

title:
THE $500 WEEKEND;
Ben Franklin's Favorite Town
description: ON the whole, my college roommate and I decided we'd rather be in Philadelphia. My roommate, Christina Fitzpatrick, is a Chicagoan transplanted to Phoenix; she longed to see autumn leaves falling and buildings that had been around before 1920. I have lived in Canada for 25 years, appreciating a country built to promote "peace, order and good government," as the British North America Act put it in 1867. But now I felt ready for a little life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness -- at the source. Or at least as much as could be had in an October weekend for $500.

title: At Work; A Fond Farewell to Big Government
description: THE message of the Democratic debacle last week, Washington pundits tell us, is that America dislikes Bill Clinton and hates liberalism and its evil twin, Big Government. This may be so. Certainly, inhabitants of the liberal sanctuaries accustomed to being out of step with the rest of the country are asking themselves how many times in one life they will have to ponder moving to Canada. For now they are just pulling raincoats tight around their "Great Society counter-cultural McGovern-ik" T-shirts and poring over David McCullough's "Truman," looking for nuggets that might help the First Boomer. President Clinton may be no liberal's idea of a liberal, but in the Damien-gone-respectable context of Newt Gingrich, even to the die-hards in Berkeley, Cambridge and New York, he must now look pretty good.

title: A Son's Notes
description: FATHERALONG A Meditation on Fathers and Sons, Race and Society. By John Edgar Wideman. 197 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $21.

title: On a Budget; Accessible Broadway: The Cheap Seats
description: Tickets to Broadway shows may cost more than $65 apiece these days, but reduced-price tickets for many shows are available at the two TKTS booths -- the main one in Duffy Square at 47th Street and Broadway, and the satellite booth at 2 World Trade Center.

title: Meeting Cuts
description: That like rarely takes to like is the implied message of Nancy Caldwell Sorel and Edward Sorel's entertaining FIRST ENCOUNTERS: A Book of Memorable Meetings (Knopf, $24). Chekhov and Tolstoy clearly didn't hit it off. Neither, despite appearances, did de Gaulle and Roosevelt, or Hitler and Mussolini -- not to mention Churchill and Stalin, or J. Edgar Hoover and Emma Goldman. These 63 "first encounters," which have appeared separately in The Atlantic Monthly over the past 12 years, prove how reliably fact can be stranger than fiction. Isak Dinesen and Marilyn Monroe got along fine. So did Houdini and Arthur Conan Doyle. Less compatible were the more celebrated pairings of Chopin and George Sand, Lotte Lenya and Kurt Weill, and Capt. John Smith and Pocahontas. But their stories, illustrated in color by Edward Sorel and retold spiritedly and concisely by Nancy Caldwell Sorel (they relate their own first meeting and subsequent marriage in an afterword), all benefit from a light touch. What is the book's most memorable meeting? Possibly the one between Fats Waller and Al Capone, who kidnapped the musician for a three-day party. Equally appealing, though it relies entirely on Welles's authority, is the story of the encounter between William Randolph Hearst and Orson Welles in an elevator in the Fairmont Hotel the day of the San Francisco premiere of "Citizen Kane." Welles introduced himself and invited Hearst to attend, but was met with stony silence. As Hearst got off at his floor, Welles called after him: "Charles Foster Kane would have accepted." DAVID WALTON

title:
HOME CLINIC;
A Fine Wood Floor Is Worthy of Good Care
description: A wood floor is a thing of beauty. But wood floors take abuse and require proper care to keep them looking good.

title:
SOAPBOX;
The Bullies of the East Village
description: ON the evening of Sept. 29, I was present when about 100 squatters and their self-proclaimed "anarchist" supporters once again disrupted a meeting of Community Board 3 in the East Village. In full costume -- their bodies pierced and tattooed -- and armed with garbage-can drums, they rushed up and down the aisles, chanted, whistled, threw stink bombs, threatened those running the meeting, taunted the police and shouted down anyone who disagreed with them. Their behavior was in keeping with their history as the bullies of the East Village.

title:
HOME CLINIC;
A Fine Wood Floor Is Worthy of Good Care
description: A wood floor is a thing of beauty. But wood floors take abuse and require proper care to keep them looking good.

title: Commuter Parking Lots Overflowing
description: WHEN Arthur M. Katz of Jericho had an 8 A.M. appointment in Manhattan recently he left his house shortly after 6, drove through the Queens-Midtown Tunnel and parked at a lot in midtown. It cost him $6 for tolls and $14 for two hours of parking.

title: Myra Y. Goldfarb, Eric Boe Outwater
description: Myra Yellin Goldfarb, a freelance writer, was married yesterday in Santa Fe, N.M., to Eric Boe Outwater, the president of Lead Inspection Services, a home inspection company in Winsted, Conn. Judge Thomas A. Donnelly of the New Mexico Court of Appeals performed the ceremony at the home of Nancy Cole, a friend of the bride.

title: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: Cuomo, a Mystery in an Enigma in a Politician, and His Final Race; Friends Look for an Answer
description: After all the years in which the riddle about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was why he didn't (run for President, take a Supreme Court nomination), the question that lingers after his defeat is why he did (run for a fourth term that it was clear he would have a hard time winning).

title: Albany Seeks Managed Care for Mentally Ill On Medicaid
description: In an effort to provide better, more reliable community-based care for people with psychiatric disorders, New York State says it will seek to create a managed-care network for 35,000 of the state's most seriously mentally ill who are covered by Medicaid.

title: Income and Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MUSIC KNOWING WHEN TO STOP A Memoir. By Ned Rorem. Simon & Schuster, $30.

title: A.T.M. Shock
description: To the Editor: Something new in automated teller machines: In Vienna I came upon an A.T.M. that exchanged one currency for another. I inserted a United States $5 bill and the receipt showed that was worth 57 Austrian schillings -- not bad. However the machine kept 23 schillings commission, leaving me 34. I was glad I didn't exchange a larger bill. ALLAN E. BROWN Maplewood, N.J.

title: For Warhol, 15 More Minutes
description: The Baltimore Museum of Art has opened its New Wing for Modern Art with an exhibition of 15 newly acquired paintings by Andy Warhol in the Caplan Family Gallery, which has a total of 42 Warhol works. This acquisition, announced last May, makes the museum home to the second-largest collection of Warhol paintings on regular public display, after the Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh.

title: Four Decades Later, an Atypical Artist Nears a Retrospective
description: THE paintings and sculpture at Stamford Center for the Arts are, by his own admission, the closest Robert Goodnough has come to a retrospective. For an artist who has been on the Manhattan scene since 1950, this is remarkable enough; but for one who has shown in galleries as prestigious as Tibor de Nagy and Andre Emmerich, not to mention the Albright-Knox, in Buffalo, it is downright mysterious.

title: State to Defend Dismissed Troopers in Lawsuit
description: David Harding and Robert Lishansky were dismissed by the New York State Police after they admitted fabricating evidence in more than two dozen criminal cases. Both are now in prison.

title: SUNDAY, November 13. 1994; It's God, Gas and Go At Virginia Church
description: It's a place of worship. It's a gas station. It's Arlington Temple United Methodist Church. Newcomers to Rosslyn, Va., a suburb of Washington, often gawk at the odd structure. But locals breezily refer to it as "Our Lady of Exxon."

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Times Magazine last Sunday, with an article about Russian fashion, misidentified a designer. The picture showed Nona Melikova -- not Tatyana Parfyonova, who is St. Petersburg's leading designer.

title: Private Club For Everyone
description: FORGET the noisy, 90's cappuccino bars. In Boston, on a cold night, the place to get warm is the Ritz Bar, where perfect martinis are poured at your table by waiters in tuxedos, as they have been since 1933.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Hong, Chen And the Pirates
description: THE EXAMINATIONBy Malcolm Bosse.296 pp. New York:Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17. (Age 10 and up)

title: BENNINGTON MEANS BUSINESS
description: Though Elizabeth Coleman seems to feel that Bennington had been plunged into some sort of intellectual dark age before it was graced with her arrival, it was an electric and magical place during my years there ("Bennington Means Business," by Mark Edmundson, Oct. 23).

title: An Epidemic Of Youth In Middle Age
description: LIKE a pugilistic Norma Desmond, George Foreman eased on a pair of old velvet trunks last week and headed for the prize ring, a bald and flabby trouper of a certain age out to avenge the darkest night of his youth. In some fleeting way, Mr. Foreman also set out to strike a blow for the relaxed-jeans generation, the baby boomers who are now hoping that with modern medicine and some latter-day Ponce de Leon in their corner, they will stay forever vital and young, defying gravity and the years.

title: Penn State, 21 Down, Saves Its Season in Last 0:57
description: There was more than roses at stake.

title: Farmland Preservation Splits Suffolk
description: AN east-west split in Suffolk County pitting lawmakers from the heavily developed west against those from the partly rural eastern towns is endangering farmland preservation, a farm official said last week.

title: Anticrime Tactic: Shut Footbridge
description: The 103d Street footbridge, the only direct pedestrian access from Manhattan to Wards Island, will be closed in mid-December as an experiment in crime prevention, officials from the police, the Parks and Recreation Department and the Department of Transportation say.

title: The Civil War Draws a Crowd
description: WHEN the director of the Watertown Parks and Recreation Department was approached six years ago about offering a series of lectures on the Civil War, he had no idea whether the concept would fly or flop. In fact, Donald Stepanek was unaware the man before him was a self-taught historian with a consuming interest in the era. But Mr. Stepanek knew Al Gambone, a Woodbury resident, from community service activities and decided to give him, and the lecture series, a chance.

title: Did Racial Redistricting Undermine Democrats
description: As politicians and academics analyze the forces that created this year's Republican tidal wave, another factor is taking its place alongside voter anger and President Clinton's unpopularity: the creation of majority black Congressional districts.

title: Unhand Me, You Cad!
description: AT THIS POINT, there is only one good thing to say about Capt. James Hewitt, the cavalry officer who wooed Princess Diana and blabbed to the world. With one audacious stroke, he has brought back the cad.

title: The World, as Planet and Neighborhood, at the Bruce Museum
description: WARM memories of the old Bruce Museum linger -- the taxidermic bear, drawers filled with starfish, shells, squid, animal and fish games, and a marine touch tank. Now, completing the last lap of a two-year expansion and renovation program, the Bruce Museum's environmental history galleries have finally opened.

title: Would You Swap Bodies With A Baby
description: THE DAYDREAMER By Ian McEwan. Illustrated by Anthony Browne. 192 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $14. (Ages 10 and up)

title: South Africa's Drakensberg
description: ON a slow Saturday in August my wife, Ann Cooper, and I drove south from Johannesburg, with a cassette of Brad Pitt reading Cormac McCarthy's elegiac cowboy novel "All the Pretty Horses," in the tape player and an easy, elusive feeling in our hearts. It took a while to pin the feeling down: it was normalcy.

title: UNNATURAL SELECTION
description: Among the many issues raised by the practice of cloning is the question of who or what will be cloned. To whom will the gatekeepers of life-after-life grant the privilege of immortality? Geneti-Pet, a company in Port Townsend, Wash., is not a cloning service. For $75 plus a $100-a-year storage fee, it will, however, store a vial of your pet's blood in liquid nitrogen so that when replication becomes widely available -- the assumption here is that this will happen during the course of a pet owner's lifetime -- you will have the means to wrest from your adorable little Puffles an eerie Puffles 2.

title: For Another Sort of Deadhead
description: IF a little white skull arrives with your name clearly written across the front of it, there's no need to worry. The skull is made of sugar; it's just a holiday gift.

title: Jennifer Marcus, Brent Barbara
description: Jennifer Rebecca Marcus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Buzz Marcus of Boca Raton, Fla., and Brent Scott Barbara, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Barbara of New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Richard Agler performed the ceremony at the Ritz Carlton in Palm Beach, Fla..

title:
Your Own Account;
A Squabble Over Rating Insurers
description: A recent report by the General Accounting Office turns the spotlight once more on the ratings of life and health insurance companies. But the report's shortcomings are drawing as much attention as its findings.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Double Dragon Robert Patrick, Mark Dacascos, Scott Wolf Directed by James Yukich PG-13 99 minutes

title: And Will This Be The Ultimate in Tours?
description: A HELICOPTER NOSE-DIVES toward Wall Street, shoots beneath a truck and soars back into the air. This is New York 90's-style via New York Skyride, which is scheduled to open in December in the Empire State Building.

title: In Green Bay, Jets' Toughest Foe Is One They Can't Tackle
description: The Jets brushed up on their Green Bay history this week -- the men from the biggest market in the N.F.L. learning something about the smallest.

title: INSIDE
description: Harder Line on Russia?

title: Brothers Under the Skin
description: To the Editor:

title: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'
description: To the Editor:

title: New Greenburgh Law On Carbon Monoxide
description: AS part of a restructuring of an already rigorous building code, the town of Greenburgh recently adopted a provision to require that new buildings, both commercial and residential, install carbon-monoxide detectors. This measure was prompted in part by the recent death of the tennis star Vitas Gerulaitis and, closer to home, the death last year of a Hartsdale resident .

title: World News Briefs; Chinese Journalist Is Reportedly Convicted
description: After failing for lack of evidence to convict a prominent Chinese journalist last April, Beijing's branch of the People's Intermediate Court has tried again and succeeded, family members and rights groups said today.

title: Meacham Paid Dues On Way to New Job
description: Bobby Meacham saw Ken Griffey Sr. several times this past season, and he wasn't sure if that was a good thing or not.

title: Trouble in Paradise, 2 Wide Views; How the Belnord Battle Took Shape Along Classical Lines
description: In 1975, Thomas Bitullo-Martin attained many a New Yorker's fantasy: an eight-room, rent-stabilized apartment in the Belnord, the landmark Upper West Side apartment house. His joy at the find lasted three years, until his refrigerator and freezer broke down, touching off 16 years of warfare with his landlady, Lillian Seril.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Bring Me a Dream
description: SHIP OF DREAMSWritten and illustrated by Dean Morrissey.Unpaged. New York: Mill Pond Press/Harry N. Abrams. $17.95. (All ages)RED RANGER CAME CALLING A Guaranteed True Christmas Story.Written and illustrated by Berkeley Breathed.Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95. (All ages)

title: Excellence Wasted?
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: C.H.S.F.L. OPPOSITES ATTRACT: CHAMINADE and ST. ANTHONY'S advanced to the Catholic High School Football League's AAA Finals with playoff victories yesterday at St. John's University. Although both teams looked impressive, they won in completely different fashions.

title: Palestinians Arrest 100 Islamic Militants After Bicycle Bombing
description: Raiding scores of houses and a mosque, the Palestinian police arrested more than 100 Islamic militants today in a crackdown ordered after a suicide bomber killed three Israeli soldiers at a checkpoint near this Jewish settlement.

title: Ramsey Murray, Pen Alexander
description: Sarah Ramsey Murray, a cartographer at the National Geographic Society in Washington, was married yesterday to Dr. Edmund Pendelton Alexander, the chief of cardiothoracic surgery at the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Washington. The Rev. Dr. John R. Price performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Annapolis, Md.

title: NOV. 6-12: A Better Harvest; The Number of U.S. Farms Falls Below 2 Million
description: From Thomas Jefferson to Grant Wood, Americans have thought of their farmers as something special: stolid, valuable, virtuous. Now they are so few. Last week the Census Bureau announced that the number of American farms had dipped below 2 million for the first time since 1850, when Millard Fillmore was President. The shrinkage has been a long-term trend caused mainly by more efficient production and the economic contretemps of the early to mid-1980's that forced many farmers into bankruptcy.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Power Rangers of Yore
description: SWAMP ANGELBy Anne Isaacs.Illustrated by Paul O. Zelinsky.Unpaged. New York: Dutton Children's Books. $14.99. (Ages 5 and up)JOHN HENRY By Julius Lester.Illustrated by Jerry Pinkney. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books. $16.99. (All ages)

title: Miss Talieh, Mr. Woodville
description: Faeze Talieh, a daughter of Mehrmah Talieh of St. Davids, Pa., and Manouchehr Talieh of King of Prussia, Pa., was married yesterday to Richard Warren Woodville, the son of Mrs. Jefferson Burrus Jr. of Washington and the late Capt. J. L. Warren Woodville Jr. The Rev. Douglas G. Scott performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Martin's Church in Radnor, Pa. Earlier in the day, a Persian Shiite ceremony was performed by Ziaddin Mirmirani, an uncle of the bride, at Bolingbroke, the parish house of St. Martin's.

title: Shopping Center Threatens An Avenue Worth Saving
description: To the Editor:

title: The Knicks Finally Fall, With a Thud
description: The Knicks' first loss of the season was a decisive one. They never threatened in the fourth quarter. They were thoroughly outplayed by the San Antonio Spurs. And for the Knicks, it was an ominous beginning to a challenging four-game trip.

title: A Gal and Two Guys
description: AT the beginning of "Fighting Over Beverley," one would think that Israel Horovitz were concocting a fairy tale for elderly lovers, but don't be fooled. At 69, Archie Bennett has traveled from England to Gloucester, Mass., for the hand of Beverley Shimma who ditched him 49 years ago to run off with Zelly Shimma, a decorated World War II officer.

title: Settling Matters in Oklahoma
description: According to a published report, university officials are trying to negotiate a settlement with Oklahoma Coach GARY GIBBS so he will resign before the new school president, DAVID BOREN, takes office on Thursday.

title:
THEATER;
An Actor Leaps the Chasm And Reaches the Director Side
description: THE DIRECTOR-ACTOR Walter Bobbie, looking something like a middle-aged Howdy Doody, can't stop grinning during rehearsals of Christopher Durang's "For Whom the Southern Belle Tolls," a parody of Tennessee Williams's "Glass Menagerie." In Mr. Durang's spoof, Laura has become Lawrence, and her beloved collection of figurines are now swizzle sticks. Mr. Bobbie stops laughing periodically to give notes. Instead of talking from his authoritative position behind a table, he walks right up to the actors to offer corrections, sotto voce. His manner is patient and encouraging. Perhaps it should be: he has earned his living as an actor for the last 24 years, mostly in the musical theater, and knows about actors' insecurities.

title: Chill Out! The New Hot Sport Is on Ice and Kerrigan Is the Biggest Star
description: Ice Wars ended tonight. In truth, the ice wars are just beginning.

title: Two Women Who Break A Tradition
description: Samuel Phillips founded a boarding school for boys here in 1778. Three years later, his uncle, Dr. John Phillips, founded one in Exeter, N.H., on the other side of the border. In the 200 years since, the two academies bearing the Phillips name have enjoyed a friendly rivalry that has endured, becoming a beloved tradition.

title: Team-First Concept Makes Packer Defense Even More Starry
description: There's a very simple philosophy behind the Packers' defense, which has been hammering opponents into submission for much of the year.

title: Heartwarming Fare for the Fall Table
description: BRAISED rabbit, pappardelle in a wild boar sauce and venison chops with a red-currant glaze signal fall as much as turning leaves and ripening gourds. This heartwarming seasonal fare stands out on the autumn menu at Pentimento.

title: Whitman's Popularity Helped Lautenberg
description: THE "time for a change" wave that swept Republicans into office across the country last Tuesday fell flat when it reached the United States Senate race in New Jersey. And paradoxically, the popularity of the Republican Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, may have been part of the reason.

title: Atlantic Center Loses Bradlees, Officials Say
description: Bradlees, the discount chain store that was meant to be the cornerstone of the 24-acre Atlantic Center development project in Fort Greene, will no longer be involved, said a Brooklyn business association official and others close to the project.

title: More Than One Way to See Art
description: FOR MUCH OF THIS CENTURY, there has been one way of looking at contemporary art, and that is the way the Museum of Modern Art does it -- on right-angled white walls in evenly lighted, shadowless spaces within a highly controlled sequence of rooms. Painters have long supported the neutrality that the Modern represents: in the 1950's a score of prominent artists complained to the Guggenheim Museum that the sloping walls and curved ramps of Frank Lloyd Wright's spinning rotunda would fail to provide "the rectilinear frame of reference necessary for the adequate visual contemplation of works of art." Wright's design, which is indeed inhospitable to some kinds of art but glorious for others, continues to fuel the deep suspicion many artists harbor toward architects.

title: Building, No League, for Budig
description: GENE BUDIG, who became American League president 11 days before the players went on strike, hasn't had much opportunity to make his mark on baseball, but he is still remembered and will continue to be remembered at the University of Kansas.

title: On Sunday; An Actress Who Belongs To the Risk
description: "WHY does the actor not look out of the window first thing in the morning?" asks Rosaleen Linehan, setting up an old joke told by actors about their frequent states of unemployment. "Because he'd have nothing to do for the rest of the day," she responds, her laughter bell-like across the idleness that's pretty much in the past for her now that she's a world-class actress.

title: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Tyson, Olajuwon Connection
description: AS sports' new odd couple, it's as if they're living in different apartments but with the same landLord: Hakeem Olajuwon, the towering basketball player, and Mike Tyson, the jailed boxer.

title: Dad Grabs the Reins but, Wait, There's a Hitch
description: The Santa Clause Eric Lloyd, Tim Allen Directed by John Pasquin PG 95 minutes

title: LET 'EM HAVE NUKES
description: America's nonproliferation policy used to be pretty straightforward: Washington simply said "No" and the country -- South Korea in the 1970's, for instance -- abandoned its nuclear ambitions. But that time is long past. It took the Persian Gulf war to stop Iraq's bomb program. While things now seem to be looking up in North Korea, it wasn't that long ago that President Clinton threatened military action if things could not be worked out peacefully. "We will not allow the North Koreans to develop a nuclear bomb," he said late last year. If it came to a conflict, he explained, he was confident that "we could do what we need to do."

title: JERSEYANA
description: IT was one year ago that Ed Rollins, the manager of the Republican gubernatorial campaign in New Jersey, boastfully announced at a breakfast meeting of reporters that his side had won by bribing black ministers and precinct workers in the cities to keep down the vote for the Democrats. Mr. Rollins quickly retracted the story and an investigation turned up no evidence that it had ever happened.

title: Many Rivers to Cross
description: THE GLORY FIELD By Walter Dean Myers. 375 pp. New York: Scholastic. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Rhodes
description: To the Editor: I just finished reading "Rhodes Sojourn With Plenty of Company" by Susan Spano (Oct. 9), and I would like to add a few things. Yes, Rhodes is expensive, compared with other parts of Greece, but it is still relatively inexpensive compared with other European destinations.

title: Britain Is Changing Its Dialing Codes
description: Britain will officially switch to new telephone codes starting next April 16, although the new ones are already in use with the old ones.

title:
Mutual Funds;
The Risks of Chasing Market Shifts
description: WHILE new money continues to pour into stock mutual funds, many investors have moved in and out of equity funds this year, trying to time the market as common stocks have see-sawed. But these participants have often run headlong the wrong way, rushing in on rallies and retreating during corrections.

title: DUMBING DOWN
description: The bell curve is certainly a slippery slope these days. Robin Marantz Henig's Hers column ("Dumbing Down," Oct. 23) illustrates, in a variety of ways, the kind of black-and-white thinking that passes for discourse on education. While it is possible for schools to hold back quicker learners through poorly planned heterogeneous grouping, it is equally possible to create narrowly focused students by accelerating their achievement in homogeneous groups.

title:
The Executive Life;
Women Fight to Get A Foot on the Green
description: WHEN Eileen Scudder, a partner with the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche in Chicago, was invited to a country club to speak at a client's board meeting and then play golf one Wednesday a few years ago, she quickly declined. What she knew, but the client didn't, was that the club barred women from the course that day of the week -- a holdover from when men received preferential treatment because they had jobs and women didn't.

title: BENNINGTON MEANS BUSINESS
description: As the mother of a first-year student at Bennington, I, too, worry that the college is losing old friends. But I balance this concern with an appreciation of what is new. Not that I underestimate the importance of tenure and issues of fairness, but as a parent, I am not displeased that poetry is taught by the poetry editor of a famous literary magazine. Nor, I confess, would I be horrified if, someday, that teacher had to move over for another -- my son, my daughter? Does that sound callous? Perhaps not to those of us who accept that job security depends on the ability to offer current, marketable skills. CONSTANCE BAILEY New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Analyzing Cuomo
description: "I think a lot of people spend a lot of time analyzing Mario Cuomo, contemplating his moves, and I think a lot of that cottage industry is unnecessary. He's far more simple than people think he is." GARY G. FRYER, a former Cuomo press secretary

title: Ruth and Loyal: A New York Love Story
description: IT is nearly noon, an unseasonably warm Friday, and all down Columbus Avenue people are dawdling in cafes and strolling the street.

title: 'What Sort of Dictatorship Is This?'
description: LENIN A New Biography. By Dmitri Volkogonov. Edited and translated by Harold Shukman. Illustrated. 529 pp. New York: The Free Press. $30.

title: Midtown East: The Lap of Luxury
description: DAWAT ** (212) 355-7555; 210 East 58th Street; $$; all major credit cards

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Huber, Pierce in Final Anke Huber and Mary Pierce posted impressive victories yesterday to reach the final of the $750,000 Virginia Slims of Philadelphia. Huber shook off a disappointing first set before beating Gabriela Sabatini, 6-7 (11-13), 6-1, 6-4, while Pierce defeated fifth-seeded Natalia Zvereva, 6-3, 6-3. Huber won the first three games of the second set and took advantage of a tired Sabatini in the third. (AP)

title: PRO FOOTBALL: TV Sports; Want to See Cowboys And 49ers? Start the Car.
description: Today, we are a city in tears. We shall not see the Dallas-San Francisco game on broadcast television. At 1 P.M., New York-area viewers will watch the Arizona-Giants game on Fox (Channel 5), followed at 4 by the Jets-Green Bay game on NBC (Channel 4). The Super Bowl, at least of Week 11, will only be a highlight special. 'Tis the shame of America. The pity of football.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER WEST SIDE Pianist, 13, to Play Bach With New American Group

title:
Morristown Journal;
Turning a Former Theater Into a Cultural Center
description: THE Community Theater of Morristown is being saved by its namesake -- the community.

title: Jennifer E. Green, Clifford Seltzer
description: Jennifer Ellen Green, a daughter of Peter and Susan Green of Harrison, N.Y., and Clifford Seltzer, a son of Stephen and Sandy Seltzer of Roslyn Heights, L.I., are to be married today. Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights.

title: 13 Musicians From County Appearing at Kennedy Center
description: THIRTEEN music students ranging in age from 8 to 17 will be on their way to Washington this week to take part in a national arts festival at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The group, selected in a nationwide competition sponsored by the National Guild of Community Schools of the Arts, includes eight youngsters from the Westchester Conservatory of Music in White Plains and five from the Hoff-Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale.

title: Nov. 6-12; At a Snail's Pace
description: North Korea sent ripples of anxiety through Asia last Wednesday when Pyongyang radio reported that an important announcement was imminent. With rumors flying of grave political developments, the Government made its disclosure: the leadership had ordered the construction of a new bridge and tunnel in Pyongyang.

title: SUNDAY, November 13. 1994; Bug Bijoux
description: Charlie Hines has designed a jewelry line that Morticia would love. It features dead insects encased in beads of acrylic resin. "When I was a kid in the late 1970's, I began wondering how they suspended insects in paperweights," says Hines, the creator of Bedebug. "Twenty years later, I figured it out."

title: Wendy L. Cohen, Jonathan Gottlieb
description: Wendy Lynn Cohen, the controller of Zeckendorf Realty in New York, is to be married today to Jonathan Adam Gottlieb, a lawyer in the enforcement division of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission in New York. Rabbi Stephen Kane is to officiate at Congregation B'nai Tikvah in North Brunswick, N.J.

title: DUMBING DOWN
description: If Henig is opposed to the concept of heterogeneous grouping, I wonder what she would think of the newest New York City Board of Education concept of "bridge classes." A bridge is a class with two grades heterogeneously grouped! In the fifth-and-sixth-grade bridge class I teach, I have 30 students whose reading scores range from the 90th to the 3d percentile, and whose abilities span at least five grade levels. This situation exists in classrooms throughout the city. Can you think of any student who would benefit from being in a class like mine, no matter how hard I try every day? GERALDINE FELDMAN Merrick, L.I.

title: Fresh Brewed Art Nouveau
description: A FEW minutes' walk from Warsaw's Old Town, and next door to the President's palace, the Cafe Bristol is a handy and inviting place to warm up after some fall or winter sightseeing. Opened in 1901, the historic Hotel Bristol, which houses the cafe, was built by a construction company partly owned by the composer Ignace Jan Paderewski, and decorated in the Viennese Art Nouveau style by the Austrian designer Otto Wagner. In 1981, after several decades of decline, the hotel closed; hotel and cafe officially reopened last year, renovated and refurbished in the original style.

title: Vietnam: Behind a Red-Tape Curtain
description: THE big day had finally arrived. The hotel had set out its finest china and crystal. There were starched linen napkins around a centerpiece of tiny American and Vietnamese flags.

title: San Antonio
description: It is almost always fiesta time in San Antonio, America's 10th-largest city and, by some reckonings, the place where Latin America begins. But there may be no better time of year to visit than this season, when there is much joyful anticipation of the holidays in the air.

title: MOMENTUM BUILDS FOR CUTTING BACK WELFARE SYSTEM
description: After a campaign in which voters rewarded a barrage of anti-welfare attacks, both parties are now calling the issue a top priority, and both are repeating stern promises to make recipients work.

title:
FILM;
From New Zealand, Heavenly Murderous Creatures
description: ON JUNE 24, 1954, IN THE NEW Zealand city of Christchurch, two girls were charged with murder. The two, Pauline Yvonne Parker, 16, and Juliet Marion Hulme, 15, were arrested and charged with killing Pauline's mother, Honora Mary Parker, age 45. The bizarre story of how the girls became friends and decided to kill the woman (who was trying to separate them) is told in the film "Heavenly Creatures," directed by Peter Jackson. The movie, which earlier this year won prizes at the Venice and Toronto film festivals, opens on Wednesday.

title: Dozing on the Shoulders Can Be Deadly
description: Just before 1 A.M. on a recent morning, 14 big trailer trucks were parked -- all illegally -- on the shoulders of Interstate 78 here. Eight were pointed westbound, toward Pennsylvania, and six eastbound, toward Newark and New York City, and all 14 were potentially lethal hazards for cars and other trucks whizzing by.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: The Latest KFC in the Bronx Is Part of a Citywide Push

title: Hey, Syracuse Did Make It to the 47 Once
description: For what it's worth, Boston College trounced Syracuse today with more conviction and more points than Miami did a week ago in the Carrier Dome. Today's Eagle victory was 31-0 and last Saturday's Hurricane spanking of the Orange was 26-7.

title: RICHARD FERBER
description: Refusing to cuddle a tired, crying baby in the early months and years of life is like withholding sustenance. For babies, night is often a frightening time of enforced separation from parents. I fear that "Ferberized" babies have not been taught so much to put themselves to sleep as to give up all hope of comforting when they most need it. NANCY STIEFEL New York

title: Taking Life, Twice
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Factors In Area's Lead In Fire Deaths
description: Here, more than anywhere else in New York City, people die in fires.

title: Samaritan Van Halts Good Deeds
description: THE Texaco Good Samaritan Van, which had been aiding stranded motorists on county roads since 1988, ceased operation early this month because of the lack of a sponsor. But supporters are signing petitions in hopes that the Governor's office will assist in finding a new sponsor.

title: Sun Becomes Shine
description: NIGHT BECOMES DAY Written and illustrated by Richard McGuire. Unpaged. New York: Viking. $13.99. (All ages)

title: Around Town The Scenes Had Possibilities
description: SOME OF THE QUESTIONS likely to be asked when it's learned that you're a theater reviewer: "How many plays do you see a week?" That depends. "Do you ever walk out before the end?" Not unless the actors do. "How do you feel about standing ovations?" Skeptical. "Do you like your job?" Yes. "Is it fun?" That's not the right question.

title: Wall Street; Election News Dims Power Company's Stock
description: FOR the Long Island Lighting Company, the Cuomo rally has turned into the Pataki crash. Shares of Lilco fell 7 percent to $16.375 on Wednesday, as investors bailed out on news that Mario Cuomo had lost the election for Governor of New York. By Friday, Lilco shares closed at $16.

title: Habitats/Renovating a Classic; Cutting a Few Corners to Keep Costs From Soaring
description: THE architects riffled through their 2-inch stack of glossy photographs searching for the right "before" shots to illustrate their points about renovating the 1,500-square-foot apartment for less than $75,000, including the architects' fee.

title: Ethics Panel Opens Inquiry Into Activities Of Gingrich
description: In an eight-page letter, the House Ethics Committee has asked Representative Newt Gingrich, the Georgia Republican expected to be the next Speaker of the House, to explain the connections between a Republican political action committee he runs and a college course he taught.

title: Pro-Life Preacher Denies Charge of Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract. MANHATTAN GREENWICH VILLAGE $375,000 139 West 13th Street 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,312-sq.-ft. co-op in a brick town house; dining area, den, fireplace, roof deck; maintenance $704, 71% tax deductible, listed at $399,000, 4 1/2 years on market (Broker: Douglas Elliman; Nannette Smith-Gordon/IBC)

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BRONX PARK EAST -- The Way They Were: Old Comrades (Re)unite; 'Coopniks' Toast Bronx Memories
description: Once upon a time, from the 1920's to 1940's, there flourished a proletarian utopia called the Allerton Coops in the East Bronx.

title: The County's Lure: More for the Money
description: WHAT induces companies to move from New York City to Westchester? Is it because of the city's problems? Tax reasons? Or is it simply because a company's chief executive lives in Westchester? Perhaps it is a quality-of-life decision.

title: Hello, Hon, Can You Guess Where I Am?
description: ONCE the toys of executives, celebrities and entrepreneurs cellular phones are turning up all over the Island, to the joy of the users and to the distress of eavesdroppers.

title: EDITORS NOTE
description: EDITORS' NOTE: An article on Aug. 14 about young gang members included photographs of Tamika Young and her friend Cee-lo Perez with recently acquired tattoos. The Times has now learned that the tattoos were paid for by the photographer, a freelancer. The subjects were about to get the tattoos on their own, but the gift created an unintended appearance of staged news photography, which would have violated The Times's policy.

title: Miss McMullan and Mr. Del Priore
description: K. Mavourneen McMullan, a daughter of Rose Mary McMullan of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Robert J. McMullan, was married yesterday to Charles J. Del Priore Jr., the son of Valerie and Charles J. Del Priore of New Rochelle, N.Y. Msgr. Vincent W. Jeffers performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Church in Greenwich.

title: Warnings on Lead-Based Paint to Be Required in House Sales
description: SUBURBAN residents often brush off lead poisoning of children as an inner-city problem. But the director of the Long Island Lead Center and medical director of the Long Island Regional Poison Control Center in Mineola, Dr. Howard Mofenson, says the story is more complex.

title:
HOME CLINIC;
A Fine Wood Floor Is Worthy of Good Care
description: A wood floor is a thing of beauty. But wood floors take abuse and require proper care to keep them looking good.

title: The New History: Showing Children the Dark Side
description: NOT so long ago, the Americans who made the history I read all appeared to be old men, dressed in dull clothing and devoted to principles so high I could perceive them only dimly. They seemed to have lived far away in that adult world where you were not to say anything at all if it was not to be something nice.

title: Liftoff
description: THEY CALL IT AN information highway, but that's like calling a live person a skeleton. That overused road metaphor may help to explain the invisible technology of the Internet -- how electronic messages are driven from George's home computer along a network of local streets to a web of networks, the Interstate, and back onto local streets to Mary's computer in Moscow (Idaho, Russia or both).

title:
ART;
Life's Riddles and the Clarity of Cameras
description: "The Riddle of the Sphinx"

title: RICHARD FERBER
description: My son was successfully "Ferberized" 10 years ago. Recently, my daughter, Carly, 11 months, began to wake and cry at night. Our pediatrician said that Carly, too, needed to be Ferberized. The technique works just as well now as it did then. SUSAN NOVAK SMITH Fairfield, Conn.

title: Newt Gingrich, Authoritarian
description: Newt Gingrich is going to talk for a while now, and thoughtful citizens will be well advised to listen. As long as he is in the throes of post-election gloating, Mr. Gingrich cannot avoid providing useful glimpses of the personality and policies with which he modestly proposes to reshape America.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-14 CYCLES OF MISERY FOR BOSNIANS Bosnian Muslims who supported a defeated separatist leader fled to a camp in Croatia, where they now live on a converted farm under conditions of desperate poverty. 1 CLINTON VISITS PHILIPPINES President Clinton began his trip to the Pacific economic meeting with talks in the Philippines to reconfirm the country's economic and security ties with the United States. 10

title: SUNDAY, November 13. 1994; Trysts in Doubt
description: When the University of Chicago survey of sexual practices came out, one conventional idea was confirmed: men have more sexual partners in a lifetime than women do. Few news reports zeroed in on another aspect of the survey: the numbers didn't add up.

title: From Sydney To Melbourne, Unhurriedly
description: A COUPLE of hours south of Sydney, en route to Melbourne, the Princes Highway breaks out of banality. Winding up through pines and pasture, the road suddenly sweeps around a corner and swoops down to a beach, parallel to the Pacific's crashing surf. Offering tantalizing glimpses of the wild, weathered Australian coast and vast stretches of sand, the predominantly two-lane highway also travels through quiet villages on serene, azure waters where fishing fleets come and go. It's not unusual to see a sign advertising, "Local oysters, $10 for three dozen."

title: Liann Schottenstein, Paul Walborsky
description: Liann Fay Schottenstein, the daughter of I. Morris Schottenstein of Columbus, Ohio, and Rosalyn Kirkel of Denver, is to be married today to Paul Walborsky Navarro, the son of Hy and Aura Walborsky of Miami. Rabbi Aaron M. Petuchowski is to perform the ceremony at Capsouto Freres, a restaurant in New York.

title: Streetscapes/Harperly Hall; Restoring an Arts and Crafts Co-op Masterpiece
description: THERE are two ways to restore a building: Establish a big budget and spend it all at once, or undertake separate projects a little at a time over years, even decades. The co-op shareholders at Harperly Hall, a 1911 Arts and Crafts masterpiece at 64th Street and Central Park West, have chosen the second path, and the history of their 11-year effort demonstrates the patience -- and money -- that a complicated building can require.

title: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'
description: To the Editor:

title: BENNINGTON MEANS BUSINESS
description: Two observations, with respect to Edmundson's article: It is ironic that, in its fiscal make-over, Bennington solicited input from students and professors but made its restructuring decisions by the fiat of its president, Elizabeth Coleman. Perhaps the moral is, don't ask unless you are prepared to listen.

title: Class of '95: What's New, Improved or Laid to Rest
description: The average car on America's street is getting somewhat long in the tooth - from an average of 5.6 years in 1968, for example, to 8.1 years in 1992. This graying of the consumer demand, and both dealers and manufacturers expect 1995 new-vehicle sales to outpace the record levels of 1994. Straining to meet the demand, auto makers are pushing their manufacturing capacity to the limit.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FIRST NOVEL A STONE BOAT By Andrew Solomon. Faber & Faber, $22.95.

title: Catterson Fights Accusations
description: ALLEGATIONS that the Suffolk District Attorney, James M. Catterson Jr. threatend grand jury investigations against four county officials intensified last week into a governmental crisis that has put Mr. Catterson's future in doubt.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HOLLAR'S ETCHINGS

title: Churches Lead Dual Lives With Separate Congregations
description: EVERY Sunday morning at 10 o'clock, members of the Closter Congregational Church gather for their weekly worship service. Finding a choice pew is easy. With the entire congregation of 40 people in attendance, there's plenty of room in the 110-seat sanctuary.

title: POP BRIEFS
description: Wallace Roney: 'Misterios' Warner Brothers 9 45641-2; CD and cassette.

title: I Am the Center of the Universe
description: A TEENY TINY BABY Written and illustrated by Amy Schwartz. Unpaged. New York: Orchard Books. $15.95. (Ages 2 to 6)

title: Mark M. Pepper and Nicole D. Slater
description: Nicole Diane Slater, the daughter of Sandra Bernstein of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Miles A. Slater of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married last evening to Mark Matthew Pepper, the son of Maggie Weiss of San Francisco and Sanford Pepper of Salt Lake City. Rabbi Steven Glazer officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title:
THE $500 WEEKEND;
Cappuccino and Culture in Seattle
description: NOW I know why Seattle has become the nation's caffeine capital. You need the high-octane espresso dispensed throughout the city to power you up those breathtaking hills.

title: Susan Rotmistrovsky, David Kahn
description: Susan B. Rotmistrovsky, the daughter of Hector Rotmistrovsky of New City, N.Y., and Eva Rotmistrovsky of Mahwah, N.J., was married on Thursday to David Roger Kahn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mike Kahn of New York. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated at Tavern on the Green in New York.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: TURNING BACK THE SUN By Colin Thubron. Harper Perennial, $12. In an unnamed landscape that resembles Australia, a provincial doctor confronts racism as he attempts to treat a mysterious disease that turns white skin a deep brown. Drought heightens tensions in the town, whose residents blame the aborigines for their suffering. In 1992 our reviewer, David Sacks, called this novel "admirable, thought-provoking . . . urgent in its message."

title: Commercial Property/Fifth Avenue; A Banking Corner Tries on a New Wardrobe
description: IN A MOVE that strengthens the renewed growth of middle-level retailing on Fifth Avenue in the mid-40's, Today's Man, the off-price clothing chain, is to open its third Manhattan superstore outlet next spring in the vacant former bank branch at 529 Fifth Avenue.

title: It's Not the Only Alien Invader
description: THREE MORNINGS A WEEK, DANIELLE KITAOKA rises at 3 A.M. and drives the 20 minutes from her home in Kaneohe, on the island of Oahu, to Honolulu International Airport, where she works as an inspector for the Hawaii Department of Agriculture. She makes a few calls from her office, then swings by the department's dog kennel near the airport to pick up an eager beagle named Columbo. Her main task for the day begins promptly at 6 with the arrival from Guam of Continental Flight 934.

title: A Theater Company Tackles the Issues
description: NO, the Luna Stage Company is not a woman's theater, says Jane Mandel in answer to those who assume it is. "But women started it," Ms. Mandel hastily adds.

title: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE DRESSING ROOM;
Fashion's Recurrent Urge To Fetter Women
description: WHAT is it about the 90's, about that period just before the turn of a century, that impels designers to corset women?

title: Up From Propaganda
description: IN a macabre way, the murder of Dmitri Kholodovthe 27-year-old reporter who was blown up in his newsroom by a booby-trapped briefcase -- testifies to the influence and impact of the Russian press these days, as it struggles honorably to do its job in a rather lawless time.

title: TRULY GROSS ECONOMIC PRODUCT
description: I suspect that Nicholas Wade (lucky man) has never been on a diet, since he reports that "affluence makes obesity possible." On the contrary, a healthy diet always costs more. In most cases, the more sinful the food, the less it costs. JUDITH S. BRONNER Tequesta, Fla.

title: Moving Ahead at Medical Center
description: IT was mostly good news last week for the beleaguered Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. After several delays and a series of interim contracts, a politically controversial 10-year affiliation agreement between the public hospital and New York Medical College got final approval from the County Board of Legislators.

title: Is the Hippie Circuit Washed Up
description: IT IS SUNSET ON SUNRISE Beach, and the great lunar orb is climbing skyward over southern Thailand. A scruffy trio of Israelis and a lone Italian follow the narrow dirt lane past rows of open-air shops down to the water's edge, where a crowd is gathering. A German woman with brightly painted breasts pushes through to greet a group of white Rastas who are clambering down from a motor launch and wading ashore. A faint musk of marijuana graces the air. A Roman candle erupts into the sky. The full-moon party, waxing and waning for a week now, has officially re-begun.

title: Alletta Laird, William Tate
description: Alletta d'Andelot Laird, a daughter of Mrs. Calhoun W. Wick of Wilmington, Del., and the late George W. Laird, was married yesterday to William Still Tate, a son of Mary C. Adams of Richmond and James P. Tate 3d of Roanoke, Va. The Rev. Luis Leon performed the ceremony at the Old Swedes' Episcopal Church in Wilmington.

title: Firefighters Battle Large Blaze in Abandoned Airplane Factory
description: Long Island firefighters were still working early this morning to control a blaze that started yesterday afternoon at an abandoned airplane factory in East Farmingdale, shooting flames so high into the air that the orange glow could be seen more than five miles away.

title: Columbia Savors Victory 23 Years in the Making
description: Sisyphus had nothing on these guys.

title: Say 'Oh, Jolly Good!' Or 'Awesome!' or Both
description: The retro style, mixing earlier decades with the present, was seen on and off the fashion runways in recent weeks. On the streets of Paris a lace-trimmed coat from the early 1900's (top, second from left) and on Madison Avenue a young couple in new clothes, all in black (top, second from right), recalled the Edwardian period. A woman on Fifth Avenue (top, far right) wore a 1940 profile hat with a circa 1949 jacket. Rakishly tilted doll hats of the late 30's (far left) were seen in New York (top) and in Paris (bottom). And a trumpet-shaped skirt, circa 1950, was mixed (left) with a 40's jacket, feather boa, tilted hat and fur-cuffed boots. Young men have joined the retro act, too: mixing a 40's tie, a 50's cardigan sweater and a late 50's velour hat decorated with toothpicks (above); reviving the 1950's London banker style with chalk-stripe suit and homburg hat (right), and imitating the stevedore style of the 20's and 30's with suspenders, plaid shirt and tweed trousers, vest and cap (bottom, far right).

title: Make Way for Allegories
description: PILGRIM'S PROGRESS By John Bunyan. Retold by Gary D. Schmidt. Illustrated by Barry Moser. 76 pp. Grand Rapids, Mich.: William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company. $24.99. (Ages 8 and up)

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Dr. Janice Cohn;
Countering Violence's Effect on Children
description: WITH daily stories of shootings, stabbings and kidnappings, Dr. Janice Cohn, a psychotherapist, worries about what effect violence is having on children.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: The Sophisticated Traveler/ Magazine Part 2 Special Today: Children's Books/ Book Review, Section 7 A 36-page special section.

title: A Question Of Safety: A special report.; Troubles at USAir: Coincidence or More?
description: As USAir Flight 565 reached cruising altitude of 33,000 feet last Feb. 22, the pilots made a chilling discovery -- their DC-9, carrying 62 passengers from Washington to Boston, might not have enough fuel to reach its destination. Radioing for an emergency landing at New York's La Guardia Airport, the pilots claimed the plane had engine trouble.

title: Deadly Gifts to Greece and Turkey
description: In recent years U.S. arms have poured into Greece and Turkey, making them two of the biggest recipients of America's lethal largesse. The United Nations arms registry reveals that in 1992 and 1993 the U.S. turned over 1,163 tanks and 23 combat aircraft to Greece and 1,509 tanks, 54 fighter planes and 28 heavily armed attack helicopters to Turkey.

title:
DANCE;
Expressing Forms Of East and West
description: THE singular advantages of the choreographer Nai-Ni Chen include a heritage that begins with the music and dance of ancient China and extends to an immersion and training with some of the icons of modern dance. Add to this amalgam physical beauty and talent, and the result is the creative package that has earned Ms. Chen and her company, the Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company, substantial financial support and audience acclaim.

title: 50 Years Later, a Romantic What-If
description: In the summer of 1944, Allied forces gained a foothold in France, and the great proletarian class struggle continued in the Coops. And Vera Shain, 13, a quiet, petite girl with wavy chestnut-colored hair, and Richard (Teykie) Treadwell Taylor, 14, a husky football player, fell in love.

title: Time and 'The Shadow Box'
description: Michael Cristofer was 32 when his play "The Shadow Box," about three terminally ill patients and the people close to them, won a 1977 Tony Award and the Pulitzer Prize. Why would such a young man write about death?

title: 1 Million Italians in Piazza to Protest Government Budget
description: More than one million Italians filled the ancient squares of Rome today to protest an austerity-budget proposal that the conservative Government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi is to submit to Parliament on Monday.

title: Business Diary: November 6-11
description: COMPANIES Sears Goes Home (Having Just Sold the Family House) In the public eye, Sears, Roebuck sells stuff -- tools, lingerie, you name it; it isn't the place to go for financial services. And investors didn't know what to make of it. Invest in the stores, you got Allstate; invest in Allstate, you got washing machines. Last week Sears simplified matters in an instant, splitting off control of Allstate to shareholders -- thus waking from a grand conglomerate dream of the 80's. "Sears is home now," one shareholder said. Well, not exactly. Earlier last week, washing its hands of a mountain of debt, Sears turned over the 110-story Sears Tower in Chicago to a creditors' trust. Also (yes, it was a busy week for Sears), Edward Brennan said he planned to retire as chairman when Allstate's gone, probably by mid-1995. His chosen successor: Arthur Martinez, who in two years did wonders in rescuing Sears stores from terminal stodginess.

title:
ART;
Now Reality, Not Imagination, Drives the Horses
description: ONE SIGN OF HOW MUCH Susan Rothenberg has changed since moving west from New York four years ago is that on the first morning of a recent trip here she headed for the American Museum of Natural History. One might have expected her top priority would be to inspect the hanging of her first exhibition of new paintings in two and a half years, at the Sperone Westwater Gallery in SoHo through Dec. 17.

title: Correction
description: A foreign exchange listing in the Travel Watch column last Sunday misstated last year's rate for the Italian lira. One dollar was worth 1,585 lire.

title: Fresh Herbs Add a Hint of the Exotic to Desserts
description: MINT is losing its monopoly. Other fresh green herbs that have long been associated with savory dishes, not sweets, have begun showing up on dessert plates in restaurants.

title:
A LA CARTE;
Letting Someone Else Cook the Turkey Dinner
description: THANKSGIVING dinner, that most traditional of American meals, is usually served at home after a blitz of cooking and is often accompanied by frazzled nerves. But for small families, or those who would rather dine out, here are a few New Jersey restaurants that will be open for the holiday.

title: BENNINGTON MEANS BUSINESS
description: Ah, the poker games. During those notorious all-nighters, every human aptitude and sentiment was on exhibition. I know. I was there -- a student cum faculty wife. The one-liners around that beat-up dining room table were the attar of education.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
An Unhappy Man
description: NOBODY'S FOOLThe Lives of Danny Kaye.By Martin Gottfried.Illustrated. 352 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster.

title: Since 1854, Tea Treasures
description: PICTURE a discreet wood-paneled facade in the Marais, the most interesting and spiciest part of old Paris. Should you open the front door and enter Mariage Freres, you can count on warming yourself all the way to your heart. This is no ordinary tearoom; the Mariage family, which has been trading in tea since 1660, maintains a house of tea that is a treasure chest, even in this city of plenty.

title: Sam Shepard, Storyteller
description: SOMEWHERE BETWEEN the East and West Coasts, at least part of "Simpatico," one of the season's most anticipated plays, was written in a moving truck by its driver. That's Sam Shepard, who says he believes "all good writing comes out of aloneness." And you're not too likely to be interrupted driving along an Interstate.

title: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 13, 1994
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 MR. MURDER, by Dean Koontz. (Berkley, $6.99.) A mystery writer's happy family life -- and the madman determined to take his place. 2 26 INTERVIEW WITH THE VAMPIRE, by Anne Rice. (Ballantine, $6.99.) The 1976 novel that began "The Vampire Chronicles." 3 9 DISCLOSURE, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $6.99.) An executive who rejected his boss is accused by her of sexual harassment. 4 22 THE SHIPPING NEWS, by E. Annie Proulx. (Touchstone/S&S, $12.) A man mourns his adulterous wife in Newfoundland. 5 8 THE DOOR TO DECEMBER, by Dean Koontz. (Signet, $6.99.) A young girl disappears. 6 7 VANISHED, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $6.99.) The abduction of a young boy creates a crisis. 7 3 A HOLIDAY OF LOVE, by Judith McNaught, Jude Deveraux, Arnette Lamb and Jill Barnett. (Pocket, $5.99.) Four romantic stories. 8 20 WITHOUT REMORSE, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $6.99.) John Kelly in North Vietnam. 9 11 SMILLA'S SENSE OF SNOW, by Peter Hoeg. (Dell, $6.50.) A child's mysterious death. 10* 8 PEARL IN THE MIST, by V.C. Andrews. (Pocket, $6.50.) The ordeals of a girl beset by a hostile stepmother and a troubled twin sister. 11 17 FORREST GUMP, by Winston Groom. (Pocket, $5.50.) A slow-witted man makes his way through three decades of American history. 12 13 LIKE WATER FOR CHOCOLATE, by Laura Esquivel. (Anchor/Doubleday, $5.99.) Love and hope -- plus recipes -- on a Mexican ranch. 13 3 HONOR BOUND, by W.E.B. Griffin. (Jove, $6.50.) Three American servicemen on a mission to sabotage German activities in 1942. 14 2 THE DEVIL'S OWN, by Sandra Brown. (MIRA, $4.99.) A 1987 novel about a woman who accepts the advances of a rogue to save nine orphans. 15 2 THE HOPE, by Herman Wouk. (Little, Brown, $6.99.) The story of Israel from the war of independence, in 1948, to the 1967 war. 16* 8 CHAMPIONS OF THE FORCE, by Kevin J. Anderson. (Spectra/Bantam, $5.99.) The final volume of a "Star Wars" trilogy. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 8 EMBRACED BY THE LIGHT, by Betty J. Eadie with Curtis Taylor. (Bantam, $5.99.) A woman's near-death experience. 2 3 SEE, I TOLD YOU SO, by Rush Limbaugh. (Pocket, $6.99.) More comments on the state of the nation by the talk show host. 3 44 CARE OF THE SOUL, by Thomas Moore. (Harper Perennial, $12.) A psychotherapist discusses spirituality and everyday life. 4 7 HAVING OUR SAY, by Sarah L. Delany and A. Elizabeth Delany with Amy Hill Hearth. (Dell, $5.99.) Two black sisters reflect on their lives. 5 3 WOULDN'T TAKE NOTHING FOR MY JOURNEY NOW, by Maya Angelou. (Bantam, $5.50.) Essays on life and death, good and evil. 6 9 PRIVATE PARTS, by Howard Stern. (Pocket, $6.99.) The memoirs of the radio and television personality. 7 575 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Inspiration. 8 11 A HISTORY OF GOD, by Karen Armstrong. (Ballantine, $14.) The development of monotheism over the past 4,000 years. 9 1 A MARRIAGE MADE IN HEAVEN ... OR TOO TIRED FOR AN AFFAIR, by Erma Bombeck. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.99.) Reflections on 44 years of marriage. 10 3 FURTHER ALONG THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $12.) A discussion of spiritual growth. 11* 24 REENGINEERING THE CORPORATION, by Michael Hammer and James Champy. (Harper Business, $13.) Innovation in business. 12 43 WHERE ANGELS WALK, by Joan Wester Anderson. (Ballantine, $10.) Stories about angelic intervention in human affairs. 13* 25 LISTENING TO PROZAC, by Peter D. Kramer. (Penguin, $12.95.) A psychiatrist reflects on mood-changing medications and their effects. 14* 7 DAKOTA, by Kathleen Norris. (Houghton Mifflin, $9.95.) A celebration of the changing life and terrain of the Great Plains. 15 91 I KNOW WHY THE CAGED BIRD SINGS, by Maya Angelou. (Bantam, $4.99.) The poet's depiction of her childhood and adolescence. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 6 HOMICIDAL PSYCHO JUNGLE CAT, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) A collection of "Calvin and Hobbes" cartoons. 2 191 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $12.) Principles to practice in the pursuit of success. 3 7 CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE SOUL, compiled by Jack Canfield and Mark Victor Hansen. (Health Communications, $12.) Stories meant to "open the heart and rekindle the spirit." 4 12 GUMPISMS: The Wit and Wisdom of Forrest Gump, by Winston Groom. (Pocket, $5.) The witticisms of a fictional character. Rankings reflect sales figures, for the week ending Oct. 29, at 3,050 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 38,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: In Houston, The Symphony Reclaims Its Past
description: A USIC CRITIC BORN AND raised in Houston, as I was, constantly bumps up against the assumption that anyone so marooned, beyond the pale of the northern culture belt, could have had no early opportunity to hear first-rate performances of symphonic music. Yet during my childhood and adolescence, the Houston Symphony Orchestra was led successively by Ferenc Fricsay, Sir Thomas Beecham, Leopold Stokowski, Sir John Barbirolli and Andre Previn. What orchestra in the United States, or Europe for that matter, can boast a more lustrous lineage than that?

title: Army Lets It Slip Away, And Boston U. Cashes In
description: After trailing Army, 6-0, at the half, Boston University scored three second-half touchdowns to beat the Cadets, 21-12, before a crowd of 33,762 at Michie Stadium. The Cadets had hoped for better, and before the game -- at least on paper -- it looked as if they might deserve it.

title: At Play in Old Miami Beach
description: (The budgets for the $500 weekends covered accommodations, sightseeing, food and drink, but not the cost of transportation to and from the cities.)

title: Literary Symposium Celebrates
description: IT is a year of round-number anniversaries for many organizations as museums, churches, music schools and other groups celebrate their achievements and meditate on their milestones.

title: Back of Beyond In Peru
description: WHAT'S probably a ruin," Don Oscar said, pointing across the valley at a mountaintop festooned with mats of jungle. If so, sheer cliffs still defended the fortress, temple or city of the ancient Chachapoyans, the warrior farmers who had flourished in what is now the Amazonas department of far northern Peru from A.D. 1000 to just before the Spanish conquest. After seeing hundreds of ruins on dozens of mountaintops, my friends and I could agree that this site fit Chachapoyan tastes: it had healthy breezes, strategic elevation, commanding views.

title: Portrait of the Electorate: Who Voted for Whom in the House
description: The Republicans made widespread gains on Election Day, capturing control of both houses of Congress for the first time in 40 years and also making advances in governor's offices and in statehouses across the country.

title: Daria F. Pizzetta, Charles D. Brown
description: Daria F. Pizzetta, a daughter of Don F. Pizzetta of Gulfport, Miss., and the late Stephanie Pizzetta, and Charles D. Brown, the son of Charles E. Brown of Concord, S.I., and the late Dolores M. Brown, were married yesterday. Msgr. James Russell performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Biloxi, Miss.

title: Battered but Unbowed, a Maestro Rebounds
description: HOW QUICKLY HAS Franz Welser-Most, a 34-year-old Austrian with a complicated personal history, risen to the top tier of international maestros?

title: A Manhattan With Michelle
description: WRAPPED in fog and mist, Seattle during the dark season feels like a set from a film noir -- all whispered conspiracies and huddled alliances over strong coffee and thick beer in local hangouts.

title: Chalk Body Outlines: Grisly, Yes, but Chic
description: WHEN Michael Carr felt compelled several years ago to produce art that would commemorate the escalating number of violent deaths in Washington, one image haunted him. So he went into an alley near his home in Washington's Northwest quadrant and began painting outlines of bodies in the style he had seen used at the scenes of homicides depicted in movies and on television.

title: End Indonesia's Imperialist Rule
description: When President Clinton visits Indonesia for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum this week, he should call for independence for East Timor.

title: This Matchup Is All It's Pumped Up to Be
description: The Dallas Cowboys enter with a familiar bluster.

title: Sexism by a Thread?
description: IN "Eat Drink Man Woman," the director Ang Lee explained the relationship between men and women via food. But it could just as well have been sartorial, a sort of "Pants Shirt Man Woman."

title: NOV. 6-12: Amid Rumors; Reagan Discloses His Alzheimer's
description: Alzheimer's disease causes the mental and physical deterioration of an estimated 4 million Americans. And it tears at the hearts of millions more who must cope with watching a loved one unravel. Last weekend, former President Ronald Reagan disclosed that he has entered the early stages of the incurable and ultimately fatal disease.

title: Rhodes
description: To the Editor: That was a terribly unfair portrait of Rhodes.
