Methinks that Ms. Spano's experience there must have been a projection of her sour mood, maintained as a result of the frustration of her plans. Admittedly, traveling around the Greek islands requires some resiliency, as well as an aquiescence to both the laws of nature and the quirky scheduling of ferries.

title: The Sublime, the Modern and the Literal in Views of the Land
description: IN the Neuberger Museum at Purchase College, it is all landscape -- painted, drawn, printed and photographed or else implied by sculpture. The show, titled "Inspired by Nature," may not be a survey, but it covers a lot of ground with 80 works by 53 artists, many of them polar opposites, like Thomas Cole and Alex Katz, Raoul Hague and Louis Eilshemius.

title: Islamic Guard Unit Ousted
description: Under pressure from a Brooklyn Assemblyman, state housing officials have decided not to renew a building-security contract held by a unit of the Nation of Islam.

title: The Election and the Kremlin
description: A Republican-dominated Congress in Washington is expected to create new strains in the Russian-American relationship, which is already showing stress as Boris N. Yeltsin's Government moves toward a more centrist, nationalist position at home and abroad.

title: This Week's Numbers
description: Last Consensus Period Estimates (I.D.E.A. INC.) Tues. Retail sales, Oct., pct. chg. 0.6 0.5 Industrial production, Oct., pct. chg. 0.0 0.5 Capacity utilization, Oct., percent 84.6 84.9 Wed. Consumer prices, Oct., pct. chg. 0.2 0.3 Business inventories, Sept., pct. chg. 1.0 0.3 Thur. Housing starts, Oct., mils., ann. rate 1.53 1.50 Weekly jobless claims, thousands 330 325 Fri. Trade balance, Sept., billions -$9.7 -$9.5 This Week's Developments Tues. Federal Reserve Open Market Committee meets Thur. Philadelphia Fed Nov. business outlook survey Fri. Minutes of Sept. 27 F.O.M.C. meeting released

title: French Classics
description: LA COTE BASQUE *** (212) 688-6525; 5 East 55th Street; $$$$; all major credit cards

title: The New Chelsea's Many Faces
description: TWILIGHT cloaked the raw-edged precinct west of the old High Line, the abandoned railroad viaduct that haunts lower 10th Avenue. Ghostly signs, ever fading on the brick walls of brooding old lofts, attested to businesses long lost: "Spears Furniture Exchange" and "Kiln-Dried Lumber" and "Tower's Warehouses."

title: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Opposite Madison Square Garden; Sports Store For Midtown
description: The Sports Authority, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla.-based retailer with more than 100 outlets nationwide and 18 in the tristate area, will open its first New York City store Tuesday in 40,000 square feet in the Hotel Pennsylvania, at Seventh Avenue and 32d Street. The Sports Authority, a subsidiary of Kmart, chose the location "because they wouldn't move Madison Square Garden for us," said Vince Osborne, a marketing executive at the company.

title: With Pataki, What You See Is Just What You Get
description: Almost everyone on his plane knew that George E. Pataki had worn the same red-orange tie for the last three days of his lurching but successful campaign for governor, and not for luck. Of course, it had never occurred to him.

title: BENNINGTON MEANS BUSINESS
description: I found Mark Edmundson's article on the changes at Bennington fair and objective. But he neglected to mention the dilemma facing recent Bennington graduates: How do we support our beloved school (which may not survive without our financial help) without feeling that we are betraying the teachers -- our friends -- who were so rudely and unnecessarily dismissed? I find no easy answer. DANIEL E. SAMS LEHMAN Bennington, Vt.

title: AnneBeth Litt And Todd Gordon
description: Dr. AnneBeth Litt, the daughter of Lois and Jay T. Litt of Dix Hills, L.I., was married last evening to Todd Gordon, the son of Barbara and Miles Gordon of Woodbury, L.I. Rabbi Arthur Rulnick officiated at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I.

title: Back to Basics in Lyons
description: WHEN I want authenticity, I go straight to the source. So if I find my thoughts turning to steaming platters of chicken with red-wine vinegar, mountainous green salads tossed with croutons, eggs and cubes of fresh bacon, and sturdy bottles of fresh Beaujolais, a pilgrimage to Lyons is in order.

title: Poussin Is Revered, but Can He Be Enjoyed?
description: FOR A MODERN VIEWER, especially one who isn't French, Nicolas Poussin may be the most difficult of all the great artists to appreciate. Anyone dimly familiar with the history of painting can probably conjure up an image of his "Rape of the Sabines" or "The Massacre of the Innocents." But that image can seem very remote.

title: Jill Golden, Joshua Tarnow
description: Jill Ann Golden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Golden of Meadowbrook, Pa., was married last evening to Joshua Robert Tarnow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Tarnow of South Orange, N.J. Rabbi Alan Fuchs performed the ceremony at Temple Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia.

title: TRULY GROSS ECONOMIC PRODUCT
description: A recent report on why Americans continue to gain weight blames the automobile and television, but mostly the auto. Most television watching is done at night, when people are not doing much anyway. Cars are used during the prime activity hours, when our ancestors would have been hunting and gathering food. Our bodies were designed to walk. EUGENE R. GOBBY Boston

title: Talks Halt As Owners Map a New Proposal
description: Negotiators for baseball's striking players and owners made it into the third consecutive day of renewed talks today, then suddenly adjourned to give the owners' bargaining team more time to develop a proposal it will present when they reconvene.

title: THE NATION: Right Stuff; G.O.P. Unleashes Its New Weapon: Winning Candidates
description: THE Republican romp in Tuesday's election was a repudiation of President Clinton. It represented disgust with big government and the way Congress has been operating. It indicated a shift toward conservatism. It reflected the anxiety of many voters about their future and that of their children in a rapidly changing economy. Or so the pundits say.

title: G.O.P. Strength Denies Cuomo A Close Finish; Suburbs Give Pataki Bounce
description: VOTERS in the New York City suburbs played a pivotal role in George E. Pataki's victory last week, sending him to the Executive Mansion with a margin of victory that far exceeded his statewide performance.

title: Ducks Are Unknowns Now in the Know
description: Roses are sold out on campus, alumni beg for field passes and Penn State may soon want to investigate. The Oregon Ducks are the hottest team nobody knows, a late-game score the East Coast can live without. But one more victory and they may be in a national championship game.

title: Wall Street; Look Who's Selling Solomon-Page
description: WHAT more could investors ask? A hot public offering, an affordable $4-a-unit price, and a company in a business that takes off in a good economy.

title: A Better Tree House
description: MY OLD COLLEGE roommate Joe, an artist who over the years has spent some particularly sweet summers with his family on a hillside in rural Vermont, has the right idea about tree houses. A tree house, of course, is not about housing. Nor, to Joe, a skilled carpenter, is it remotely connected to the craft of woodworking. It is, instead, airborne sculpture, best left to the imagination and exertions of those young enough to make it right.

title: The Painter's Life Is Cracking
description: WHEN THE 35-YEAR RETROSPECTIVE OF HIS paintings opened at the Tate Gallery in London in June, the reviews were so barbed and so poisonous that R. B. Kitaj, who had emerged from his quiet, orderly burrow to publicize the show, staggered back into seclusion with a bitterness of Shakespearean depths. He announced that he would never again exhibit his paintings in England. He suggested to friends that, having lived as an expatriate American in London since 1959, he was ready to return to the States. He speculated in a British newspaper interview that his pummeling in the press might represent "a form of low-octane English anti-Semitism." While he had always eschewed modern communications, including answering machine and fax, he said he would now disconnect his telephone, retreating behind the gray brick facade of his 19th-century house in the Chelsea district. There, he could return to working in his studio, and to the domestic life he shared with his wife, the painter Sandra Fisher, and their 9-year-old son, Max.

title: How It Works: Guide-Dog School for People and Dogs
description: THE Seeing Eye and Guiding Eyes for the Blind, the most renowned guide-dog schools in the New York area, extensively interview prospective owners. Guiding Eyes will send a representative to the home of anyone living too far to visit; the Seeing Eye often does, too. During training, students live on campus, eating in the dining rooms and sleeping in the private or shared bedrooms. A first-time guide-dog training at Seeing Eye takes 28 days; subsequent trainings take 21 days. The training at Guiding Eyes lasts 26 days for first-time and veteran dog users.

title: The Queen and the Mathematician
description: CLEOPATRA By Diane Stanley and Peter Vennema. Illustrated by Diane Stanley. Unpaged. New York: Morrow Junior Books. $15. (Ages 7 and up) THE LIBRARIAN WHO MEASURED THE EARTH By Kathryn Lasky. Illustrated by Kevin Hawkes. 48 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Palm Bech On Wry
description: I shudder to think what it says about my character, but when I'm on vacation there are two things I like to do, almost to the exclusion of all others. Number one, I like to drive around fancy neighborhoods, and number two, I like to browse through expensive stores. And this is why I like Palm Beach so much. These are not only the best things to do in Palm Beach; they are virtually the only things to do in Palm Beach.

title: A Brooklyn Co-op Tries Acting Like a Condo
description: A CENTRAL goal of many co-op apartment buildings in New York City is to build up the level of owner-occupancy. These are buildings that are owned by co-op corporations but are largely occupied by long-term rental tenants.

title: SUNDAY, November 13. 1994; England's Puzzling Passion
description: The English love mazes. Especially the present Marquess of Bath. Twenty years ago, when he was a mere viscount, he commissioned Greg Bright to design the world's largest hedge maze (above) for his home, Longleat House. He is now creating the Labyrinth of Longleat, composed of mazes by the world's leading designers. One, the 18-inch-high Love Maze by Graham Burgess, has been planted and should be ready to walk through in a few years when the roses and boxwood mature. Two others, a linked Sun Maze and Lunar Labyrinth, have been designed by Randoll Coate, who specializes in symbolic mazes. Ground-breaking is tentatively set for next year. The Marquess has not completely cornered the maze market. Coate worked on a maze for the city of Bath and has recently been approached about a project on a smaller scale. A collector of historic doll houses has asked him to do a circular maze for a miniature Palladian villa. The maze will have a diameter of about five inches.

title: A Concert Calendar With Wide Variety
description: CHAMBER and orchestral music, folk songs and children's programs are all on today's calendar, starting at 2 P.M., when Claire Barry brings "Yiddish Swing" to the Jewish Cultural Series at the Lehman Center in the Bronx. The number for more information is (718) 960-8833.

title: Shoulder Pain Sidelines Jeter
description: DEREK JETER's rapid ascent to the majors has hit a minor snag as the Yankees announced yesterday that the 20-year-old shortstop had been removed from the Arizona Fall League because of a shoulder injury. Jeter, who played in 154 games in four leagues this season, had complained of soreness in his right shoulder since last month and Dr. STUART HERSHON examined him Wednesday and detected minor inflammation.

title: Sex Shops and Peep Shows: Hard to Avoid or Ignore
description: To the Editor:

title: Left to Die, the South Bronx Rises From Decades of Decay
description: When Fausto Rodriguez, his wife and three children fled East Harlem two years ago in search of a house in a quieter, safer neighborhood, they headed across the river.

title: Hoosiers in Africa
description: WHITE MAN'S GRAVEBy Richard Dooling.386 pp. New York:Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: The Aging Process Holds Few Fears For This Troupe
description: EVERYTHING ABOUT JIRI kylian as a choreographer has an original touch. So it comes as no surprise that creativity runs through all levels of the three-tier organization he directs under the title of Netherlands Dance Theater (N.D.T.).

title: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'
description: To the Editor:

title: California Regulates Those Who Sell Travel
description: IN an effort to protect the California consumer, Gov. Pete Wilson has signed legislation designed to offer a safeguard against potential travel-related scams and bankruptcies. The law, which revises existing legislation, is widely expected to be used as a national model.

title: Long Island Q&A: Joel Sussman; On the Trail of an Enzyme That Could Lead to Alzheimer's
description: DR. JOEL SUSSMAN sits restlessly behind his computer at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton typing furiously. At last the screen displays a dynamic bending and flexing three-dimensional image of a body enzyme, acetylcholinesterase. It does not look much different from childhood Tinkertoy projects.

title: 2 Plans to House Elderly Opposed by Neighbors
description: TWO unrelated projects that seek to provide housing for the elderly have triggered opposition in two disparate communities.

title: Fiddling With Psyches
description: To the Editor:

title:
HOME CLINIC;
A Fine Wood Floor Is Worthy of Good Care
description: A wood floor is a thing of beauty. But wood floors take abuse and require proper care to keep them looking good.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Great Leaping Illustrations! It Works!
description: THE WAY THINGS WORKBy David Macaulay.CD-ROM. (Windows) New York:Dorling Kindersley. $99.95. (Ages 11 and up)

title: An Important First Step for New Products
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: Awaiting 'the Big One' Q. I understand there is a fault line that runs under New York City. Where does it run? When was the last earthquake? Are there any predictions about the next one -- and are New York skyscrapers designed to withstand such a thing? I've heard reports that a large earthquake (over 5 on the Richter scale) is overdue for New York City. Is this true? A. Everyone knows New York City has more than its share of faults. At least two run across upper Manhattan, one along 125th Street and another near Dyckman Street in Inwood.

title: Bitter Tone of the '94 Campaign Elicits Worry on Public Debate
description: Campaigns are the conversation of democracy, and the one that just concluded was angry, deeply personal, powerfully ideological and exceedingly negative -- sometimes all at once.

title: CURRENCY
TRULY GROSS ECONOMIC PRODUCT
description: In "Truly Gross Economic Product" (Method and Madness, Oct. 16), Nicholas Wade did a fine job of using economics to describe the rise in American obesity. How can this trend be limited? In economics, one way to balance an uneven market is through tariffs. Perhaps a "fat tax" on fatty meat and cream would do us good. JASON PRICE New York

title: The Contract's Brutal Arithmetic
description: Republicans have pledged to vote within 100 days of taking control of the House on a "Contract With America," a package of 10 bills that offers government reforms, tax cuts and deficit reduction. Newt Gingrich, the likely next Speaker, has vowed to honor the pledge promptly.

title: Editorial Notebook; Lessons of the Plague
description: The plague outbreak that struck India this year caused more panic than was warranted. The sudden appearance of this ancient scourge sent hundreds of thousands of residents fleeing from the industrial city of Surat, igniting fears that they would spread the contagion to the jam-packed slums of India's major cities. Apprehensive nations cut off air travel and trade with India; tourists and conference groups canceled trips.

title: For a Competitive Edge, Study in Europe; Cultural Ambassadors
description: To the Editor:

title: New Kid on Block Bumps Shoulders With an Idol
description: When Reggie White recorded 21 sacks during the 1987 season -- a number that still stands as a National Football Conference record -- James Brown was a two-way lineman for the football team at Philadelphia's Mastbaum High School, a teen-ager who watched White and the Eagles religiously.

title: Executives Suspended By Bank
description: The Bankers Trust Company says it has suspended from their normal responsibilities several executives involved in selling to corporations the complex financial agreements known as derivatives.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Askew's Career High Helps Seattle Win Vincent Askew scored 9 of his career-high 20 points in the fourth quarter yesterday as the Seattle SuperSonics defeated the Los Angeles Clippers, 115-90, in Tacoma, Wash. The Sonics went on a 19-5 run in a 6 1/2-minute span of the third and fourth quarters, extending a 76-67 lead to 95-72 with 7 minutes 21 seconds left in the game. Sarunas Marciulionis and Detlef Schrempf had 5 points apiece during that spurt.

title: D. H. Lawrence Seen In One Intense Lens
description: The Story of a Marriage By Brenda Maddox Illustrated. 620 pages. Simon & Schuster. $30.

title: Name Changes For 2 Agencies
description: An advertising agency and a public relations agency have announced name changes.

title: A Comeback With Energy To Spare
description: Few bands are as exhausting to watch as the Proclaimers, who performed on Thursday night at Tramps. Playing one rousing song after another, belting choruses until they were red in the face and pounding on their instruments to accentuate every backbeat, the twins Craig and Charlie Reid put on a performance that was as much a sporting event as a music concert. With a four-member backing band, the Scottish brothers conjured up the ghosts of 1950's doo-wop, soul and rhythm-and-blues but substituted muscle and adrenaline for emotion and ache.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about a rent dispute at a Manhattan apartment building, the Belnord, misspelled the surname of a tenant. He is Thomas Vitullo-Martin, not Bitullo-Martin.

title: We Must Do More to Heal Rwanda's Children; U.N. Forces on Call
description: To the Editor:

title: Nintendo Counts on a New 'Virtual' Game
description: Seeking to revitalize a slowing video game market, the Nintendo Company will announce on Monday a low-priced "virtual reality" game system that it will begin selling in the United States and Japan in April.

title: Disney Mulls Big Florida Expansion
description: The Walt Disney Company is close to approving the investment of as much as $2 billion to expand Disney World, its theme park in Orlando, Fla., a person close to the company said yesterday.

title: Motor Vehicle Theft
description: After peaking around 1990, reported motor vehicle thefts in New York City and the region have fallen considerably. Preliminary 1994 figures show a further decline: car thefts were down 15 percent in the city and 13 percent in New York State in the first six months of 1994 from the first six months of 1993. Law-enforcement officials credit increased enforcement efforts, the proliferation of alarms and other anti-theft devices, and the growing use of identification numbers on cars and parts as reasons for the drop in auto theft. Bridgeport and Newark have even higher rates of car theft per 100,000 residents than New York City, though reported theft in each of those cities declined more than 20 percent in 1993 from 1992.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Japanese stocks traded slightly lower here today. At the close, the 225-stock Nikkei index was down 22.91 points to 19,261.45. On Friday, the index closed up 19.51 points.

title: Whirling Dervishes Spin a Mystical Link Between Earthly and Divine Love
description: For the whirling dervishes of Konya, Turkey, ecstasy derives from discipline. They performed a sema, the Sufi ritual of spiritual rebirth, before a sold-out house on Friday night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. It was a spectacle: six men dressed in white with tall camel-hair hats, with arms outstretched and long skirts twirling, accompanied by music that slowly gathered momentum, from stately extended melodies to more vigorous, more rhythmic tunes.

title: Treasury Bill Auction Today
description: The schedule of Treasury financings this week includes only today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: At 633 License Suspensions, The Top Scofflaw Is Arrested
description: He called himself Bobby Leonard or Harvey Linen, Leroy Linden or something else, and he used various addresses, real and unreal, the police said. But the officers who nabbed him in the Bronx Saturday night called him New York City's top scofflaw -- a phantom motorist whose license has been suspended 633 times since 1990, once every two or three days, on average.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A. M. ROSENTHAL, the former executive editor of The New York Times and a columnist for the newspaper, will receive the Light of Truth Award from the International Campaign for Tibet for his efforts to expose the plight of the Tibetan people.

title: The Mayor's Wife Ignites a Furor in Yonkers; Lynn Zaleski Arrives on the Public Stage With Ample Fire and Brimstone
description: The way Lynn Zaleski sees it, the Yonkers city government can be divided into two camps: one captained by her husband, the Mayor, a good man trying to rescue the city from its corrupt past, and the other led by a majority of the City Council, intent on destroying him.

title: Albert Symphony Has a Posthumous Premiere
description: At his death in an auto accident in 1992, the composer Stephen Albert was working on a theory of what he called harmonic fields in music. Presumably the idea was that much music that did not literally use traditional tonal harmony created its tensions and resolutions with large, vaguer areas of harmonic force. Albert may have written his Second Symphony as an example. It was commissioned by the New York Philharmonic and received its premiere during the weekend's series of subscription concerts conducted by Hugh Wolff. Albert completed a short score before his death, indicating about half the instrumentation; a colleague, Sebastian Currier, felt very little else was required and orchestrated the piece based on his knowledge of Albert's style.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about a surge in the Chiron Corporation's stock price misstated the stock's trading activity on Thursday in some copies. Chiron's shares closed unchanged Thursday at $59.75; they did not rise $4.

title: Fearing a Conspiracy, Some Heed a Call to Arms
description: On a raw, damp weekend morning near this town at the top of Lake Michigan, some 100 members of a group calling itself the Michigan Militia have convened amid the scrub pine to practice military techniques many long ago forgot. Although the training is unsophisticated and the breathing ragged for the middle-aged self-styled warriors, the purpose of the assault maneuvers and target practice is deadly serious, they say. The Michigan Militia is preparing to defend itself against the United States Government.

title: JAZZ
description: A Composer Whose Music Asks The Audience to Come to It Miller Theater

title: China's Trade Status
description: The United States and China are entering the final phase of bitter negotiations over the terms for admitting China to the new World Trade Organization. Page D1.

title: In Prague, a New Daily for English Speakers
description: The first English-language daily newspaper in Eastern Europe since the collapse of Communism is to be introduced on Monday by a young American publisher who has made a name here with a daily fax publication.

title: People
description: * Gary Topolewski, managing partner for creative at Bozell Detroit, Southfield, Mich., was promoted to the new position of executive creative director.

title: Once Again, Jets Are Shot Down on 4th Down
description: It ended for the Jets on the Packers' goal line today, Rob Moore slipping on old-fashioned grass in this old-fashioned stadium as Boomer Esiason's pass skidded off the fingers of one hand.

title: Polite Politics in Beijing's
description: Many observers believe that history is about to repeat itself in China. They say the ailing health of 90-year-old Deng Xiaoping is brewing power struggles between reformers and conservatives, just as the conflicts between the radical Gang of Four and the moderates escalated during Mao Zedong's waning days. Mr. Deng's death, this theory goes, could lead to a period of instability reminiscent of the palace coup in 1976 that resulted in the arrest and imprisonment of the Gang of Four.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Askew's Career High Helps Seattle Win Vincent Askew scored 9 of his career-high 20 points in the fourth quarter yesterday as the Seattle SuperSonics defeated the Los Angeles Clippers, 115-90, in Tacoma, Wash. The Sonics went on a 19-5 run in a 6 1/2-minute span of the third and fourth quarters, extending a 76-67 lead to 95-72 with 7 minutes 21 seconds left in the game. Sarunas Marciulionis and Detlef Schrempf had 5 points apiece during that spurt.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Monday about proposed mergers in Italian banking referred incorrectly to the financial condition of one bank. Banco di Napoli is not threatened by bankruptcy and was not bailed out by other Italian banks at the behest of the central bank.

title: 3 Bands That Help Redefine the Conventions of Their Form
description: Short, fast, loud and catchy: the basics of pop-rock haven't changed in decades, but they are constantly being reaccessorized. For the 1990's, the popular trappings include a buffer of guitars -- often distorted or discordant -- and lyrics that fracture or ignore the romantic verities of older pop. Mere melody can seem too sweet, not tough enough; fierce guitars and booming drums eliminate any wimpiness. On Saturday night at Roseland, Sugar, Velocity Girl and Magnapop were a triple bill of kindred bands, shielding tender feelings in muscular, noisy rock, skipping lead-guitar solos to get to the next riff or accusation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 U.S. PROPOSAL ON CHINA

title: DANCE
description: A Bacchanalia That Errs On the Side of Decorum Performance Space 122

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Challenge to Iraq

title: Gay Politicians Cite Gains Amid Losses
description: Although they lost several major allies and face a far more conservative and hostile Congress, lesbian and gay political leaders say that last week's election was not a repudiation by voters of the gay rights movement.

title: From Stealth Candidate To a Stealth Governor?
description: NEVER has in-your-face New York, with its history of brawling, demanding politics, seen anything like George E. Pataki's campaign for governor. He managed to run a stealth candidacy, standing for little other than the death penalty, lower taxes, welfare reform and not being Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. And he won.

title: Miscellany
description: * DDB Needham Worldwide, New York, and Media Marketing Assessment, Westport, Conn., have formed a joint venture to offer Gold Finder, a service to develop advertising and marketing programs to improve the sales of neglected and poorly performing brand-name products. * Publishers Information Bureau, New York, said magazine advertising pages rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October, to 18,164, from October 1993. For the first 10 months of 1994, total pages rose 4.4 percent, to 144,499, from the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Knicks Need Offense, Not Another Jump Shot
description: Instead of analyzing their first loss, the Knicks were more concerned with how they would respond to it.

title: Hameroff Expands To Florida
description: Hameroff/Milenthal/Spence in Columbus, Ohio, has expanded its operations to Florida by acquiring McFarland & Drier in Miami. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Let's Abolish New York's Obsolete State Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton, on Asia Trip, Faces a Rougher Road
description: As President Clinton began meetings here with Asian and Pacific leaders including China's President, Administration officials said today that he would offer reassurances that the setbacks suffered by the Democrats in last Tuesday's elections would not disrupt American policy in the region.

title: CBS Is Betting on 'Scarlett' To Get Back in Ratings Hunt
description: Considering what it has invested and what it has riding on the outcome, CBS surely does give a damn, and then some, about what happens to Scarlett O'Hara on television this week.

title: G.O.P. Victory Leaves Some Israelis Worried
description: After the Republican sweep in the United States midterm elections last week, two words have entered Israel's political vocabulary with unsettling effect: Jesse Helms.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The lady is a fossil, and that's why she will be the guest of honor, if only in absentia, at a black-tie dinner tonight at the Metropolitan Club. The Institute of Human Origins, which usually honors a living scientist at its annual benefit in New York, is celebrating the 20th anniversary of the discovery of Lucy, the skeleton of one of the oldest human forebears.

title: Korea-Japan Tension Is Centuries Old; Oe the Dissenter
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OFFERS CHINA DEAL TO RESOLVE A MISSILE DISPUTE
description: The United States has offered to forgive China's violations of an international missile accord and waive possible sanctions if China admits the violations, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Haytaian, Philosophical on Senate Loss, Looks Ahead to a Tough Year in Assembly
description: Chuck Haytaian can enjoy television again: "It's the first time in a while I can watch without seeing a nasty commercial about myself," he says.

title: Irish Premier Says Threat to Coalition Impedes Peace Initiative
description: Prime Minister Albert Reynolds said today that a threat by the Labor Party to break up his coalition Government would impede efforts toward peace in Northern Ireland.

title: ABC Affiliates Form Venture
description: ABC's television station affiliates plan to form a company to develop new revenue sources.

title: Pre-Death Cash: A Business Grows
description: Buying life insurance policies from terminally ill people to provide them cash before they die, once seen as a ghoulish business not for the faint of heart, is emerging from the shadows.

title: Rome's Lengthening Shadow
description: When the Roman Catholic bishops of the United States gather in Washington Today for their annual conference, they face a tremendous blow to their teaching authority. The challenge comes not from their often fractious and demanding laity but from Rome. The surface issue in the conflict is the use of two new translations of the Bible; the deeper cause is the Vatican's fear of expanding the roles of women in the church.

title: An Air Attack by Killer B's: Blake and Bledsoe
description: Bengals 34, Oilers 31

title: Hope Sprouts in the Ruins of an Angolan Town
description: Storms of bombs and bullets have left the graceful Portuguese facades along Avenida Joaquim Kapango looking as though they were made of pastel-colored Swiss cheese.

title: Prank Ends in Arrest of 2 Rutgers Students
description: As fraternity pranks go, this one lacked daring, but it nonetheless landed two Rutgers students in jail.

title: Abortion Clinic Case Revives a Legal Dilemma
description: In his trial for fatally shooting a doctor and his volunteer escort outside a Pensacola, Fla., abortion clinic, Paul J. Hill waged one last protest: he chose to represent himself, then refused to offer any witnesses or evidence on his own behalf.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Sleepy, shuffling Fred the Baker is gaining new visibility, beyond his trademark doughnuts.
description: MILLIONS of people know his face, but relatively few know his name. But when you ask Michael Vale -- "Fred the Baker" on the Dunkin' Donuts television commercials -- about it, he says that he does not object one bit.

title: DANCE
description: Moody Dances On a Misty Stage Kaye Playhouse

title: Mattel Doll Account Goes to Deutsch
description: Mattel Inc. of El Segundo, Calif., has assigned Deutsch Inc. in New York responsibilities for its Cabbage Patch Kids brand of dolls. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek has estimated them at $20 million.

title: The Battle Over Artificial Snow
description: Whooshing downhill across blankets of snow on the Rocky Mountain slopes, skiers and snow-boarders are exulting once again in the thrilling joy rides and magnificent vistas of a sport that prides itself on being harmoniously in step with the rhythms of nature.

title: Countdown for Navratilova
description: The $3.5 million Virginia Slims Championships, the year-ending -- and in Martina Navratilova's case, career-ending -- event that features the top 16 players for 1994, gets under way this afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

title: An Official Says Industry Can Police Policy-Buying
description: Brian D. Pardo, president of the National Viatical Association and Life Partners Inc., both of Waco, Tex., has long argued that the industry can police itself and does not need outside regulators.

title: Now Myanmar Must Choose
description: Myanmar's ruling junta, the State Law and Order Restoration Council, or Slorc, is one of the world's most brutal, least legitimate regimes. It seized power in what used to be known as Burma by massacring democracy demonstrators in the streets of Rangoon six years ago. Since then it has ignored elections, cooperated with drug lords and waged a relentless war against democratic political leaders, university students, Buddhist religious activists and the ethnic minorities who make up more than a third of Myanmar's population.

title: Bosnian Army Fights to Hold Areas Taken From Serbs
description: Fighting continued today in northwestern Bosnia as Muslim-led Government forces battled to maintain their hold on territory captured from Bosnian Serb forces and endured artillery attacks from Serbs in Croatia.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: 2 Operas Make Contrast Of the Pastoral and Shrieks Fashion Institute of Technology

title: Take Six in Search of a Communal Feeling
description: Take Six tried so hard to make something special happen at the Beacon Theater on Saturday night that it was hard not to feel some sympathy when nothing came of its work. The band, a pop-gospel group with supercharged harmonies that borrow from jazz vocal music to doo-wop to quartet gospel music, did its best to create the sort of mood that gets a house rocking, but it failed.

title: Niners Press the Issue and Finally Get the Best of Cowboys
description: Sure looked like Dallas, the champs.

title: Rights Protests Undercut Indonesia's Standing at Asia-Pacific Forum
description: Disturbances in East Timor today and a two-day-old sit-in at the United States Embassy here have moved Indonesia's human rights record into the spotlight at a meeting of leaders of the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Cowboys Say a Loss Is Just a Loss
description: Steve Young kissed the Candlestick Park sod; the Dallas Cowboys kissed off the entire game.

title: Of Rankings, Survival And the Quack Attack
description: This was not a weekend to discover a sharper focus in this passionate college football season. This was a weekend to appreciate resourcefulness. Even as teams began to clinch bowl positions, or come within a step of championships, the questions persist. On Survival Saturday, all anyone wanted to do was minimize the damage and get to the next week.

title: BP May Cut 1 of 5 U.S. Jobs
description: The BP Oil Company said yesterday that it would eliminate or farm out as many as 1,000 jobs, one-fifth of its work force.

title: Press
description: JOURNALISTS sometimes promise to keep the identities of their sources secret. Occasionally, a reporter even goes to jail to keep a pledge of confidentiality.

title: Plays That Cast an Irreverent Eye Over Two Revered Playwrights
description: The worlds portrayed in the plays of Tennessee Williams and Sam Shepard may be enlightening places to visit, but who on earth would want to live there?

title: We Must Do More to Heal Rwanda's Children
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Competitive Edge, Study in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE
description: A Mingling of Styles Creates Special Effects Theater of the Riverside Church

title: Abroad at Home; Eye Of Newt
description: With victory, would Newt Gingrich move from street fighter to statesman? It took only a few days to learn the answer: No.

title: Patents
description: SCIENTISTS who helped the Navy create the sophisticated submarine-tracking computer system celebrated in "The Hunt for Red October" now want to deploy similar technology to listen for trouble spots in jet engines, nuclear reactor coolant pumps and electricity-generating steam turbines. Early detection of hairline cracks, for example, would enable technicians to replace crucial parts long before lives are endangered or there is expensive damage.

title: Lintas Executive Goes to Earle Palmer
description: Steve Norcia, a former top executive at Lintas New York, has been named to the new position of managing partner at Earle Palmer Brown and will head the agency's New York office, which has 40 to 45 employees and billings estimated at $50 million.

title: For New York City's OTB, A Sure Bet Ends Up a Loser
description: When New York City went into the bookmaking business in 1971, its officials envisioned that their monopoly franchise would ultimately yield annual profits of $200 million. As it turns out, their projection was off -- by just a little more than $200 million.

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week:

title: Essay; Transfer Of Power
description: Bill Clinton remains President of the United States for foreign affairs, but the center of power in domestic affairs -- both in voting strength and intellectual energy -- has shifted from the White House to the putative Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich.

title: It Seems The Force Is With Chargers
description: All year long everyone has suspected that the San Diego Chargers had a guardian angel sitting on their shoulder pads. Now, they know for sure. It was certified here on a rainy afternoon at Arrowhead Stadium, where the Chargers had not won a game since 1989.

title: Korea-Japan Tension Is Centuries Old
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Chief Urges Talks on Freer Flow of Migrants
description: With Mexican anger still building over the approval of a California ballot initiative to cut social services to undocumented immigrants, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has said Mexico and the United States will have to discuss a freer flow of migrant workers just as they negotiate free trade.

title: He Shot the Ball Into the Air. Reeves Caught It. Touchdown!
description: The play is called Rocket Right Sally All Hook. Sally describes the pass protection. All Hook is what the four receivers are supposed to do.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None

title: Bridge
description: Newspaper columns collected in book form tend to be dull reading, but there are exceptions. One of them is "Get Smarter at Bridge" by Phillip Alder, a highly entertaining offering by North America's youngest bridge columnist. Some of his deals show the author's addiction to P. G. Wodehouse and the television show "Get Smart." Most of them are introduced in a quiz format, and he includes a brief introduction to duplicate play and modern bidding methods.

title: Siberia's Oil Keeps Spilling
description: In Alaska, an oil spill like the one that happened in the Russian Arctic this summer and fall would be called an unmitigated disaster, unleashing a national media frenzy. In Russia, the reaction could hardly have been more different.

title: Court Rejects Goodrich Suit
description: A Federal district judge has rejected a claim by the B. F. Goodrich Company that Allied Signal Inc. infringed Goodrich patents in the design of aircraft brakes.

title: Improved Schools at a Profit: Is a Private Effort Working?
description: Yet another tour group was moving through Sarah M. Roach Elementary School, one of nine schools here managed by Education Alternatives, the nation's biggest for-profit company running public schools. Once again, it was 8-year-old Tamira Griffin's turn to perform.

title: Microsoft Seen Disclosing On-Line Network Plan
description: The Microsoft Corporation, seeking to extend its domination beyond the software industry into the realm of interactive services, is expected to outline its plans today for an ambitious on-line information service called the Microsoft Network.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A European Conductor Finds a Common Denominator Carnegie Hall

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHELLE ENGLER and her husband, GOV. JOHN ENGLER of Michigan, turned their attention away from politics yesterday to the births of their triplet daughters, The Associated Press reported.

title: Election Has Altered Regulatory Landscape
description: In addition to denying the Clinton Administration the power to set a legislative agenda for the 104th Congress, it is now becoming clear that last week's elections will make it more difficult for the White House to assert its social and political priorities by issuing new regulations.

title: Bump And Grin: German Wins Title
description: The 1994 Formula One season, dogged by tragedy and controversy, ended yesterday in a most fitting manner: an anticlimax.

title: No Headline
description: "We are preparing to defend our freedom. The way things are going, I think bullets might be as valuable as gold and silver one day soon." -- RAY SOUTHWELL, a member of the Michigan Militia. [ A14:5. ]

title: When Bad Things Happen To Bad Teams
description: Twenty minutes after the Giants had lost on a bizarre, late play to the Arizona Cardinals, Michael Strahan sat motionless at his locker. His teammates had undressed, but the Giant defensive end just sat there, staring, his equipment still strapped on. He was stunned. The coach was stunned. The team was stunned.

title: An Indirect Route Brings a Charge In the Death of a Milk Deliveryman
description: In four decades of delivering milk, butter and eggs to small markets throughout Brooklyn, Gerald Goldberg built his business through connections, talking to customers, gaining people's trust and learning of opportunities.

title: For Assembly and Senate, Slim Changes
description: This was a banner election for the downtrodden Republicans in the New York Assembly, their best showing since 1968. Yet the six new seats amounted to a few crumpled dollar bills against the vast currency of the Democrats, who have controlled the body for 20 years and still hold nearly a two-to-one margin.

title: Far-Flung Jam Session: Medium Is the Massage
description: The distance between the maker of music and the music itself has always existed. It takes a certain amount of traveling for a finger, a foot or a set of lungs to produce a sound. Pianos have complicated levers that must be negotiated one by one; air must pass through tubes and valves to give a trumpet life.

title: For Hasidim, Rebbe Continues to Inspire
description: To the Editor:

title: Winnipeg Journal; On Canada's Prairie, Kinfolk Rush to Help Ukraine
description: Leonid D. Kuchma, the President of Ukraine, wasn't just being polite when, on a visit last month to this prairie city half a world away from Kiev, he said he "really felt at home."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: In Europe, the Right Also Rises
description: Jorg Haider, an athletic-looking and charismatic 44-year-old, is the new European right personified, one of the rising conservative populists who may be the wave of the future or a troubling throwback to the fascist past.

title: China Pressing to Join Trade Club
description: With its huge internal market and steep growth in exports to the United States, China's effort to become a founding member of a new world trading system could prove to be one of the significant trade events of this time.

title: Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for Peter Bonanni, a longtime advertising and publishing executive, is scheduled for 1 P.M. today at St. Peter's Sanctuary at the Citicorp Center, 619 Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. Mr. Bonanni, who died of cancer on Nov. 3 at the age of 62, was the publisher of Golf Magazine. He previously held sales and executive positions at Charter Publishing, CBS Publications and the Simmons Market Research Bureau.

title: Six Regional Teams Bound For Playoffs All Over Map
description: Six teams from the metropolitan area will play in playoff games on Saturday, and one of them, the United States Merchant Marine Academy, will start the trek toward a possible national championship.

title: Men's Health Magazine Gains Muscle
description: In 1986, with virtually everyone saying they were crazy to start a health magazine for men, the people at Rodale Press put out 200,000 test copies of a sprightly new magazine called Men's Health. It quickly went on to become one of the great circulation success stories of recent years.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week: MONDAY Amer Intl Gr Fort Dearborn Income FPL Group Inc Meredith Corp Minn Mng&Mfg Co Pitney Bowes Inc Synovus Finl Corp TUESDAY Automat Data Processing Bandag Inc Belden Inc Corestates Finl Corp Cross Timbers Oil Co Curtiss-Wright Corp Edo Corp Harsco Corp Loctite Corp Ohio Edison Co Reynolds & Reynolds Co Smith Corona Corp TNP Enterprises Inc Unifirst Corp Mass Valley Natl Bancorp WEDNESDAY Ametek Inc Avnet Inc Baltimore Bancorp Barnett Bks Inc Bowater Inc First Amer Bk Corp First Va Bks Inc Fleet Finl Gr Florida East Coast Gabelli Equity Tr Inc Geico Corp Horace Mann Educators Johnson Ctls Inc Morgan Stanley Gr Newmont Gold Co Newmont Mng Corp Western Res Inc THURSDAY Air Prods&Chems Inc AmSouth Bancorporation Beneficial Corp Champion Intl Corp Chateau Pptys Inc Dial Corp Dresser Inds Inc Duracell Intl Inc Florida Progress Corp Gallagher Arthur J & Co Kansas City South Inds Laclede Gas Co Lee Enterprises Ogden Corp Pepsico Inc Perkin-Elmer Corp Ruddick Corp Sterling Bancorp NY Time Warner Inc XTRA Corp FRIDAY Bairnco Corp Barnes Group Inc Donaldson Inc Edwards A G Inc Hewlett-Packard Co Reynolds Metals Co South Jersey Inds Inc Student Ln Marketing Varian Assoc Inc Whitman Corp

title: Market Place; Two views of the future for New Plan Realty Trust.
description: THESE are not the best of times for real estate investment trusts, known as REIT's. Many publicly owned companies in this interest-rate-sensitive industry have suffered from this year's advances in interest rates and their prices have been steadily pushed lower.

title: Accounts
description: * Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Hong Kong, to handle its Fanta line of soft drinks in Asia and Australia, previously handled by McCann-Erickson Worldwide, New York. The D.M.B.& B. Americas agency handles Fanta in Latin America; Lowe Howard-Spink, London, handles it in Europe. * Kellogg Co., Battle Creek, Mich., to Leo Burnett U.S.A., Chicago, a longtime Kellogg agency, to handle three products being introduced next year: Kellogg's Temptations, a gourmet-style corn cereal in almond and pecan flavors; Rice Krispies Treats bars, ready-to-eat versions of the cereal snack, and Pop-Tarts Minis, bite-sized versions of Pop-Tarts. Billings have not been determined.

title: Step Aside Spot, Ferrets Are Ready to Be Top Dog
description: Patty Krywos dutifully passed out leaflets, brochures and pamphlets to the stream of people who passed by her convention booth hungry for information on a subject of immense importance to them: pet ferrets.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball National Basketball Association

title: Reed Holds And Waits For 2 Aces To Pay Off
description: Willis Reed the player had this uncanny knack of imposing his will on important games during his 10-year career in the National Basketball Association. Willis Reed the general manager has this uncanny knack of imposing his will on personnel matters.

title: Haitians Also Deserve Unarmed Police Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Wilenski; Former Ambassador, 55
description: Peter Wilenski, a former ambassador to the United Nations from Australia who proposed reforms for the administration of the United Nations, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Sydney. He was 55 years old.

title: Pataki Plans Major Overhaul To Shift Direction in Albany
description: Governor-elect George E. Pataki will begin a sweeping overhaul of New York's state government this week, seeking to impose his Republican vision on a sprawling bureaucracy guided by Democratic policies and partisans for the last 20 years.

title: What's in Style For the G.O.P.? Running Shoes
description: So, Mr. Big Shot Republican. You just won control of the Senate. Where do you go next?

title: Exploring the Links Between Depression, Writers and Suicide
description: When the poet Anne Sexton learned of Sylvia Plath's suicide in 1963, she was horrified. "That death was mine," she said. Eleven years later, wrapped in a fur coat that once belonged to her mother, she sat in her car with the engine running in a closed garage and ended her life.

title: Gunning for Wife, Man Kills Sister-in-Law and Himself
description: After what neighbors said was an escalating nightmare of violence and desperation, a man searching for his estranged wife in Queens Saturday night killed his sister-in-law, wounded his brother-in-law and then killed himself, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Askew's Career High Helps Seattle Win Vincent Askew scored 9 of his career-high 20 points in the fourth quarter yesterday as the Seattle SuperSonics defeated the Los Angeles Clippers, 115-90, in Tacoma, Wash. The Sonics went on a 19-5 run in a 6 1/2-minute span of the third and fourth quarters, extending a 76-67 lead to 95-72 with 7 minutes 21 seconds left in the game. Sarunas Marciulionis and Detlef Schrempf had 5 points apiece during that spurt.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Finding Common Passions In Romanticism and the Modern 92d Street Y

title: Harlem Dreams Are Revived For Trade Center and Hotel
description: Nearly given up for dead after more than five years of delays, the long-awaited plan to build an international trade center and hotel on West 125th Street in Harlem appears to be back on track.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Sports of The Times; Admission by Omission: Giants Don't Have a Quarterback They Trust
description: KENT GRAHAM got a standing ovation at the end of the first quarter, and then depressing reality set in. He wasn't Phil Simms either.

title: Legacy of Violence: Indian Officials Face Vengeance for the Killing of Sikhs
description: The number of police commandos mounting a round-the-clock watch on the home here of a senior official of the governing Congress Party has increased sharply in recent weeks. Anybody wearing the turban that is the traditional headwear of the Sikhs has been especially closely watched.

title: To Black Audience in Brooklyn, Mayor Promotes Austerity Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took his message of fiscal austerity to a Bedford-Stuyvesant church yesterday, telling worshipers that his administration's budget cuts would produce some pain for New Yorkers, but were crucial to the survival of the city.

title: As Iraqis Scrimp, Their President Lives Lavishly, U.S. Says
description: American officials trying to maintain support for economic sanctions against Iraq said today that since the end of the Persian Gulf war, Saddam Hussein has spent what may be as much as $1 billion on palaces and presidential retreats around the country.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: A SURE BET TURNS OUT TO BE A LOSER

title: Blocked Path Costs Seton Hall Runner
description: Bryan Spoonire, a senior at Seton Hall, will learn Monday whether his appeal will be upheld by the National Collegiate Athletic Association so he can run in the Division I cross-country championships Nov. 21 in Fayetteville, Ark.

title: Dorothy Dehner Memorial
description: A memorial tribute to the sculptor Dorothy Dehner is to take place tonight at 7:30 in the Gallery of the Art Students League, 215 West 57th Street, Manhattan. Mildred Constantine, James Marston Fitch, Joan Marter and David C. Levy are the scheduled speakers. Miss Dehner died on Sept. 22 at age 92.

title: Police Add Law Degrees To Their Badges and Guns
description: When Thomas L. Kirk of the West Virginia State Police tried law school 14 years ago, he was an anomaly. No patrolman had ever asked for leave for such training, and the department did not know what to do with one who did.

title: In This Believe It or Not, Santana Is a Champion
description: After being crowned the new super welterweight champion on Saturday night, Luis Santana of the Dominican Republic was whisked out of the ring on a stretcher. For the boxing world -- where paragliders intrude on fights and a 45-year-old is the heavyweight champion -- it was just one more hard-to-believe development.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Sports of The Times; In the Mist, Opportunity Slips Past the Jets One More Times
description: IT was all there for the Jets, as it so often has been. But in the end there was no there there.

title: For Musical Appreciation, Sexes Go Their Own Ways
description: Look around most concert halls during any evening or matinee performance, and you might notice more women than men listening for the strains of Mozart or Rachmaninoff. But after the curtain falls and the lights go up, saunter over to the classical section of the nearest record store to see the flip side of this gender-tuned natural selection. There you will more likely find men thumbing through the current batch of music magazines or buying yet another version of the Bach B-minor Mass.

title: POP
description: A Mingling of the Arts By 2 Groups From Mexico Hostos Community College

title: Political Briefs; An Interim Chairwoman For Democratic Party
description: President Clinton today named Debra DeLee to fill in as chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee until he selects a more prominent replacement who would be voted on by the party in January.

title: Revived Stereotype of Hollywood Jews Abounds in Ironies
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Big Dog, Big Time Means Big Pressure
description: They are Boy Scout troop leaders and advisers and they have come from all over the state of Wisconsin to discuss the future of their organization. For the moment, though, there are more pressing things taking place on the gym floor one story below. Faces pressed against the glass, eyes straining downward, they are watching a tall, lanky young man challenge a player more than 10 years his senior to a simple game of H-O-R-S-E.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC., New York, an insurance brokerage and risk management consulting service, has announced a fourth-quarter pretax gain of about $20 million from the sale of its U.S. personal insurance lines business to Chubb Personal Lines Insurance Brokerage Inc., a division of Chubb Corp., Warren, N.J.

title: Future Now Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income(Loss)

title: REPUBLICANS PLAN AMBITIOUS AGENDA IN NEXT CONGRESS
description: As it rolled out its "new order" for Congress and the nation, the incoming House Republican leadership announced today that it would force Congress to work 20 hours a day, seven days a week, if necessary, to push through Newt Gingrich's "Contract With America" in 100 days.

title: Tire Company Leaves
description: The latest Nascar tire war ended abruptly yesterday with a surprise announcement from Hoosier Racing Tire that it was withdrawing immediately from the Winston Cup and Grand National series. (AP)

title: Giuliani Joins Give-and-Take Among Regions
description: With upstate residents saying they voted against New York City in last week's gubernatorial election, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani defended the city yesterday and the perception that it is a drain on state tax dollars.

title: Yeltsin Tells His Military Chiefs They're Doing a Bad Job
description: Speaking today to a conference of top military commanders, President Boris N. Yeltsin expressed unhappiness with their work, urged greater military readiness and said he expected new frictions with the United States under a Congress controlled by the Republican Party.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17 PACIFIC TRADE AGREEMENT As the summit meeting of east Asian and Pacific nations began in Indonesia, they neared an agreement to try to remove all barriers to free trade by the year 2020. A1

title: EXPANSION OF A BRITISH INTERACTIVE TV TRIAL IS PLANNED
description: The Oracle Corporation and BT, formerly British Telecommunications P.L.C., plan to expand their British interactive television services trial to 2,500 homes in the middle of 1995. Previously, the service has been delivered to the homes of BT employees. The system will offer consumers living in Colchester and Ipswich, England, movies-on-demand, home shopping and other services. The service uses a set-top controller based on an Apple Macintosh computer.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an arrest in the slaying of Gerald Goldberg, a deliveryman in Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to the victim's business. He delivered eggs and a variety of dairy products to local stores, but he did not deliver milk.

title: Apple's PC's Top Shipments
description: Apple Computer Inc. topped the Compaq Computer Corporation for third-quarter shipments of personal computers in the United States, the global market research company Dataquest Inc. said today.

title: Raise Share Price, Kerkorian Tells Chrysler
description: With one tart letter to the Chrysler Corporation's board, Kirk Kerkorian, the largest investor in the company, made $100 million in paper profits today.

title: Prudential Places Account in Review
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said yesterday that it had placed in review its estimated $50 million account, which has been handled by Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York for almost five years.

title: Liberty Plans Acquisition
description: The Liberty Financial Companies said today that it planned to buy Newport Pacific Management, which oversees more than $650 million in customer assets.

title: Cheeks Considers Return as Player
description: The assistant coach MAURICE CHEEKS practiced as a player yesterday with the Philadelphia 76ers and said he might try to resume his National Basketball Association career.

title: DANCE
description: Seven Solos of Simplicity Presented by a Wanderer New York Conservatory of Dance

title: Pope Wants the Church to Atone for Historical Errors
description: Pope John Paul II urged the Roman Catholic Church today to mark the third millennium of Christianity starting in the year 2000 by atoning for transgressions, including what he termed "acquiescence" in human rights abuses under totalitarian governments of the 20th century.

title: GM Card Tests New Products
description: GM Mastercard will selectively offer home-equity loans, mortgages, annuities, auto insurance and other products to determine whether the services should be offered to all card holders.

title: How Ever Did You Do It, Mr. Ives?
description: Of Charles Ives, the greatest and strangest of American composers, so much is still unknown. There are basic, unresolved questions about the editing of his manuscripts, the chronology of his output, the validity of his recollections. And a more essential mystery shrouds his process of creation. At an Ives-centered festival presented by the Brooklyn Philharmonic last weekend, a member of the audience asked, "How did you do it?" The question was directed at the composer John Adams, who had orchestrated several Ives songs, but one wanted to ask it of Ives himself. How, from a chaos of secondhand material, does great music arise?

title: The Rise of a Self-Proclaimed Phenomenon
description: VAMPS AND TRAMPS By Camille Paglia 532 pages. Vintage Books. $15.

title: INSIDE
description: Shootout in San Francisco

title: Political Briefs; This Term in Senate To Be Last for Simon
description: Senator Paul Simon, a liberal Democrat from Illinois who once sought his party's nomination for the Presidency, said today that he would not seek re-election when his term expires in 1996.

title: Ice Stars Keep On Melting Hearts of Their Viewers
description: Figure skating is heating up again. Hot on the toe loops of CBS's two-part "Ice Wars" live figure-skating exhibition comes NBC's "The Gold Championship," a live, two-hour show Saturday night from Edmonton, Alberta.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a pop review of a performance by the Proclaimers at Tramps misidentified the performer shown. He was Craig Reid; his twin brother, Charlie, also performed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALESSANDRA MUSSOLINI, the granddaughter of Benito Mussolini, the Italian dictator, is expecting a child in July.

title: Subway Work In Flushing Is Restored
description: Using its power over transit construction funds as leverage, the Giuliani administration persuaded transit officials yesterday to go ahead with rebuilding a busy subway station in Flushing, Queens, even as they planned to put off similar work at 15 other stations.

title: DF&R Restaurants
description: Shares of DF&R Restaurants, which operates Harrigan's and Don Pablo's, fell sharply yesterday for a second day. The company said on Friday that second-quarter profits would be below estimates.

title: Lyle Lovett, From Wistful to Weird
description: Lyle Lovett can make any song sound like a small tragedy. His pained, honeyed voice, with its bluesy turns and its countryish ache, fills every line with sincerity; his unhurried, deadpan delivery gives every line the air of an intimate confession. He uses his Large Band, including horns, strings and backup singers, to add small touches of down-home Americana like gospel harmonies or a Western-swing fiddle solo; it's a virtuosic group that always defers to its leader. While Mr. Lovett always comes across as sympathetic and convincing, his songs leave it up to listeners to decide what's really going on. Sometimes his narrators are genuinely affectionate or heartbroken; sometimes they're the weirdos who appear in "Creeps Like Me."

title: Decking the Screen With Lots of Savers
description: DEAR Santa,

title: U.N. Council Decides to Keep Economic Sanctions on Iraq
description: The Security Council maintained its economic sanctions against Iraq today after the United States provided evidence that President Saddam Hussein was spending lavishly on his own comforts while millions of Iraqis lacked food and medicine.

title: Furr's/Bishop's Inc.(CHI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Included special charge of $ 1.2 million for closing of a specialty restaurant in the quarter and 9 months.c-Included a special credit of $ 2.6 million from the reversal of liabilities accrued relative to two closed units whose leases were terminated in the quarter 9 months. The 9 months also included a charge of $ 2.4 million.(Loss)

title: Role Shifts For Central Bankers
description: For the world's central bankers, the stage these days may be smaller, but their role has become bigger.

title: Revived Stereotype of Hollywood Jews Abounds in Ironies; Anecdote in Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Filene's Basement Corp.(BSMT,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After an extraordinary charge on debt repurchase of $ 107,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 2,312,000, or 11 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 1,000,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Henry A. Brachtl, Securities Lawyer, 50
description: Henry A. Brachtl, a Manhattan securities lawyer and a former assistant United States Attorney, died on Monday at his home in Old Greenwich, Conn. He was 50.

title: In House and Senate, 2 Kinds of G.O.P.
description: When they were in opposition, Senate and House Republicans sounded pretty much alike in their complaints. When they won last Tuesday, they sang in jubilation from the same page, promising a diminished Federal Government.

title: Clinton Defends Halting Arms Embargo Enforcement
description: President Clinton today offered his first public defense of his decision to order the American military to stop enforcing the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government, a step that has alarmed American allies.

title: Bishops' Leader Warns Against 'Punitive' Welfare Cuts
description: Even as Representative Newt Gingrich, the incoming Speaker of the House, is proposing to drastically scale back welfare payments and have charities and orphanages assume greater responsibility for the poor, the head of the nation's Roman Catholic Bishops conference warned today against "punitive welfare provisions" that would harm families and children.

title: Fairchild Corp.(FA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 25,000.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 29,000 and after net charges of $ 10,950,000, or 68 cents a share, for changes in accounting which consisted of $ 8,015,000, or 50 cents a share, for a change in accounting for postretirement benefits and $ 2,935,000, or 18 cents a share, for a change in accounting for income taxes.The company said first-quarter revenues from aerospace fasteners were $ 52,132,000 in fiscal 1995, up from $ 51,578,000 a year earlier. Industrial products revenues were $ 49,319,000 in the latest first quarter, up from $ 40,770,000 in year-ago period, and communications services revenues were $ 19,942,000, up from $ 18,143,000.(Loss)

title: G.P., Call City Hall
description: George Pataki owes Rudolph Giuliani a telephone call.

title: Sybase To Acquire Powersoft
description: Sybase Inc., a leader in software for managing corporate data bases, said today that it planned to acquire the Powersoft Corporation in a stock swap valued at more than $940 million.

title: Lessons Beyond 'The Bell Curve'
description: At a meeting of social scientists at the Harvard Business School last month, Richard Herrnstein's and Charles Murray's controversial book "The Bell Curve" came up. One group reported that in an earlier conversation they had thoroughly "trashed" it. Heads around the room nodded in approval. I asked the room at large -- about 20 people -- how many had actually read the book. Two raised their hands.

title: Ralphs Grocery Co. reports earnings for 12wks to Oct 9
Palestinian Police Rounding Up Radicals
description: Tensions between Islamic militants and Yasir Arafat's autonomy government rose sharply today when Palestinian authorities banned street protests and promised a sustained crackdown against radicals.

title: Executive Changes
description: ACORDIA INC., Indianapolis, a holding company for 22 operating units that provide insurance brokerage, managed-care administration and consulting services, named Frank C. Witthun to the new post of president and chief operating officer. AYDIN CORP., Horsham, Pa., appointed Donald Taylor president.

title: Odd Attack of Esthetics Strikes a Village of Castles
description: THE house that Frank Lloyd Wright designed blends in with the trees, no doubt as he intended. Other houses in Great Neck Estates are not quite as quiet.

title: Syms Corp.(SYM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHRONICLE
description: What better way to promote a pet cause than on a national television series?

title: 25 Minutes of Terror in San Francisco
description: About eight days ago, a 37-year-old drifter named Victor Boutwell told a relative, "You're gonna be surprised at what I'm going to do." The relative thought Mr. Boutwell was contemplating suicide.

title: Unilever (UN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars.The net income represented the net profit at constant 1993 exchange rates.The net profit at exchange rates current in each period for the latest periods were $ 694 million in the quarter and $ 1,702,000,000 in the 9 months, compared with $ 618 million and $ 1,643,000,000 in year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Top Admiral Striving to Preserve Size of Fleet
description: As the rivalry among the military services escalates, the Navy's top admiral is mounting a campaign against plans to shrink the fleet.

title: William A. Higinbotham, 84; Helped Build First Atomic Bomb
description: William A. Higinbotham, a physicist who developed electronic components for the first atomic bomb and then became a leading advocate of controlling nuclear weapons, died on Thursday at his home in Gainesville, Ga. He was 84.

title: Rutgers Point Guard Returns to Her Roots
description: A familiar name will be a new face in the backcourt for the Rutgers women's basketball team when it begins its season Tuesday night in a first-round Preseason Women's National Invitation Tournament game against Seton Hall.

title: Jules Masserman, 89, Leader Of Psychiatric Group, Is Dead
description: Dr. Jules H. Masserman, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who was a former president of the American Psychiatric Association and a former member of the Northwestern University medical school faculty, died on Nov. 6 at his home in Chicago. He was 89.

title: David Salomon, A Decorator, Is Dead at 45
description: David Salomon, one of the leading decorators of his generation, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 45.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League TEXAS RANGERS -- Announced they will not renew the contracts of Tom House, minor league pitching instructor, Toby Harrah, minor league batting instructor, Marty Stajduhar, major league physical therapist, Stan Cliburn, manager of Tulsa of the Texas League; Tommy Thompson, manager of Port Charlotte of the Florida State League, and Walt Williams, manager of Charleston of the South Atlantic League. Dismissed minor league coaches Randy Whisler, Marvin White, Darrin Garner, Allan Anderson, George Threadgill, and Lyle Yates.

title: Court Backs College Plan In Louisiana
description: In what might be the end of a 20-year legal battle over segregation in Louisiana's colleges and universities, a Federal judge today approved a plan that officials said would lessen racial imbalances in the state's higher education system.

title: Memorex Telex N.V. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included goodwill amortization of $ 31.3 million in the quarter and $ 62.6 million in the 6 months.c-Included goodwill amortization of $ 5.9 million in the quarter and $ 11.7 million in the 6 months.Year-ago periods' share earnings were not relevant due to the prepackaged plan of reorganization which was filed in February 1994 and became effective March 24, 1994.(Loss)

title: BIG EUROPEAN SEMICONDUCTOR MAKER PLANS OFFERING
description: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Europe's second-largest semiconductor company, said yesterday that it expected to raise $441 million to $483 million in an initial public offering. SGS-Thomson -- a joint venture between Thomson-CSF S.A. of Paris and Italy's state-owned Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale -- said it expected to sell 21 million shares in the offering. The chip maker will sell 13.65 million shares, or 65 percent of the offering, in the United States and Canada.

title: Bonds Surge On Advances By the Dollar
description: Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday on a strong dollar and gains in the futures market after an initial opening dip. Traders were waiting for the meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee today, with some adjusting of positions ahead of what many in the market expect will be the sixth increase in short-term interest rates by the Fed this year.

title: Cinemark USA Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the increase in revenue resulted from the addition of 112 screens since the third quarter of 1993.

title: Hindsight Offers Little Safety
description: After the Giants lost to the Arizona Cardinals, Coach Dan Reeves was in the shower thinking the game over. As coaches do, Reeves pondered what might have been. And the thing that continued to stick in his gut today was not a call he made, but one he didn't make.

title: Goody Guys Inc.(GGUY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Shawmut-Barclays Deal
description: The Shawmut National Corporation plans to buy Barclays Business Credit, the United States asset-based lending operation of Barclays Bank P.L.C.

title: Dwindling Salmon Spur West to Save Rivers
description: HOOK-JAWED, wild and still magnificent after its taxing and hazardous struggle up the Rogue River from the ocean 125 miles away, the big coho salmon was beginning to don his scarlet mating colors, just as his kind has done every November for thousands upon thousands of years. But far fewer fish than made the trip just a few years ago are being recorded these days by the video camera trained constantly on a narrow underwater passage through which all migrating salmon must pass to get around Gold Ray Dam.

title: Market Place; TV assets help Belo shine in dull times for newspaper stocks.
description: YOU don't hear much buzz these days at the A. H. Belo Corporation, the newspaper and broadcasting company in Dallas, about the latest multimedia gizmo or the information superhighway. Being a couple of hours' flying time away from both coasts seems to help.

title: Political Depression Hits Brunch Belt
description: What did you think of the election?

title: Tropical Storm Wreaks Havoc on Haiti, Killing at Least 75
description: Torrential rains that battered Haiti last weekend left at least 75 people dead, radio reports and officials said today. Roads and bridges were destroyed, neighborhoods flooded and houses swept away.

title: A Disillusioned State Gives Up on Democrats
description: Sometimes it is the little things that lead to big changes.

title: Judge Hands Two Setbacks To Lawyers For Simpson
description: In a setback to the lawyers defending O. J. Simpson against murder charges, the judge in the case today denied their request that evidence taken from Mr. Simpson's Ford Bronco be excluded from trial. He also rejected defense assertions that evidence helpful to Mr. Simpson's case had been lost because of police bungling.

title: Sea Containers Ltd.(SCRA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After payment of preferred dividends of $ 3,968,000, the net applicable to common shares was $ 13,200,000, in the quarter and after payment for preferred dividends of $ 11,906,000, the net applicable to common shares was $ 12,084,000, in the 9 months.c-After payment for preferred dividends of $ 4,005,000, the net applicable to common shares was $ 11,870,000, in the quarter and after payment for preferred dividends of $ 12,049,000, the net applicable to common shares was $ 21,685,000, in the 9 months.The company also has a stock ticker symbol of SCRB for its class B stock.

title: Hatch Falls From Plane On Takeoff
description: A cockpit emergency hatch flew off of an American Eagle commuter plane yesterday, seconds after takeoff from Kennedy International Airport, injuring no one but frightening 13 passengers and three crew members.

title: Graham May Go Back to Bench; Miller May Go
description: When teams win, there are few changes. Coaches don't tamper with the chemistry of a winner. Losing is different. To losing teams, changes are almost a part of daily life. And right now, the 3-7 Giants are on a seven-game losing streak. That's why there could be two drastic changes, one immediately and the other soon.

title: Goldman, Sachs to Let Investment Bankers Go
description: Amid its worst slump in recent memory, Goldman, Sachs & Company has begun laying off investment bankers, according to executives both inside and outside the firm.

title: Big Money Corrupts Politics, Absolutely
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Wilenski, Former U.N. Delegate, 55
description: Peter Wilenski, a former representative at the United Nations from Australia, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Sydney. He was 55 years old.

title: Clinton Promotes U.S.-North Korea Nuclear Agreement
description: In wide-ranging meetings with Asian and Pacific leaders, President Clinton sought on Monday to promote support for Washington's nuclear accord with North Korea and train the spotlight on America's more prominent role in the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Sampras Faces Challenge in First Round of ATP
description: If this is the sort of draw one gets for being No. 1, perhaps Pete Sampras should set his sights a little lower.

title: No Headline
description: "We in the church stand with the unborn and the undocumented, the poor and the vulnerable, the hungry and the homeless in defense of human rights and human life. Our advocacy does not fit ideological or partisan categories, for our witness is not politically correct, but unfailingly consistent." -- WILLIAM H. KEELER, Archbishop of Baltimore. [ A24:1. ]

title: Q&A
description: Frogs and Toads

title: 25 Films Added to National Registry
description: The Library of Congress added 25 films to the National Film Registry yesterday, including "The Manchurian Candidate," the original "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" and the Zapruder film of the John F. Kennedy assassination.

title: Monk-Austin Inc.(MK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income(Loss)Monk-Austin said that the loss in the latest quarter is primarily attributable to timing of tobacco shipments.Also, in July the government of Brazil implemented a new monetary policy affecting foreign currency translations and inflation. The company said as a result, it sustained a foreign exchange loss in Brazil of $ 2.8 million in the quarter.

title: By Design; Oriental Inspiration
description: "Orientalism," the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute exhibition opening next month, couldn't be more timely. A flavor of China is showing up in many collections. Jean-Paul Gaultier showed mandarin-inspired clothing for fall, and Richard Tyler and Todd Oldham used Chinese-patterned spring fabrics.

title: We Only Wanted to Scare You
