description: On the radio the morning after the election, I heard an interview with a teacher urging children not to be afraid to go to school. It was a disturbing way to learn that Proposition 187 -- the sweeping California statute that would deny health care and educational services to illegal aliens and facilitate their deportation -- had passed by a landslide.

title: To Remember Seed Caches, Bird Grows New Brain Cells
description: EVERY fall, when the trees of North America's forests shake themselves into bare brown bones, and the sky grows gray and surly, and the meadows offer little but brambles and shriveled berries, the little black-capped chickadee rises brilliantly to the challenges of a callous world.

title: Was There or Wasn't There a Pneumonic Plague Epidemic?
description: In September, Indian Government officials set off an international public health emergency by reporting an epidemic of pneumonic plague, the most dangerous form of plague, which is spread by coughing. Indians panicked and fled the areas where the disease had been reported. Tourists canceled trips to India and other countries imposed surveillance checks of passengers arriving at many airports from India and banned imports of goods from India.

title: Looking Back: All the Bustle Over Retro
description: People who enjoy the luxury of not being designers are the first to cry foul when retro arises on a runway. But the common view in fashion that there exists some amorphous "modern" idea of dress may be, in itself, a myth.

title: Trident NGL Holdings Inc.(NGL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income, which included extraordinary loss of $ 500,000 on retirement of debt.(Loss)

title: Ford in Negotiations for Pact On Electric Car Conversions
description: Like the look of a new Taurus or Windstar, but maybe not what comes out of the tailpipe? Then Ford will sell you one without a tailpipe -- or muffler, catalytic converter, engine, fuel pump or gas tank, for that matter. But only if you qualify.

title: COLLEGE SOCCER REPORT
description: N.C.A.A. Tournament

title: Liuski International Inc.(LSKI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIZ CLAIBORNE TO CUT TIES WITH BURMESE
description: Liz Claiborne Inc., one of the nation's largest apparel makers, has decided to stop making and buying apparel in Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, because of its authoritarian Government. Liz Claiborne buys goods from 40 countries, and the knits and woven apparel from Myanmar represent less than 1 percent of its volume, a company spokeswoman said. Its announcement would thus seem to be largely symbolic. Liz Claiborne does more business with China, which is also the subject of human rights complaints, but the company said it had no plans to examine its commitments there.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Fitness-Gear Units Are Sold to Bain Capital
description: In a $373 million deal, an investor group led by Bain Capital yesterday acquired the home-fitness-equipment and sports-medicine subsidiaries of Weider Health and Fitness, a closely held concern.

title: Solar Power, for Earthly Prices
description: The nation's largest natural gas company is betting $150 million that it can succeed where the Government has so far failed: producing solar power at rates competitive with those of energy generated from oil, gas and coal.

title: Times Names Book Editor
description: Charles McGrath, deputy editor of The New Yorker, has been named editor of The New York Times Book Review. His appointment, effective in March, was announced yesterday by Joseph Lelyveld, executive editor of The Times.

title: P.T.A. President Accused of Sexual Abuse
description: The president of a P.T.A. at an elementary school in Brooklyn was forced to resign five months after four girls accused him of molesting them in the school auditorium, officials said yesterday.

title: Back on Track at Seton Hall
description: Bryan Spoonire, the Seton Hall senior who made a costly wrong turn during Saturday's IC4A 10,000-meter cross-country race at Franklin Park in Boston, was notified yesterday that he will be allowed to compete in the Division I championships in Fayetteville, Ark., next week after all.

title: Bosnia's Cynical, Senseless War Is Over
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A 'Porgy and Bess' Direct From the Source Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts

title: Rhone Unit Focuses on Gene Drugs
description: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said yesterday that it had started a new division that would concentrate on the discovery, development and commercialization of drugs based on gene and cell therapies.

title: Physicists Strive To Create Atoms Of Antihydrogen From Antimatter
description: ANTIMATTER: the super fuel for driving spacecraft to the stars, the wonder annihilator that could make hydrogen bombs seem like firecrackers, the antistuff of antigalaxies inhabited by antipeople . . ..

title: Asia-Pacific Countries Near Agreement on Trade
description: Eighteen nations of the Asia and Pacific region were on the verge of a sweeping agreement to stimulate economic growth by seeking the removal of barriers to trade by 2020, senior officials said on Monday night.

title: POP
description: Many Voices in Harmony, Or a Musical Babel? S.O.B.'s

title: Corrections
description: A brief front-page report on Saturday, summarizing an article about Congressional Republicans' reactions to victory, referred imprecisely to automobiles used by Representative Newt Gingrich. The Cadillac in which he rode had been provided by a group he was addressing; he did not trade in his own car. Mr. Gingrich's comments are reported today on page B8.

title: Credibility of Carjacking Witness Is Debated
description: Lawyers for a Bronx premedical student accused of murder in a carjacking in January tried today to support his account that the murder was committed by a drug dealer named Dino. They called two witnesses who said they saw a tall, nattily dressed man on the day of the crime who could have been the shadowy figure.

title: Sides Break Bread; No Answers on Table
description: As the bitter National Hockey League lockout lurches through its seventh week, the canceled games are replaced by personal dinner meetings, big boardroom sessions and telephone conference calls.

title: Hot-Weather Marathon Concerns the Athletes
description: If anything can match the expected heat of the men's marathon at the 1996 Summer Olympics, it is the emotional parboiling of top American runners who are seething at the prospect of having to run 26.2 miles in the late-afternoon sauna of Atlanta.

title: Primark Corp.(PMK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses of $ 1,863,000 in the quarter and $ 2,351,000 in the 9 months, from discontinued operations.The net income and share earnings were before preferred dividends.Primark said that results for the latest nine months were hurt by a $ 20 million decline in TASC's contract with the Ballistic Missile Defense Organization due to a general reduction in federal spending for national missile defense.

title: Health Care and Hospital Chains; Small Institutions Choose Survival Over Independence
description: For 40 years, the volunteers of the women's auxiliary of the Schoharie County Memorial Hospital ran the hospital coffee shop. They divided themselves into 30 chapters named for gemstones -- Sapphire for the Methodist Church women, Crystal for teachers, Diamond for the wives of doctors and lawyers. Together, they kept the restaurant open six days a week, ran bake sales and antique shows in their spare time and raised hundreds of thousands of dollars to support the town's 70-bed pride and joy.

title: U.S. MIGHT ADMIT DETAINED CUBANS TO HELP CHILDREN
description: Facing intense pressure from Cuban-American groups, the Clinton Administration is leaning toward granting entry to Cuban families being held at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Station on the ground that holding children there month after month is inhumane.

title: Inphynet Medical Management Inc.(IMMI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Pro forma, because the company went public in August 1994.Year-ago 9 months' share earnings included a gain of 6 cents a share from the sale of a unit.

title: Pioneer Financial Services Inc.(PFS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included realized investment losses of $ 254,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 32,000 in the 9 months; both periods also included a pretax charge of $ 1.7 million due to the company's decision to make a $ 16.7 million adjustment to deferred acquisition costs and to a $ 15 million reduction in group medical claim reserves.

title: Court Reopens Demotion Case At City College
description: The United States Supreme Court today gave City College of New York a second chance to show that its demotion of the outspoken chairman of its black studies department did not violate the Constitution.

title: Martin to Go Pro
description: Pitt running back CURTIS MARTIN said yesterday that he would pass up a final year of eligibility and turn pro. Martin rushed for 1,132 yards last season and was leading the nation in rushing after a 251-yard game against Texas but badly sprained an ankle against Ohio University on Sept. 10 and hasn't played since. (AP)

title: METRO DIGEST
description: CITY COLLEGE DEMOTION CASE IS REOPENED

title: Proposed Budget Stirs Protest at Hearings
description: Dozens of college students, administrators and education advocates bitterly protested proposed budget cuts yesterday that they said would hurt education in New York City, as the City Council opened its public hearings on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to close a $1.1 billion budget gap.

title: COOKSON AND JOHNSON MATTHEY CONFIRM MERGER TALKS
description: The British materials and metals companies Cookson Group P.L.C. and Johnson Matthey P.L.C. confirmed yesterday that they were in friendly merger talks that could lead to the creation of a $4 billion company. A statement from Cookson, an electronic materials, ceramics and plastics company, said discussions were still at a "relatively early stage." If a merger takes place, job losses among the 20,000-strong combined work force are inevitable, analysts said.

title: Mercer Int'l.(MERCS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary income of $ 26.5 million, or $ 2.37 a share, in the quarter and $ 2.35 a share, in the 9 months, which is related to a German government supplement totaling $ 37.9 million for its pulp operations. The amount is included in revenue for the latest quarter and nine months. The latest 9 months' revenue also included additional supplements of $ 5.4 million.c-Included extraordinary income of $ 562,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 2,801,000, or 26 cents a share, in the 9 months, from extinguishment of debt.Year-ago periods were restated for changes in disclosures to sales and investments.

title: Thomson Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Some year-earlier figures have been restated.The company has a stock ticker symbol of TOC and is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Laying Odds on America's Soul
description: The most colorful character in Sam Shepard's elegiac new play "Simpatico" is a former bigwig in the California horse-racing world who has been forced through scandal to relocate and start life over under an assumed name. The man, once known as Simms (James Gammon), now calls himself Ames and holds down a low-echelon job with the Kentucky Racing Commission.

title: Nassau's Proposed Budget Freezes '95 Property Taxes
description: Less than two years after Nassau County was forced to borrow $65 million to close a budget gap, the County Executive today proposed a budget for 1995 that would freeze taxes for homeowners and cut taxes for some businesses.

title: Designs Inc.(DESI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included an accounting gain of $ 79,000, or 1 cent a share, from the adoption of SFAS 109.

title: Chess
description: In winning the United States Championship in Key West, Fla., in late October, Boris Gulko performed in close accord with every grandmaster's daydreams. The 47-year-old former Soviet champion, who lives in Fair Lawn, N.J., won with captivating combinations, trenchant tactics, precise positional play and excellently executed endgames. And when, in a rare case, he got himself into a dangerous situation, he cleverly crawled away unscathed.

title: 49ers' Hanks Still Has Work to Do
description: The running joke back at the Hanks home in Dallas was this: No, you didn't have to get a job, go to work, until you were, oh, 14 years old.

title: Goalie Is Charged
description: The English Football Association yesterday charged the former Liverpool goalkeeper BRUCE GROBBELAAR with accepting bribes to fix matches.

title: In Russia, Corruption Inflates the Cost of Dying
description: The Russian way of death would make anyone want to live forever.

title: American Israeli Paper Mills Ltd. (AIP,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rising Dollar Helps Dow Post Gain of 28.26
description: One day ahead of an important meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers, the stock market rallied yesterday, buoyed by a rising dollar that also lifted bond prices.

title: Interest Rate Illogic
description: To the Editor:

title: Raveling Resigns as Coach Of U.S.C., Citing Accident
description: Still recuperating from a car crash that hospitalized him for much of the autumn, George Raveling resigned today as the University of Southern California basketball coach. Raveling, 57, cited a low amount of energy as the determining factor.

title: Steelers Battering Has Bills Reeling
description: Then, that same defense became a spectacular scoring machine with two great individual plays by cornerback Rod Woodson which resulted in two Steeler touchdowns. It even came up with a blocked field goal when defensive end Brentson Bruckner deflected a 32-yard attempt by Bills kicker Steve Christie with 13 minutes 54 seconds to play.

title: OfficeMax Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 22
description: b-Net lossThe share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma figures reflecting the company's November 1994 initial public offering as if it occurred Jan. 23, 1993.(Loss)

title: ADT Ltd. (ADT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 3,300,000, or 2 cents a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,500,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 800,000 in the 9 months.

title: DANCE
description: Painters and Gertrude Stein Provide the Inspiration Merce Cunningham Studio

title: Making China Trade Fairly
description: China desperately wants to qualify as a founding member of the World Trade Organization. President Clinton obstinately stands in the way -- which is exactly where he belongs.

title: Patterns
description: Swimsuits Mom Never Knew

title: A Cyberspace Atlas: America Online
description: AMERICA ONLINE, the second stop on our virtual tour of cyberspace, is the most ambitious and aggressive of the popular online information services. It is impressive and infuriating in nearly equal measures.

title: Lucy S. Morgan, 93, Adviser to W.H.O.
description: Dr. Lucy Shields Morgan, a groundbreaking educator in public health and an adviser to the World Health Organization, died on Friday at the Deerfield Episcopal Retirement Center in Asheville, N.C. She was 93.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Off the Menu column of The Living Section last Wednesday about the formation of a catering company by Daniel Boulud and Jean-Christophe Le Picart referred incorrectly to Mr. Le Picart's previous catering concern, Tentation. It is still in business, under the name Tentation, Potel & Chabot, owned by Potel & Chabot, a Parisian catering company.

title: The Sanchez Express Halted By Halard
description: When the match was finally over and the upset had fully registered in the victor's mind, Julie Halard, a Parisian pixie ranked 22d in the world, sat down and stared down at her racquet as if she could not fathom what it had just done for her.

title: Sports of The Times; Beard Gets A Lesson In the Nets
description: ONE night last week in Landover, Md., one Alfred (Butch) Beard blew his top, which was unusual only in that Mr. Beard is a man of normally gentle mien. The circumstances make a point that goes to the heart of the matter. Mr. Beard, of course, is the rookie coach of what for want of a better term is called a basketball team. It is the New Jersey Nets basketball team, which explains why even someone like Mr. Beard might find occasion to go bananas.

title: Fed Move to Raise Rates Expected Today
description: Despite the likelihood of unusually strong public criticism, the Federal Reserve appears poised to raise short-term interest rates on Tuesday for the sixth time this year.

title: SALEM REJECTS OFFER FROM HARBOUR GROUP INVESTMENTS
description: The Salem Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected an acquisition offer from Harbour Group Investments III L.P., saying the terms of a breakup fee and exclusive negotiating rights were restrictive and not in the best interest of shareholders. Salem, a Pittsburgh-based furnace and finishing equipment maker, said that Victor Posner, the financier, had also expressed an interest in acquiring all of its stock outstanding at the price offered by Harbour or better. Salem said it had also turned down Mr. Posner's offer because it did not contain definitive terms. Mr. Posner now owns 49 percent of the company's shares. Salem's stock slipped 12.5 cents, to $16.50. Harbour Group made its offer Nov. 1.

title: Tyson Foods Inc.(TYSNA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included special charges equaled to $ 1.38 a share to write down goodwill and impaired asset values of Arctic Alaska Fisheries Corp.c-Included one-time charge of $ 9 million for additional deferred income tax accruals and $ 1.6 million of retroactive income taxes due to an increase in the federal income tax rate.d-Net income(Loss)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bosnia Army Retreating in North As Serbs Press Attack, U.N. Says
description: Nationalist Serbs have forced Bosnian Government fighters to withdraw from about 60 percent of the territory they recaptured two weeks ago near Bihac, in the northwest, United Nations officials here said today.

title: Dr. C. Andrew L. Bassett, 70, Professor of Orthopedic Surgery
description: Dr. C. Andrew L. Bassett, a New York orthopedic surgeon whose work led to faster healing of broken bones, died yesterday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 70.

title: Earthquakes as Just a Fact of Life
description: Looking for another reason not to live in Los Angeles? It's available tonight on "Nova." The horror-movie title, "Killer Quake!," tells the story.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies Sybase agreed to acquire Powersoft in a $940 million stock swap. The deal would create the world's seventh-largest software company and give Sybase control of the leading maker of development tools for client-server computing. [ Page D1. ]

title: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc.(AAL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations associated with an agreement in principle to resolve certain indemnity obligations to the Sphere Drake Insurance Group of $ 20.9 million, or 47 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 26.9 million, or 61 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Net income and included a gain from cumulative effect of accounting change of $ 3,300,000, or 8 cents a share.Revenue represented operating revenues.(Loss)

title: Lost Period Results in Lost Game For Knicks
description: It was the Knicks' worst offensive drought of the young season, and it came at a most inopportune time.

title: You'd Hardly Know Cuba's Open for Business; A Shirt for Every Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Coleman Gets Spotted On After-Hours Scene
description: Derrick Coleman stayed after practice today to work on his shooting and it immediately evolved into the saucy development of the day at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: For Pataki, the Adirondacks Before the Deluge
description: So where does the Governor-elect unwind after 13 months of subsisting on cold pizza, giving the same speech four times a day and stuffing his 6-foot-5 frame into four-seater planes? A tropical paradise? Some posh European resort?

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Isaac Stern Celebrates A Brooklyn Anniversary Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts

title: Busch Tells Longtime Shop: This Bud's for You No More
description: It's last call for one of the longest relationships in advertising. Anheuser-Busch Inc. startled Madison Avenue yesterday by unexpectedly dismissing the St. Louis office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which has served as the sole agency for its flagship Budweiser beer brand since 1915.

title: CHRONICLE
description: From the religious frescoes of the Italian Renaissance to product logos and restaurant design might seem a huge artistic leap, but the graphic designer MILTON GLASER has made it a round trip.

title: Fairchild Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $ 11,738,000 for changes in accounting for income taxes and postretirement benefits.Fairchild Industries is a unit of Fairchild Corp.

title: Creating a Republican Wave, Then Riding It In
description: Until last week, he was best known as the husband of Susan Molinari, the Republican Representative from Staten Island. But now Bill Paxon has an independent claim to fame. As chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, he was one of the chief architects of the political coup that put Republicans in charge of the House of Representatives.

title: S.E.C. Is Reviewing Nasdaq Market
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced this evening that it had begun a review of the Nasdaq stock market's general compliance with Federal regulations.

title: Observer; The Final Analysis
description: The most interesting explanation of the famous Republican triumph comes from my wife, who is not political and whose mind, therefore, has not been ossified by total immersion in polling statistics.

title: Flood of Rwanda Refugees Is Destroying Ecological Treasure
description: AT first light, the lines of humanity are already snaking across the fields of tall grass and stumps, heading into the forests of Virunga National Park. Throughout the day people straggle back out, their bounty balanced on their heads -- here a child with a bundle of sticks, there a man with a thick log, women struggling under remarkably heavy loads.

title: The Mess at Youth Services
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has created a special task force to examine allegations of mismanagement at New York City's Department of Youth Services. It will incorporate an investigation already started by the city's Department of Investigation. A separate City Council investigation also continues. These probes are aimed at determining what went wrong at the agency, which has been in disarray for months, and how it can be fixed.

title: Jets Must Earn Stars Without the Stripes
description: In their 35th year, the Jets may have figured it out: Don't leave something as important as the outcome of a football game up to someone in a striped shirt.

title: Ross Stores Inc.(ROST,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included after-tax income of about $ 6.2 million, or 25 cents a share, from insurance proceeds, in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Indonesia's Embarrassment
description: Indonesia is the world's fourth most populous country. It is a diverse society, rich in both culture and natural resources and eager to take a respected place in the community of nations. So it is appropriate that the Indonesian city of Bogor is hosting the informal summit of the newly formed Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation alliance.

title: Woman Says Jar Contained Crack
description: Federal food and drug officials and the police yesterday were investigating a report by a Washington Heights woman who said she found 32 vials of crack cocaine in a sealed jar of Hellmann's mayonnaise bought at a local supermarket on Sunday. No product recall was ordered, and there were no indications that other jars were tainted.

title: Amid Turmoil, Legal Aid Names New Top Executive
description: With its future darkened both by deep budget cuts and a possible loss in status as the city's chief legal representative of the poor, the Legal Aid Society announced yesterday the appointment of a new top administrator, the first change in that position in nearly 20 years.

title: Canadian Fracmaster reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: International Family Entertainment Inc.(FAM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
What It Will Take to Make Russia Capitalist
description: To the Editor:

title: Tenacity Solves an Ugly Bankruptcy
description: When people talk about Integrated Resources, the nationwide real estate syndication firm that filed for bankruptcy almost five years ago, only a few observations will not draw a big argument.

title: Trying New Ways to Save Decaying Parks
description: City and community leaders gathered in 1986 to break ground on the Underhill Playground in Prospect Heights in Brooklyn. A brass band played, children sang and Mayor Edward I. Koch proclaimed, "One million dollars is a lot of money and we'll be getting a lot of playground for our money."

title: Los Angeles Sports Entrepreneur Charged With Fraud
description: Bruce P. McNall, part-owner and president of the Los Angeles Kings hockey team, was charged by Federal prosecutors today with defrauding banks to obtain millions of dollars in loans.

title: You'd Hardly Know Cuba's Open for Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Cairo Journal; Novelist's Unwitting Role: Sword Against Militants
description: Naguib Mahfouz, a Nobel Prize-winning author, has been dragged from his hospital bed into a debate about religion, freedom of expression and the interpretation of a novel he wrote that was banned in Egypt for 35 years.

title: LOCKHEED TO GET $1.3 BILLION FOR F-16 JET PROJECT
description: The Lockheed Corporation is getting $1.3 billion from the Air Force so the company can move toward the completion of F-16 jet fighters destined for Korea. The money is being awarded under a foreign military sales transaction announced on July 8, 1991. It will allow Lockheed's operation in Fort Worth to build 12 F-16's, and provide another 36 F-16 kits. Korea will assemble the kits when it takes delivery, which is expected by September 1996. The Air Force is acting as the middleman for the deal under foreign military sales regulations. Korea sent the money to the United States Treasury, which then transferred it to accounts to which the Air Force had access.

title: APS Holding Corp.(APSI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-Net loss and included $ 1.2 million nonrecurring charge for recognition of compensation expense under a stock appreciation rights plan resulting from its September 1993 initial offering in both the quarter and 9 months; a charge $ 2,330,000 of change in accounting for postretirement benefits and a tax benefit of $ 13.4 million, or 98 cents a share, due to an expected acceleration of its ability to utilize its available net operating loss carryforwards.(Loss)

title: Joseph H. Hazen, 96, Is Dead; Lawyer and Movie Producer
description: Joseph H. Hazen, a retired lawyer, film producer, art collector and philanthropist, died on Sunday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 96..

title: Fed Move Sends Stocks on Roller Coaster
description: Stock traders had clamored for strong inflation-fighting medicine but swooned when they got it yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average initially plummeted almost 50 points after the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates by a surprisingly large three-quarters of a percentage point.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT CORP., Atlanta, completed the purchase of most of the assets of Western Union Financial Services Inc. from New Valley Corp., Upper Saddle River, N.J., in a transaction valued at $1.19 billion. GENERAL ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS INC., a unit of General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., signed a $250 million contract with Tenaga Nasional Berhad, a Malaysian utility, to supply power generation equipment for a plant in Kapar, Selangor, Malaysia.

title: Enthusiasm Is Lacking During the Knicks' Trip
description: The Knicks have not played their first five games with the intensity that has become their signature. So before today's practice at the Forum, Coach Pat Riley met with the team briefly and voiced his displeasure, followed by a hard, 90-minute workout.

title: NATO Keeps Bosnia Arms Blockade as U.S. Drops Role
description: Washington's allies in NATO said today that they would continue a sea blockade of arms shipments to the Muslim-led Bosnian Government even though American forces are no longer fully taking part.

title: Waban Inc.(WBN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After a gain of $ 905,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Cortines May Seize District
description: Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines yesterday summoned the board of Brooklyn's largest school district to a meeting on Monday, a move that could lead to his seizing control of the troubled district.

title: Kohl Elected to 4th Term as German Chancellor, but by a Hair
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl was officially elected to a fourth term today, but members of Parliament gave him only a single vote more than the required majority, suggesting that his new Government may be weak and perhaps short-lived.

title: Personal Health; Clinical trials: the bogged-down hub of progress.
description: THIRTY-ODD years ago when I became a science and health writer, cancer treatment was a hit-or-miss affair that relied mostly on surgery and mop-up radiation therapy. Only a handful of children with acute leukemia and only about a quarter of children with solid tumors survived. Women dreaded breast cancer not only for its life-threatening implications but also because the diagnosis inevitably meant mutilating surgery: a radical mastectomy.

title: Bulls Are Victors in Spain
description: The giant metallic bulls along Spain's highways will be protected from bulldozers under a decree approved today by a parliamentary commission.

title: Seymour Malman; Developer, 76
description: Seymour Malman, a retired Long Island developer, died on Friday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 76 and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: AT THE MOVIES WITH: Paul Rudnick; Would Libby, Like, Even Read This?
description: DOES Libby like "Stargate"? You bet. Big time. No need to ask, really. How could a movie in which Kurt Russell kicks keister among the ancient Egyptians at the far end of the universe fail to enchant Libby Gelman-Waxner, the monthly film critic for Premiere magazine and the finest judge of cinematic art ever to come out of Great Neck, L.I.?

title: Who Gets No. 1 Job? A Riddle For Reeves
description: When the Giants won their first three games this season, their quarterback was Dave Brown. When they lost their next six, their quarterback was still Dave Brown. When they lost by a point Sunday to the Arizona Cardinals, their quarterback was Kent Graham.

title: TRW AND TELEGLOBE PLAN SATELLITE PHONE PROJECT
description: TRW Inc. and Teleglobe Inc. said yesterday that they would lead a 12-company satellite partnership that would in effect put a telephone company in orbit. The announcement included the first details about the way TRW planned to finance the $2.5 billion Odyssey system. Odyssey will use 12 satellites to provide wireless voice, fax and paging to mobile telephone subscribers worldwide. TRW and Teleglobe, a Canadian maker of data communications equipment, said they would jointly invest 15 percent of the equity. They did not disclose the financial contributions of the other companies. TRW, based in Cleveland, said it needed to attract more telecommunications companies as partners to help finance the system.

title: Frederic Spiegelberg, Religion Teacher, 97
description: Frederic Spiegelberg, an early teacher of comparative religion in the United States, died on Thursday at the California Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco, where he lived. He was 97.

title: Mystery Solved
description: To The Living Section:

title: Preseason N.I.T. Tipping Off
description: Nobody needs to remind Jack Powers that ranking teams before they've played a single game can be a fatuous exercise, but as the executive director of the Preseason National Invitation Tournament, Powers, at least, didn't have a choice.

title: Tele-Communications Inc.(TCOMA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss(Loss)The share earnings are after payment of preferred dividends.

title: World News Briefs; Khmer Rouge Admit Killing Western Tourists
description: The Khmer Rouge admitted today that they had executed three backpacking Western tourists whose bodies were found in a shallow grave in southern Cambodia earlier this month.

title: Leslie Fay Cos. Inc.(LES,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-After reorganization costs of $ 17,595,000 in the quarter and $ 30,645,000 in the 9 months.c-After reorganization costs of $ 7,312,000 and $ 23,787,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.The reorganization costs in the latest quarter included a one-time charge of $ 10 million for the previously announced discontinuance of the company's theomiles lines of ''better'' women's apparel.Leslie Fay said that sales for the latest quarter were significantly impacted by a six-week strike at all of its domestic manufacturing and distribution facilities by the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union. The strike began June 1 and ended July 15.The lower sales in the 1994 third quarter also reflected the closing of the Spitalnick division in the third quarter of 1993 and the closing of the HUE division and licensing of the HUE trademark at the end of 1993, as well as lackluster consumer demand at the retail level in all women's apparel categories.The quarterly results were comprised of 13 weeks each, and the 9 months' results each had 39 weeks.Sales represented net sales.(Loss)

title: Hoechst Celanese Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Hoechst Celanese, a unit of Hoechst AG, said its performance in the latest third quarter was helped by the strengthening economy and its efforts to invest in strategic growth areas and reduce costs.

title: Clinton Aide Criticizes G.O.P. Plans for Tax Cuts
description: President Clinton's budget director said today that it was nonsense for Republicans to suggest that tax cuts would pay for themselves by stimulating economic activity. The director insisted that such cuts had to be offset by reductions in Federal spending.

title: America Embraces Its Native Foods
description: The Thanksgiving menu springs from the soil of the Americas. The sentimental favorites are cranberries, corn, squash, pumpkins, pecans, wild rice, sweet potatoes and turkey. But now the shopping list of foods native to the New World is expanding.

title: REGULATORS DENY G.M. REQUEST ON PICKUP HEARING
description: Federal regulators denied a request yesterday from the General Motors Corporation to go directly to court in a dispute about the safety of millions of older G.M. pickups. The Department of Transportation said it would hold a public hearing on Dec. 6. G.M. had asked the agency to call off the hearing. At issue are all full-sized Chevrolet and GMC pickups made from 1973 to 1987. In a ruling last month, Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena found that the trucks, with side-mounted fuel tanks, could leak when struck from the side, and may have caused the deaths of 150 people. In a statement yesterday, G.M. said Mr. Pena was "fundamentally wrong" and had a "closed mind." The Department said hearings "serve the important function of helping to further inform the department of additional relevant factual and legal matters."

title: Long-Bond Yield Dips After Fed's Tightening
description: The long end of the Treasury market rallied yesterday after the Federal Reserve announced its sixth and largest interest rate increase of the year, easing traders' fears of inflation.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: Familiar Texas Tales, Told With Sarcasm Bottom Line

title: The Pleasures of Craft, Honesty and Intelligence
description: THE POST OFFICE MURALS RESTORED By Robert B. Shaw 80 pages. Copper Beech Press. $11. THANKSGIVING OVER THE WATER By Stephen Sandy 83 pages. Knopf. $11. THE GREEN LAKE IS AWAKE By Joseph Ceravolo 131 pages. Coffee House Press. $11.95

title:
COMPANY REPORTS;
Big Expansion Is Planned for Target Stores
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation said yesterday that it would invest $1.3 billion next year on capital expansion, with the largest share expected to accelerate growth of its Target discount stores.

title: Ralston Sells Feed Unit
description: The Ralston Purina Company said today it had signed a letter of intent to sell its international animal-feed operations to the PM Holdings Corporation for an undisclosed amount. The sale is part of Ralston's plan to focus on pet food and batteries. Earlier this year, it spun off businesses including Chex cereal and the Breckenridge ski resort as Ralcorp Holdings.

title: Consolidated Stores Corp.(CNS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Leaderless Orpheus Finds Singularity in Plurality Carnegie Hall

title: Angolan Foes Sign a Truce in Step Toward a Formal Peace
description: Leaders of the rival armies that have mauled Angola for 19 years signed a truce tonight, promising that in 24 hours they would stop fighting the last war in southern Africa.

title: P.& G. PLANS PRICE CHANGES ON SOME PAPER PRODUCTS
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would raise the prices of its Charmin toilet tissue, Bounty paper towels and Puffs tissues because of higher pulp prices. The company will reduce its price per diaper of Luvs by 11 percent and of Pampers by 2 percent, to narrow the gap with lower-priced competitors. P.& G., based in Cincinnati, said it would increase Charmin prices by 5 percent, Bounty prices by 6 percent and Puffs prices by 8 percent. Pulp is a significant part of P.& G.'s raw material cost for tissues and towels, a P.& G. spokesman said. He declined to be more specific.

title: Death Made Too Easy
description: Until Oregon voters approved a law last week that permitted physicians to prescribe lethal medication for terminally ill people, physician-assisted suicide had been forbidden in every state. In the very near future, all these remaining state prohibitions may be swept away as a result of constitutional challenges pending in lawsuits around the nation.

title: Space Telescope Leaves Scientists Puzzled About the Mass of the Universe
description: The Hubble Space Telescope looked deep into the sky and what it did not see has left cosmologists more mystified than ever about the unseen stuff out there, called dark matter, that may account for at least 90 percent of the universe's mass.

title: Ameridata Technologies Inc.(ADA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHRONICLE
description: ARTHUR LEVINE, who will be inaugurated as the ninth president of Teachers College at Columbia University tomorrow, took a field trip yesterday to his old elementary school, P.S. 79, at 180th Street and Creston Avenue in the South Bronx.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Kohl's Corp.(KSS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Wine Talk
description: TRADITIONALLY, Thanksgiving marks the beginning of the holiday season. Unless you are a Beaujolais devotee. For fans of France's favorite wine, the fun begins tomorrow, the third Thursday of November, the day this very special wine, the first of the new vintage, goes on sale.

title: World News Briefs; 8 Algerian Militants Slain in Escape Attempt
description: Eight people were killed and 60 were wounded on Monday when Government forces put down an escape attempt by Muslim militants on death row in Algeria, an Algerian newspaper reported today.

title: Moscow Journal; Historian Looks Darkly at Russia, and Sees Light
description: One of Russia's most penetrating democratic voices, Yuri N. Afanasyev, has by his desk a bronze statue of Diogenes, lantern lifted, searching for a single honest man. It is an obvious analogy for these times of moral improvisation in Russia, when so many officials and businessmen are seeking personal advantage to the detriment of a still-weak public spirit.

title: Commuter Airlines Need Tougher Rules, Panel Says
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that commuter airline pilots fly more hours than major-carrier pilots but receive less training, less help on safety issues, less help from ground personnel and less rest between flights.

title: Seton Hall Edges Rutgers as Women's N.I.T. Kicks Off
description: The college basketball season opened tonight with the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: K-III Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 11.9 million from a write-off of unamortized deferred financing costs.Sales represented net sales.K-III's preferred stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol of KCC.

title: Arrest of Released Sex Offender Unnerves New England Region
description: Despite police warnings that he remained a "chronic sexual predator," Ronald W. Caron was released from jail here eight days ago, then arrested on Monday amid concern that he was returning to his old patterns of behavior.

title: News Staff Faces Layoffs At Journal
description: The Wall Street Journal told more than a dozen members of its news staff yesterday that they would be laid off as part of a cost-cutting move, the newspaper's managing editor said in an interview.

title: Guidelines For Classes On Civics Are Issued
description: National educational standards for civics and government were announced today, provoking less criticism than did the recently unveiled standards for American and world history.

title: INSIDE
description: With or Without U.S., Allies Will Blockade Bosnia Arms

title: Without a Date, It Will Be Pretty Hard Setting a Curfew
description: So what exactly is the date to announce the cancellation of the National Hockey League season?

title: New Look at Disputed Study Is Reassuring on Lumpectomy
description: Women who have breast cancer that has not spread outside the breast can almost always safely choose a lumpectomy followed by radiation rather than a mastectomy, researchers concluded at a workshop here today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Pastrami on Rye, Hold the West Coast
description: Seeking the solace of salami and the balm of brisket amid the aftershocks of the 1993 earthquake, a long line of people gathered outside Nate 'n Al's, the venerable show-biz delicatessen here. When some customers grew antsy at the wait, a counterman reminded them that they had a choice: they could always go down the block to the Carnegie Deli.

title: Stopping Sex Abuse in Schools
description: Sexual abuse of children is one of those issues that easily leads to overreaction. All the more reason to welcome sensible recommendations from a special commission on how the New York City school system should handle child sex abuse.

title: Stephen Dykes Bower, 91, Architect
description: Stephen Dykes Bower, a British church architect skilled in the Gothic style, died on Friday in Quendon, 20 miles north of London. He was 91 and lived in Quendon.

title: New Judge In a Crucial Tobacco Case
description: A Federal judge in New Orleans reassigned a much-watched tobacco-liability case to another Federal judge yesterday, postponing a crucial hearing scheduled for today on a landmark class-action lawsuit. The court will determine whether, for the first time, the tobacco industry can be sued for addicting huge numbers of smokers to cigarettes.

title: Watch Your Thoughts in Gingrich's Land; I Wish Him Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Notes
description: Dial 'T' for Turkey

title: 2 Officers Are Acquitted of Assault on a Prisoner
description: Two New York City police officers were acquitted yesterday of assault charges in a case in which they were accused of causing a prisoner to become a virtual quadriplegic by slamming him violently into a station house door.

title: Banesto Criminal Charges
description: Spanish prosecutors filed charges today against Mario Conde, the dismissed chairman of the Banco Espanol de Credito, and nine of his executives, formally accusing them with misappropriating funds, manipulating stock prices and falsifying documents.

title: Running Game Puts Jets Into Big First-Down Rut
description: Coach Pete Carroll believes that in order for the Jets to be successful, they have to establish their running game, something they have had trouble doing this season.

title: Tiffany & Co. (TIF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss, which was after a net charge $ 32.7 million, or $ 2.07 a share, in the second quarter as part of the realignment of the company's business in Japan. Before the charge, Tiffany & Co. had year-ago nine months net of $ 4,455,000, or 28 cents a share.(Loss)Year-ago 9 months' sales were before product return totaling $ 115 million from Japan realignment.

title: Pollsters Say Health Care Helped Sweep Away Democrats
description: Candidates may not have talked much about health care in the 1994 campaign, but some leading pollsters suggested today that the bitter 18-month-long struggle over the issue was crucial in stoking the attitudes at the heart of last week's election: anger, cynicism and disappointment with the Democrats.

title: No Headline
description: "I am not sounding the alarm on tax cuts per se. I am saying that tax cuts must be paid for. Tax cuts without spending cuts would increase the budget deficit and would be an irresponsible thing to do." ALICE M. RIVLIN, the Federal Budget Director. [ A16:5. ]

title: Bumper Crops Pose Political Problem for Farmers
description: The nation's farmers have been reaping their most bountiful harvest ever in many important crops, benefiting shoppers for groceries from meat to cooking oil but costing taxpayers an estimated $3 billion to $4 billion in additional farm subsidies.

title: BUFFETT MAY WRITE DOWN HIS HOLDINGS IN USAIR
description: The investor Warren E. Buffett may write down the value of his investment in USAir Group Inc. this year if the airline fails to move forward with a cost-reduction plan. Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the holding company in Omaha controlled by Mr. Buffett, would take a fourth-quarter charge to cover the write-down, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Buffett's investment in USAir consists of cumulative convertible preferred stock purchased for $358 million in 1989. The shares are convertible into 9.2 million common shares. Shares of USAir rose 12.5 cents, to $4.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. USAir and its unions have agreed to resume talks about reducing costs.

title: 3 Enterprising Women: Bright Lights of the City
description: THREE women, three stories.

title: Fox May Propose Series of Tournaments
description: The Fox Television Network, already involved in professional football and -- if the season begins -- professional hockey, may be attempting to step into golf in a big way.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Kmart Corp., Troy, Mich., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $180 million of pass-through certificates through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: President-Elect In Brazil Aided By State Races
description: In victories likely to strengthen the free-market mandate of President-elect Fernando Henrique Cardoso, the governors' seats in Brazil's three most powerful states went to his allies today, according to preliminary returns and voter surveys.

title: ITT TO FORM AUTO PARTS VENTURE FOR CHINESE MARKET
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it would form a joint venture with the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation to make brake parts and wheel cylinders for the Chinese automotive market. ITT, the diversified manufacturing and services company based in New York, said it would own 40 percent of the new company. The joint venture will initially employ more than 150 people and produce 400,000 brake calipers and 600,000 wheel cylinders a year. The company will operate in a new plant near Shanghai. Production is to begin early next year.

title: Prison Inmates Stage Dining Room Protest
description: About 2,500 of the 15,000 Rikers Island inmates refused to eat lunch and dinner yesterday, apparently to protest conditions at the prison and to show their anger over possible operational changes, correction officials said.

title: Opera, Yes, And More From Ebony
description: Since 1974, Opera Ebony has been presenting minority singers in low-budget but inventive productions in Harlem, on tour and, lately, as part of the 651 series at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It has offered an interesting repertory of mostly contemporary American works, particularly operas by minority composers or about aspects of black history. And it has just released its first compact disk, "Done Crossed Every River" (Arcadia).

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 BOSNIA EMBARGO AFFIRMED Even though American forces are no longer fully taking part, Washington's allies in NATO said they would continue a sea blockade of arms shipments to Bosnia's Muslim-led Government. A3 A STRATEGY TO AVERT WARS President Clinton will join allies in Budapest next month to sign an accord aimed at helping European and former Soviet-bloc countries resolve conflicts before they lead to war, officials said. A3

title: Singapore Questions American's Actions
description: To the Editor:

title: Bills to Lift 3-Casino Limit Clear Panels in Legislature
description: Mayor James Whelan's protestations that enough is enough fell on deaf ears today as two legislative committees released identical bills that would enable Donald Trump to seek his fourth casino license here.

title: The Fed's Moves: How Consumer Rates React
description: Six times this year, the Federal Reserve has increased short-term interest rates, trying to brake the economy, including a 0.75-percent jump yesterday. Some rates that consumers earn or pay have reacted sharply and promptly; others have shrugged off the Fed's moves.

title: When a Tax Resembles a Salary Cap
description: Anyone deliriously optimistic about the so-called breakthrough in negotiations in the three-month-old baseball strike hasn't been paying attention to the negotiations in the month-and-a-half-old hockey lockout. The National Hockey League has a taxing problem, and baseball is about to get one, too.

title: As It Scrubs Down Its Art, Rome Takes The Brush to Itself
description: Nowadays, when you stand on the Campidoglio, Michelangelo's piazza atop the Capitoline Hill, you can clearly see the cleaned corkscrew dome of Sant'Ivo della Sapienza, which Borromini designed, rising among the city's rooftops. The spanking white facades of San Andrea della Valle and the Church of the Gesu punctuate the gritty Corso Vittorio Emanuele, the busy street leading from the bridge over the Tiber to the Vatican. Across town, the exterior of the giant Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore has been thoroughly scrubbed. Inside, its patterned floor, medieval mosaics, delicate wood-coffered ceiling and voluminous chapels have been given the once-over, too.

title: Democrat Gets Nearer Top Job In Maryland
description: Parris N. Glendening, the Democratic candidate for Governor of Maryland, moved a step closer to victory today when the state election board finished counting absentee ballots and said he had 6,064 more votes than his Republican challenger, Ellen R. Sauerbrey.

title: W.B.C. Planning Ban of California Bouts
description: The world's biggest boxing authority announced yesterday that it would stop sanctioning world title fights in California because of what it termed racist measures against illegal immigrants recently approved by California voters.

title: Lumber and Copper Prices Soar While Coffee Plunges
description: Lumber rose to its highest price in two months yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as demand from home builders stays strong even as interest rates go up.

title: Precious Ingredients
description: To The Living Section:

title: Aikman's Injury Draws N.F.L.'s Attention
description: The Dallas Cowboys did nothing wrong by not immediately reporting quarterback TROY AIKMAN's thumb injury to the National Football League, the team owner, JERRY JONES, said yesterday. The N.F.L. is reviewing whether the Cowboys violated policy in not reporting that Aikman was hurt last Friday in a closed workout. Aikman missed the last two plays of practice.

title: Sir Patrick Dean of Britain, 85, Envoy to U.N. and Washington
description: Sir Patrick Dean, who was Britain's representative at the United Nations from 1960 to 1964 and Ambassador to the United States from 1965 to 1969, died on Nov. 5 in Kingston in the English county of Surrey. He was 85 and lived in London.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: Reindeer and Rockettes Are in Residence Again Radio City Music Hall

title: Hughes Supply (HUG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the At the Bar column on Friday, about American lawyers who are helping to shape the legal system in Albania, referred to one of them incorrectly. Donn Rubin of Washington is a man.

title: Recount Shows Rep. Gejdenson Wins in Connecticut by 4 Votes
description: After seven days of counting and recounting, Sam Gejdenson, a seven-term Democratic Congressman from eastern Connecticut, was declared the victor today in his bid for re-election -- by four votes out of 186,000 cast. But his Republican opponent, Edward W. Munster, vowed to challenge the results of the Second District vote all the way, if necessary, to the new Republican-controlled Congress, which has the final say in the seating of its members.

title: Libel Suit Against Prodigy Tests On-Line Speech Limits
description: The Prodigy Services Company, operator of one of the country's largest on-line information services, has agreed to help track down a computer user who posted an electronic message accusing a Long Island investment bank of fraud and other criminal activity.

title: A Chinese-Italian Effort
description: THE Chinese and the Italians have been making culinary marriages since Marco Polo brought noodles from China. This dish joins the two cultures once more. To cool the spiciness of the sauce, try a yogurt salad with carrot and cucumber. Yogurt Carrot Cucumber Salad 3 ounces Kirby cucumber 2 ounces peeled baby carrots 1 small clove garlic 1 cup nonfat plain yogurt.

title: Concern Over Airline Safety
description: A study by the National Transportation Safety Board and an investigation by New York Times reporters cast a disturbing light on airline safety rules and regulations. The Safety Board, focusing on commuter airlines, said all but their smallest aircraft, and the people who fly them, should meet the same safety standards as major carriers. The Times's investigation of USAir, the nation's sixth-largest carrier, indicated that even major carriers' safety procedures can be flawed.

title: World News Briefs; Confidence Vote Postponed in Ireland
description: A confidence vote in the Government was postponed today until Wednesday as Prime Minister Albert Reynolds apologized to the country for his Attorney General's failure to extradite a Roman Catholic priest to Northern Ireland.

title: Health Care Awards Given
description: The New York Festivals has named the first winners of its international awards competition honoring health care communications work. In the competition, called the Globals, 4 Grand Global best of show awards and 24 best of category awards were presented.

title: Ammirati Lays Off 40 Employees
description: Ammirati & Puris/Lintas in New York said yesterday that it had laid off 40 of its 700 employees, from all areas of the agency, as it continues reorganizing after the merger in July that combined Ammirati & Puris with the New York office of Lintas Worldwide.

title: People
description: * Craig Middleton has rejoined Young & Rubicam Inc., New York, in the new position of executive vice president and strategic planning director. He was previously executive vice president and director of marketing and planning at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, New York. * Brian Jacobs, senior vice president and international media director at the Leo Burnett Co., London, has resigned, the agency said, when he was asked to relocate to Chicago. Robert C. Brennan, senior vice president and media director on the agency's McDonald's account, succeeds him in Chicago.

title: Assembly Speaker Voices Doubts On Pataki's Pledge to Cut Taxes
description: Starting to build a Democratic case against Governor-elect George E. Pataki's central campaign promise, the Assembly Speaker said today that it would be difficult to cut taxes as quickly and deeply as Mr. Pataki has pledged, and added that the Assembly Democrats might offer a tax-cutting plan of their own.

title:
Real Estate;
Madison Ave. Store for Ann Taylor
description: The women's apparel retailer Ann Taylor Inc. has signed a lease with the Equitable Life Assurance Society for a 25,000-square-foot, four-level store at 645 Madison Avenue in Manhattan, at the southeast corner of 60th Street. The retailer will join Calvin Klein and Crate and Barrel, both of which have announced new stores in the area. The large Barneys New York flagship store is a block away.

title: CHRONICLE
description: To many people, an 80th birthday is, in itself, reason for a major celebration. To JAMES W. ROUSE, the developer of such sites as the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan, Faneuil Hall in Boston and the town of Columbia, Md., it is an occasion to promote his favorite cause.

title: Sergeant Pleads Guilty in Harlem Thefts
description: The police sergeant who supervised a band of officers accused of corruption in the troubled 30th Precinct in Harlem pleaded guilty yesterday to breaking Federal law during what investigators say was a two-year binge of theft.

title: Gold Glove: It's New Garb For Boggs, Old For Mattingly
description: Don Mattingly's remarkable play at first base has made him synonymous with fielding excellence for a decade. Wade Boggs's steady play at third base has rarely forced anyone to include his name in the same sentence with Brooks Robinson. Until this season.

title: Staples Inc.(SPLS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included a one-time pretax gain of $ 8.4 million on the sale of an investment, in the quarter and 9 months.All per share amounts reflected the company's 3-for-2 stock split, effected as a dividend, on Oct. 28.Staples said that all amounts from fiscal 1993 have been restated to give effect to its acquisition of National Office Supply Co. and Spectrum Office Products Inc., which were completed in fiscal 1994 and were accounted for under the pooling of interest method.The company said the financial statement also included the effect of consolidation of Business Depot since the end of August.

title: Con Edison Agrees To $9 Million Fine For Contamination
description: Con Edison agreed yesterday to pay New York State a $9 million fine for illegally discharging oil and contaminants into New York Harbor, allowing contractors to dump waste from cleanup sites into the city's sewer system and ignoring complaints filed by state environmental officials.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; With a new name and logo, a financial giant tries to brand its units.
description: THERE are those who let a smile be their umbrella. Then there is Travelers Inc., which will let an umbrella be its umbrella.

title: JUMP IS LARGEST SINCE 1981
description: Determined to prevent strong economic growth from feeding inflation, the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates today by the largest amount since 1981 and left open the possibility of further increases. Banks followed by raising the rates they charge for loans.

title: Jackson Journal; The Rich Are Different. They Can Afford Homes.
description: In all the sweet-breathed valleys of the West, there is no designation more feared than being labeled "the next Aspen," a reference to the Colorado ski town where the rich gather like deer to a salt lick.

title: Eating Well
description: THE nutrition police may have trouble with some items on this list of mail-order holiday gifts.

title: Taiwan Apologizes After Troops Fire Artillery Shells Into China
description: Taiwan acknowledged today that its troops had fired at least a dozen artillery shells into a village on mainland China on Monday, wounding four people. It expressed "deep regret" over the incident.

title: Officer's Protective Jacket Stops a Bullet
description: A 38-year-old police officer who was chasing a drug suspect in East New York, Brooklyn, was shot in the ribs yesterday, but the bullet was stopped by a protective shield sewn into the officer's denim jacket, the police said.

title: Navratilova Beaten, but She Wins Garden's Heart
description: She wore her heart on her sleeve, and for 22 years she jammed her backhand volley -- one that won't be replicated and was rarely returned -- down the throats of any and all opponents who weren't savvy enough to get out of harm's way.

title: Great Dane Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and the 9 months included a charge of $ 46,626,000 for adoption of accounting standards FAS 106 and FAS 109.(Loss)

title: With 3 Votes to Spare
description: Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, was declared the victor in his re-election bid -- by just four votes. His Republican opponent vowed to challenge the results all the way, if necessary, to the new Republican-controlled Congress, which has the final say.

title: Clinton Outlines Plan to Bolster Europe-Wide Security
description: President Clinton will join the leaders of Russia, Germany, France and Britain in Budapest next month to sign an agreement aimed at helping European and former Soviet-bloc countries resolve conflicts before they lead to war, American officials said today.

title: Mugging Victim Looks At Drop in Crime Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Reach Out to the Homeless, But Often Find Efforts Rejected
description: The night was windy and brittle. On Central Park West near 68th Street, the police officers spotted a grizzled man with tufted eyebrows hunched alongside a bench under a street lamp. In the stiff breeze, his windbreaker made an empty rustle. The two officers slid out of the van and headed in his direction.

title: Nets Answer Wake-Up Call And Triumph
description: They had an All-Star forward whose game needed an awakening and an exhausted All-Star guard whose body needed a rest. So the Nets, daydreaming away the first month of the season, reached back into time tonight. They inserted Eric (Sleepy) Floyd, who last played for the Nets in a regular-season game 12 years ago, into their backcourt.

title: Cardinals' Beuerlein Will Miss 2-3 Weeks
description: STEVE BEUERLEIN underwent surgery yesterday to repair his injured left knee, and the quarterback will be lost to the Arizona Cardinals for two to three weeks. Beuerlein injured the knee early in Sunday's 10-9 victory over the Giants. He continued to play and directed both second-half scoring drives that helped the Cardinals improve to 4-6. Beuerlein said the knee's medial meniscus cartilage is torn. (AP)

title: Living Centers of America Inc.(LCA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated for implementation of Financial Accounting Standards Number 109 ''Accounting for Income Taxes.''

title: School Lunches
description: To The Living Section:

title: Brian Dutton, 59, Scholar of Spanish
description: Brian Dutton, a scholar of medieval Spanish literature, died on Oct. 21 at his home in Oak Park, Ill. He was 59 and also had a home in Madison, Wis., where he taught at the University of Wisconsin.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Governor-elect JOHN G. ROWLAND of Connecticut announced the leaders of his transition team today, and minutes later announced the state's soon-to-be First Lady, saying he is to marry PATRICIA LARGAY, his high school sweetheart, on Saturday.

title: Fantasies and a Love That Led to Murder
description: "Next time I write in this diary, Mother will be dead," wrote Pauline Parker, a 15-year-old living in Christchurch, New Zealand, in 1954. "How odd -- yet how pleasing." Making good on that promise, Pauline and her school friend Juliet Hulme went on an outing with Honora Parker, Pauline's mother, and bludgeoned her to death with a brick stuffed in a stocking. Just before this fateful stroll in the woods, the threesome had stopped to enjoy tea.

title: Watch Your Thoughts in Gingrich's Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * New World Telephone, Hong Kong, to Bozell Ltd., Hong Kong, as the first agency to handle the telecommunications company's account. Billings were estimated at $5 million. * Royal Oak Enterprises, Atlanta, to Fricks Advertising, Atlanta, to handle advertising for the marketer of Royal Oak charcoal briquets and other related products, previously at Tausche Martin Lonsdorf, Atlanta. Billings were estimated to exceed $3 million.

title: Leaders Agree On Free Trade For the Pacific
description: The glow of Tuesday's victory of creating the largest free-trade zone in the Asia-Pacific region dissipated today as President Clinton and President Suharto of Indonesia clashed over the issue of Indonesia's much-criticized human rights record.

title: Smoke, Not Substance, at APEC
description: The leaders of 18 nations who gathered this week at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting in Indonesia arrived with lofty talk of achieving a sweeping agreement to stimulate economic growth on the Pacific Rim, already among the most vibrant economic regions in the world. Their final communique enshrines a noble objective: free trade and investment by the year 2020.

title: Ex-State Police Investigator Admits Evidence Tampering
description: Three weeks after saying he was pleading guilty to evidence tampering only because he was emotionally drained and could not afford to mount a defense, a former state police investigator admitted at his sentencing today that he had faked evidence in a 1992 Orange County burglary.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Coach Is Dismissed at Louisiana State
description: Louisiana State University Coach CURLEY HALLMAN was dropped yesterday but will be allowed to coach the Tigers' final two games of the season. Hallman will coach L.S.U. (2-7) on Saturday against Tulane and Nov. 26 at Arkansas. In four years, Hallman's record at L.S.U. is 14-28.

title: Mesa Airlines Inc.(MESA,NNM) reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The latest year's share earnings included extraordinary gain of 1 cent a share, compared with an extraordinary gain of 4 cents a share in the 1993's share earnings.

title: Clinton Devises New Guidelines On Arms Sales
description: Making explicit a policy that has existed in practice for three years, the Clinton Administration is preparing new guidelines that will consider the health of the nation's military contractors when reviewing arms sales to foreign countries.

title: Motoo Kimura; Japanese Geneticist, 70
description: Dr. Motoo Kimura, a Japanese geneticist who challenged prevailing views about evolution, died on Sunday in a hospital in Shizuoka, Japan, after collapsing in his home, The Associated Press reported. He was 70.

title: D.R. Horton Inc.(DRHI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leader Says Austria Must Face Nazi Past
description: President Thomas Klestil of Austria, going where none of his predecessors had ever been, went before the Israeli Parliament today to say that his country had often failed to face its past and that it produced "many of the worst henchmen in the Nazi dictatorship."

title: Earle M. Jorgensen Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Case On Pricing Of Tobacco
description: Federal antitrust regulators today accused the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation of improperly stifling price discounting by the American Tobacco Company, putting pressure on retailers and threatening sales personnel with retaliation if a planned merger of the companies was completed.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Ruling in City College Demotion Suit Is Greeted With Concern
description: Academics and legal experts reacted with concern yesterday to the Supreme Court's order that the City College of New York be given a second chance to defend the demotion of its black studies chairman, who has been accused of bigotry.

title: Tennessee Williams, With Love and Pain
description: "The Glass Menagerie" is the American theater's most exquisite mea culpa.

title: Spreading the Word in the South Bronx; In a World Stripped of Luxuries, Mormon Missionaries Help Faith Take Root
description: Soon after arriving in New York last December, Kevin Mower sidled up to a young woman on the subway and tried to engage her in conversation.

title: Public Interest Law Students Need Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Watch Your Thoughts in Gingrich's Land; North Deja Vu
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Martina Exits Smiling
description: THE curtain was coming down. The banner was going up. Martina Navratilova, out of habit, carried out a box of tissues.

title: Toxicity Test Delaying Dredging to Reopen Marine Terminal
description: A plan to revitalize commercial shipping in New York City by reopening a marine terminal on Staten Island has been delayed for at least several months after contaminated sediment was unexpectedly found around the terminal's berths, port officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. Industry Had a Surge In October
description: American factories, mines and utilities stepped up their operating rate to nearly 85 percent of industrial capacity in October -- a level that had not been reached since 1980 during the Carter Administration.

title: From Virginia, Early Thanksgiving Traditions and Feasts
description: Although many people associate Thanksgiving with New England, an early thanksgiving prayer was recorded in Virginia on Dec. 4, 1619, when 38 settlers from England came ashore at the James River.

title: Rockefeller Center May Face Mortgage Default
description: The Rockefeller Group, the company that owns Rockefeller Center in Manhattan, lacks the cash to make the mortgage payments and may be close to defaulting on the loan, according to a Government filing by the company that holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on the property.

title: Israel Turns Over More Responsibility to Palestinian Authority
description: Israel handed over responsibility for tourism and social services in the West Bank today to the Palestinian Authority.

title: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co.(MC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are in U.S. dollars. The latest quarter and 6 months' results have been translated from yen at the rate of U.S. $ 1.00 equaled 98 yen, the approximate rate on the Tokyo Foreign Exchange Market on Sept. 30, 1994.Year-ago periods' results were translated at the rate of U.S. $ 1.00 equaled 105 yen.Operations of MCA Inc. are included in the company's consolidated financial results on a one-quarter lag basis relative to MCA's fiscal year, which ends Dec. 31.Share earnings are in American Depositary Share (A.D.S.), and each A.D.S. represented 10 shares of common stock.Sales are net sales.

title: A Debate on the Greater Evil: Inflation or Chill or Pink Slips
description: The Federal Reserve's decision to increase interest rates by the largest amount in years intensified a debate that focuses not so much on the amount of the rise but whether the Federal Reserve should have acted at all.

title: Whirlpool to Shut 2 Plants and Cut Work Force
description: Continuing a trend among large companies of cutting employment even in times of prosperity, the Whirlpool Corporation said today that it would close two North American factories and reduce its worldwide work force by more than 8 percent.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: CON ED TO PAY $9 MILLION POLLUTION FINE

title: TJX Cos.(TJX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After a charge of $ 2,667,000, or 4 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Columbia to Celebrate 75 Years of Great Books
description: In a Columbia College classroom the other day, Prof. Hamid Dabashi, 43, was discussing Machiavelli's "The Prince." He pointed to a passage about the dangers of political alliances in uncertain times.

title: Kodak Plans To Eliminate 800 More Jobs
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, which has been trimming its ranks for several years to cut operating costs, announced yesterday that it would eliminate about 800 jobs at its big Kodak Park manufacturing complex in Rochester.

title: Public & Private; The Politics of Meanness
description: This is my new motto: Keep Al Gore Healthy.

title: Opening Asia's Door
description: In setting their vast and vital region on the path toward free trade by the year 2020, the leaders of 18 nations around the Pacific Ocean have taken a step that appears to be a bold move toward the future.

title: Of Torvill and Dean, With Dreams on Ice
description: Apparently still salivating over the media feast delivered by the sensational "battle" of Nancy and Tonya, television is pushing just about any figure-skating button it can find.

title: Class Notes
description: Carl Westcott, Ford dealer turned education entrepreneur, is standing in his office adjacent to the glitzy Galleria mall in north Dallas clicking quickly across the channels on his Toshiba television until he comes to his TI-IN educational network, which serves 2,000 schools.

title: Maturing Jazz Industry Opens Convention Tonight
description: The Jazz Times Convention starts tonight, which means that tired-looking, cigarette-smoking people from all over the world will gather to talk about what they heard last night, what kinds of deals can be cooked up today and who is sitting in with whom and where. For the next four days, the convention becomes jazz's business paradise, with bookers, musicians, radio programmers, record company executives, agents, club owners and critics swarming like fish around a particularly fertile reef.

title: Manley Released on Bail After Drug Arrest
description: DEXTER MANLEY, once one of the N.F.L.'s top defensive linemen, appeared in court yesterday after a crack cocaine arrest in Houston. Manley, who was banned from the N.F.L. for violating the league's drug policy, was arrested Sunday night and was released Monday after posting $5,000 bail. Yesterday, he made an initial appearance in court with his lawyer, PAULA ASHER, who said, "He is anxious to get this matter resolved." A Dec. 6 arraignment has been scheduled.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: A Candid Self-Portrait Of a Drag Queen in Mufti Dixon Place

title: Pataki's Break: Mostly in Vermont
description: Governor-elect George E. Pataki did not spend his four-day holiday in New York State, as his aides said on Monday, but crossed the border to Vermont, where he stayed at the Equinox Hotel in Manchester, his spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, said today.

title: HOME DEPOT INC. (HD,N)
description: Home Depot Inc. said yesterday that fiscal third-quarter profit soared 36 percent, exceeding Wall Street's expectations, as expansion into Canada and the Midwest fueled a 40 percent sales increase.

title: Tosco Deal With Exxon
description: The Tosco Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy Exxon's gas stations in Arizona for $60 million. Tosco, a gasoline refiner based in Stamford, Conn., said the purchase included 88 service stations that sell a total of 336,000 gallons a day. Tosco will become a distributor of Exxon products in Arizona for at least seven years. It said it expected to complete the purchase by the end of the year.

title: Remembering Aerobics
description: To The Living Section:

title: Play in New U.S. League Won't Kick Off Until 1996
description: The World Cup may yet achieve its intended legacy of a first-rate professional soccer league in the United States, but not next year as planned.

title: Ailing Lungs Said to Improve When Smokers Stop
description: Nearly all smokers experience an accelerated decline in lung function, and many eventually develop a chronic lung disease like chronic bronchitis or emphysema. But a new study has found that quitting smoking can repair some of the damage.

title: Elizabeth G. Speare, 84, Author Of Children's Historical Novels
description: Elizabeth George Speare, an author of historical novels for children, died yesterday in Northwest General Hospital in Tucson, Ariz. She was 84.

title: Frito-Lay Plans Media Consolidation
description: The Frito-Lay snack foods subsidiary of Pepsico Inc. will consolidate the media planning portion of its brands account, divided between BBDO New York and DDB Needham Chicago, at one of those agencies. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $70 million.

title: City Council Offers Plans On Budget
description: Opening negotiations with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over his plan to close a $1.1 billion budget gap with deep spending cuts, the City Council revealed a wish list of alternatives yesterday, including the creation of an authority to oversee recycling, an increase in taxi medallions and the consolidation of nearly a dozen of New York City's agencies.

title: Weicker Gives Budget Plan But Rowland Sees Problem
description: Lowell P. Weicker Jr. today issued a budget plan for the next two years that would increase spending 7.3 percent without new taxes, but Governor-elect John G. Rowland immediately said he would reduce spending to make possible the income-tax cut he promised in his campaign.

title: Penney (J.C.) Co. (JCP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 36 million, or 14 cents a share, net of income taxes of $ 23 million, in the quarter and $ 53 million in the 9 months, net of income taxes of $ 33 million, on debt redemption. The 9 months was also after a gain of $ 51 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting adjustment. The two items in the 9 months equaled a loss of 1 cent a share.The effective income tax rate was 38.7 percent in the latest third quarter, compared with 40.4 percent in the year-ago period.
