But when Bowe, the former heavyweight champion, takes on Donald in a 12-round HBO fight at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., on Dec. 3, there's one similarity you can bet on: Both fighters will be getting the same kind of calm, studied critiques between rounds. That's because Donald's trainer, JANCKS MORTON, learned his craft by studying Bowe's trainer, 83-year-old EDDIE FUTCH. Both trainers took part in a conference call yesterday, and part of the conversation turned on the similarities of the two fighters, both former Olympians who failed to win their weight classes. The two fighters have identical measurements in reach (81 inches), neck (17 1/2 ), biceps (17) and expanded chests (50), but at 38 inches, Bowe's waist is 6 inches larger than Donald's (32).

title: Film in Review; The Many Lives of a Man, All of Them Odd
description: Maurizio Nichetti, the director and star of the mildly funny and excruciatingly whimsical "Stefano Quantestorie," should not be confused with Nanni Moretti, the director and star of the current "Caro Diario," a far more sophisticated and droll film. Both have been compared, wrongheadedly, to Woody Allen, but a taste for one does not translate to the other.

title: In America; At Last, A Truce
description: The cold war has ended. Governor-elect George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani are going to sit down and talk. The blood feud, provoked by Mayor Giuliani's decision to cross party lines and endorse Mario Cuomo for re-election, is being put aside -- at least for the time being.

title: A Bunch Of Bobcats Are Caught In a Cage
description: It was all the Ohio University basketball team could do to make it to New York. But for a few moments yesterday, a portion of the traveling party was not sure how long it would take to get out.

title: Sir Ian Potter, 92, a Financier And Philanthropist in Australia
description: Sir Ian Potter, an Australian financier and philanthropist, died on Oct. 24 at his home in Melbourne, Australia. He was 92.

title: CML Group (CML,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
The Miracle of Cold 'Cooking' in a Bath of Fresh Lime Juice
description: LIMES are like nature's microwave. Take a chunk of tuna, put it in a bath of lime juice for several hours, and in a kind of kitchen voodoo, the fish will cook without fire. Or slice a red onion, mix it with lime juice, and the onion will soon transform itself into a delicious fuchsia-hued relish with the harsh bite cooked right out of it.

title: Slovak Folk Troupe in Its New York Debut
description: Lucnica, the Slovak song-and-dance ensemble from Bratislava, is absolutely first-rate. Its young dancers sparkle with glittering technique in an eye-opening repertory that remains true to its surprisingly diverse sources.

title: On Campus; Catholic Group Buys Toronto U. Site
description: A conservative Roman Catholic organization, Opus Dei, which some former members say uses cult-like practices to recruit college-age students, is opening a branch at the University of Toronto.

title: Two More Young Lovebirds On a Murderous Rampage
description: As one more gory road movie about gun-toting, media-mad white trash on the rampage, C. M. Talkington's "Love and a .45" has elements of parody. There's enough of "Natural Born Killers" here to suggest that Mr. Talkington has read the mind of Quentin Tarantino, or at least taken satirical notice of Mr. Tarantino's early screenplay for that Oliver Stone film. On the other hand, maybe murderous teen-age lovebirds yearning to be television stars are simply a staple of our culture these days. And maybe some ideas are just plain parody-proof.

title:
On Campus;
President's Salary Puts Amber U. on the Map
description: Last month, when The Chronicle of Higher Education listed the highest-paid college presidents, Amber University's Douglas Warner was third from the top.

title: Rabbi Given Prison Term In Kidnapping Of Teen-Ager
description: In a courtroom rife with rancorous passion, an ultra-Orthodox rabbi was sentenced yesterday to 4 to 12 years in prison for kidnapping a Jewish teen-ager who disappeared from his family for two years.

title: A Sex-Defying 'What If,' Taken to Full Term
description: Virtual comedy is often the province of Ivan Reitman ("Twins," "Kindergarten Cop," "Ghostbusters"), whose films can look a lot funnier than they actually are. Big stars, attention-getting stories and bright, shiny backdrops create a comic imprint that has more to do with brand-name manufacturing than with a humorous directorial touch.

title: Sunglass Hut Int'l.(RAYS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: All per share amounts adjusted to reflect a 100 percent increase in the number of shares from the stock dividend declared Oct. 31, 1994.Year-ago periods are pro forma and restated to reflect December 1993 ''pooling of interests'' acquisition of Wallis Arnold Enterprises Inc.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HAWKER SIDDELEY CANADA INC., Toronto, has a preliminary agreement to sell the assets and some liabilities of its Canadian Steel Foundries unit to Atchison Casting Corp., Atchison, Kan. Terms were not disclosed. ELI LILLY & CO., Indianapolis, said it had completed the $4 billion purchase of PCS Health Systems Inc., Scottsdale, Ariz., from McKesson Corp., San Francisco.

title: New York, Beware: The Death Penalty Is Riddled With Iniquity
description: To the Editor:

title: Chargers Keep Hearing Tune to 'Kansas City'
description: Wobbly wheels on the playoff express are slowing some of the division leaders, especially the San Diego Chargers.

title: Oneida Ltd.(OCQ,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Sceptre Resources (SRL,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: H & R Block Stock Plunges On Electronic Filing Change
description: Shares of H & R Block Inc. plunged today after the company said that a change in an Internal Revenue Service policy would hurt its electronic filing business.

title: M. T. Jenkins, 77, Doctor Who Tried To Revive Kennedy
description: Dr. Marion Thomas Jenkins, the Texas anesthesiologist who tried to resuscitate both President John F. Kennedy and his assassin, Lee Harvey Oswald, 31 years ago, died on Monday at his home in Dallas. He was 77.

title: Sports of The Times; A Father Learns From His Son
description: THE father was doing time in Federal prison when he realized the cycle of failure is not impossible to break. On the TV screen, the child he left behind a handful of years before was now 6 feet 8 inches tall, 240 pounds, the best player in a college basketball game.

title: Expedition to Houston Leaves a Good Taste in Reeves's Mouth
description: It was about 1 A.M. and the Giants, fresh off a 13-10 victory over the Houston Oilers on Monday night, were stuck in traffic en route to the airport and the flight home. A car fire was raging up ahead. The Giants were sitting on the bus. But Dan Reeves couldn't wait. He was too hungry. So he and three of his assistant coaches, upon seeing a McDonald's about a mile up the highway, decided to hoof it.

title: Dow Plunges 91.52 As High Rates Lure Investors to Bonds
description: In one of the most turbulent market sessions this year, stock prices fell further yesterday than on any other day in the last 10 months.

title: Hanukkah's a-Coming: Geese Are Getting Fat
description: A HANUKKAH goose? With latkes?

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about moves by the New York Police Department to combat prostitution by arresting clients referred incorrectly to a 1979 radio broadcast by Mayor Edward I. Koch. The men whose names Mr. Koch read on the air had indeed been convicted, not merely arrested, on charges of patronizing prostitutes.

title: AT HOME WITH/Ntozake Shange; Native Daughter
description: AFTER a rough start to a rough morning, Ntozake Shange is settling down. She has been ill all night and still does not feel well. She's grumpy at being asked to meet at her home instead of at a restaurant and annoyed that a photographer showed up 10 minutes early.

title: Stocks Trade Lower in Japan
description: Stocks tumbled in trading here today in the first opportunity for Japanese investors to react to the plunge on Wall Street on Tuesday.

title: Bus Bound for Atlantic City Hits Truck, Injuring Both Drivers
description: A charter bus en route from Chinatown to Atlantic City crashed into a flatbed tow truck on the Garden State Parkway Tuesday night, critically injuring the bus driver and interrupting a holiday gambling junket for 37 passengers.

title: Vincent Puts Down His Pen
description: Fay Vincent, the former baseball commissioner, said yesterday that he has decided not to complete and publish the book that he and a collaborator have been writing.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Sounds of a 'Winterreise' Schubert Never Dreamed Of La Mama E.T.C.

title: Here, A Mother Can Age Gracefully
description: WITH her June Allyson-style blond bob and don't-dawdle gait, Irene Bender wears her 74 years lightly. She still swings a mean golf club. "But whether anyone would consider it 'playing' is debatable," she said with a self-deprecating laugh. This week, so that her daughters and sons-in-law can "play their games and drink their cocktails," Mrs. Bender will have a Thanksgiving sleep-over in her newly renovated house. The guests? Her five grandchildren, who range in age from 3 to 9 years.

title: Unlocking the Grid?
description: Senator Dole's agreement with President Clinton on GATT raises a possibility that when the Republicans take over Congress, gridlock may not necessarily be inevitable.

title: Ruminations on Life By a Korean Minimalist
description: Sin Cha Hong, a Korean-born minimalist performer and choreographer, is at her best when she is simplest. Miss Hong has a gift for expressing profound ideas about life, death and transcendence in a cross-stage walk or an odd lift of a body, for instance, as she did on Saturday night in a program of new work at the Annex Theater at La Mama.

title: Corrections
description: A film review yesterday about "Resistance" misstated a film credit for its director of photography, Sally Bongers. She did not work on "The Piano"; the cinematographer for that film was Stuart Dryburgh.

title: Gerber Scientific Inc.(GRB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 788,000, or 3 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: Events: Latin American Art, Crafts, Tours, Holiday Trees
description: Benefit Shops New York Design Center, 200 Lexington Avenue (33d Street); (212) 255-9877.

title: Genesis Health Ventures Inc.(GHV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 18,000 from an adjustment in accounting.The per share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.Genesis Health Ventures said that results for the latest fourth quarter and year include Meridian Healthcare, which was acquired Nov. 30, 1993.

title: Repayment on ARCO Fund
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, or ARCO, said today that it would reimburse about 17,000 employees almost $23 million to cover losses tied to their investments in a money market fund.

title: Author of Nicole Simpson Biography Finds She's a Prisoner of Her Own Book
description: Faye D. Resnick sat on the couch of her country hideaway here, 3,000 miles from her home in Los Angeles and 40 miles southeast of the closest Starbucks. Here, roadside vendors sell maple syrup rather than star maps. Autumnal trees turn brilliant reds and yellows rather than a dull brown. The log burning in the fireplace is genuine, not a California model lit by a switch.

title: Currents; Inspiration From an Angel
description: PERHAPS as a grim example of wartime landmarks preservation, the colossal Kolner Dom, or Cologne Cathedral, which took 600 years to complete, was the only building untouched by Allied bombs. Today, it is a pilgrimage site, both sacred and secular, and the architectural center of the city.

title: Suspect in Washington Shootings Had Past Weapons Convictions
description: The man who police say killed a District of Columbia police officer and two F.B.I. agents in a gun battle on Tuesday inside police headquarters here had a criminal record that included convictions on 13 weapons and ammunition charges, law-enforcement officials said today, and the 16-month probation he received after 18 months in jail had ended four days before the shootings.

title: U.S. and Europe Adrift in Balkans
description: Despite the NATO air raids this week on Serbian missile sites in northwestern Bosnia and in Croatia, the United States and its European allies remain divided on the fundamental question of how to respond to the threat to European security from the fighting in the Balkans.

title: FORT HOWARD TO GO PUBLIC AS PART OF RECAPITALIZATION
description: The Fort Howard Corporation, one of the nation's biggest paper products companies, said yesterday that it would go public as part of a $1.6 billion recapitalization. The company, which makes Mardi Gras paper napkins and Soft 'N Gentle toilet paper, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to raise about $300 million by selling 13.1 million shares of common stock. Fort Howard plans to use the proceeds, along with bank loans, to redeem and prepay $1.54 billion of outstanding debt securities and bank debt. Fort Howard, based in Green Bay, Wis., has been closely held since a $3.7 billion leveraged buyout in 1988 led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Playing Comes First, Pain Is Second
description: In the first quarter in Monday night's game against Houston, Giants linebacker Carlton Bailey tried to jam a 300-pound offensive lineman, and Bailey took the brunt of the hit. He said it felt as if someone had taken a hammer and driven it into his right shoulder.

title: THEATER
description: When the Punishment Is Worse Than the Crime National Jewish Theater

title: THEATER
description: When the Word Was All: 6 Short Plays From Radio Intar Theater

title: Economic Scene; Ukraine has a good chance of winning its dash for capitalism.
description: LEONID KUCHMA, the President of Ukraine since July, made the rounds this week to convince Americans to come to the aid of his country. To no one's surprise, the blunt, poised politician -- once the manager of the Soviet Union's premier nuclear missile factory -- argued that Ukrainians were finally ready to take the plunge to free markets.

title: House Committee's Report Is Critical of F.B.I. in Ames Spy Case
description: A draft report by the House Intelligence Committee on the Aldrich Ames spy case criticizes the Federal Bureau of Investigation for taking a "wait-and-see attitude" on the executions in the Soviet Union in the mid-1980's of the bureau's best Soviet double agents, Government officials said today.

title: Joseph H. Reid, 78, Director of League On Child Welfare
description: Joseph Harold Reid, who was executive director of the Child Welfare League of America for 25 years until his retirement in 1978, died last Friday at his home in Melbourne Beach, Fla. A former resident of Bellerose, L.I., he was 78.

title: U.S. Long Distance (USLD,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary charge of $ 316,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Thanksgiving Day
description: NEW YORK PARADE Begins at 9 A.M. at 77th Street and Central Park West. Travels south on Broadway to 34th Street. Concludes at noon.

title: High School Senior Held in Fatal Shooting of 15-Year-Old Girl
description: A senior at Mount Vernon High School fatally shot his 15-year-old girlfriend in his living room Tuesday night, then tried to bury her body in his backyard garden before his mother came home, the police said this afternoon.

title: Dissident G.O.P. Senators Bid To Topple Marino as Leader
description: Dissident members of the State Senate's Republican majority have mounted a campaign to unseat Ralph J. Marino as their leader, charging that he is quietly subverting the interests of Governor-elect George E. Pataki.

title: System Maker Faces Inquiry
description: The Network Imaging Corporation said yesterday that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan for accounting practices in 1992 and 1993.

title: Thomas H. Kuchel Dies at 84; Ex-Republican Whip in Senate
description: Thomas H. Kuchel, a Californian who spent 16 years in the United States Senate and who as Republican whip there played a vital role in enactment of major civil rights legislation in the 1960's, died on Monday night at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 84.

title: Dollar Benefits From Gains Registered in Bond Trading
description: The dollar firmed against most leading currencies yesterday, bolstered by gains in the United States bond market.

title: One Deal Hints at More to Come
description: Things will not always be so easy, but today's agreement between the White House and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas on the worldwide trade pact demonstrated that the Republican triumph in the midterm elections need not produce two years of gridlock in Washington, with Congress and President Clinton constantly at war.

title: Police Commissioner Orders Officers to Wear Seat Belts
description: Alarmed by a rash of traffic accidents involving police cars, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said yesterday that he would require police officers to wear seat belts beginning Jan. 1.

title: Bridge
description: The controversy over the Women's Board-a-Match Teams, when a full session of play was canceled because some of the players had played the same deals four months earlier, has died down, but a similar problem seemed about to erupt at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A literary squabble between the widow and the ex-wife of Kenneth Tynan, the British drama critic, has heated up. ELAINE DUNDY, who was married to him first (1951 to 1964), is fighting mad at her successor, KATHLEEN TYNAN (they married in 1967; he died in 1980).

title: A House That Anchored a Child's World
description: THREE-THIRTEEN South O Street. I wrote that address on a hundred letters during my childhood, first in shaky print and later in plump, self-conscious script. I hardly believed you could reach such a fabulous destination with an ordinary postage stamp. In my mind, the "O" might as well have stood for Oz. Lake Worth was a little Florida town near the ocean, where my grandparents' house stood, protected by mango, loquat, jasmine and shower of gold trees.

title: Dutch Prince Is Robbed of $5,000 Watch
description: A Dutch prince who braved the New York City Marathon fell afoul of a thief in Times Square the next afternoon and was robbed of a $5,000 gold Rolex watch and about $100 in cash, the consul for press affairs of the Consulate General of the Netherlands said yesterday

title: Reacting to Wall Street, European Markets Fall
description: Taking a cue from the steep drop in stock prices in the United States on Tuesday, markets across Europe plunged today as investors dumped stocks and sought refuge in bonds.

title: Boy Who Fled Chemotherapy Is Back Home, His Wish Granted
description: Billy Best, the 16-year-old with cancer who ran away to Texas last month so that he would not have to undergo chemotherapy treatments, has been granted his wish now that he has returned home.

title: Yearling in an Executive Suite; Genuine Risk's First Foal Is Starting Life as a Race Horse
description: Nobody knows yet if he can run fast or far, but his mother won the 1980 Kentucky Derby and his father was a European mile star, and he is just now getting his first taste of training as the best-known yearling in America.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: COUNCIL CREATES AGENCY TO WATCH POLICE

title: A Day to Give Thanks for Balloons; A 'Balloonatic' Makes Air Sculptures for Macy's Parade
description: For 30 years, Manfred G. Bass has dreamed up and guided the creation of the balloons and floats of Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade. It is the only job Mr. Bass, a 59-year-old artist, has ever held, and the only one he ever really wanted.

title: Army Says Nerve Gas Incinerator in Utah Is Safe
description: A team of Army engineers dispatched last month to review allegations that a nerve gas incinerator in Utah was unsafe found lapses in training and management, but concluded that none was serious enough to threaten the safety of workers or the public.

title: No Headline
description: "What idiot is going to work 500 consecutive games when my wife doesn't even drive and I still work? There will never be another nut like me." BERNARD SHERMAN, 80, who has not missed a football game at his high school alma mater since 1934. [ B29:4. ]

title: Argentina Demotes Its Once-Powerful Armed Forces
description: Ever since Argentina's defeat by Britain in the Falkland War in 1982, the armed forces have been in decline here, and President Carlos Saul Menem has virtually eliminated any threat of a military coup through a series of reforms since taking office in 1990.

title: Newbridge Networks (NN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 5
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Young Austrian Melts Into the Music at Hand Avery Fisher Hall

title: Budd Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income(Loss)Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Carjacking Jury Visits the Field Where Teen-Agers Were Shot
description: The jury in the carjacking trial of Edward L. Summers took a bus trip to the brush-covered field where two Rockland teen-agers were shot last January, one fatally, and both the prosecution and defense argued that the visit shored up their cases.

title: Merrill Corp.(MRLL,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 177,000, or 2 cents a share, reflecting the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income tax.

title: Essay; A Dinner Party
description: As soon as he arrived at the dinner for him at the Israeli Ambassador's residence, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin took me aside to chastise me for opposing his desire for U.S. troops on the Golan Heights.

title: First Harrisburg
description: Shares of First Harrisburg Bancor plunged yesterday in Nasdaq trading after the company said it was ending merger talks with several suitors because their stock prices were dropping sharply. First Harrisburg is a bank holding company in Pennsylvania.

title: Nets Find at Least One Answer
description: If they had doubts about this, the Nets and their training-camp gamble on a 34-year-old veteran guard, Sleepy Floyd erased them tonight.

title: Election Harvest Crowds Thanksgiving Table
description: To the Editor:

title: In Trade-Pact War, Clashes Outside Capital Are Heavy
description: Business lobbyists may be battling for the global trade agreement in Washington, but some of the heaviest combat has come where people produce things more tangible than legislation.

title: Yeltsin Says Russia Won't Yield in Baltic Border Dispute
description: Less than three months after withdrawing all his troops with fanfare from Estonia, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia stood on his disputed border with the Baltic nation today and promised that he would never yield "one single centimeter" of land.

title: Making a Film Out of the Horror of Mother Murder
description: It remains the most sensational murder case ever in New Zealand. In 1954 two girls, Pauline Yvonne Parker, 16, and Juliet Marion Hulme, 15, were convicted of brutally killing Pauline's mother.

title: A Family Comes Back From a Slow Descent Into Poverty
description: Twice a day she leaves the half-light of her apartment and gingerly circles the block, savoring the sharp air and grasping at normalcy after months of illness and loss.

title: Lower Stocks Aren't a Worry for the Fed
description: The steep fall in stock prices this week is not expected to prompt any policy review at the Federal Reserve, where officials have been surprised at the stock market's resilience until now.

title: Pfizer Will Buy SmithKline Unit for $1.45 Billion
description: In the latest in a whirl of billion-dollar deals in the drug industry, Pfizer Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the animal health business of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. of Britain for $1.45 billion in cash.

title: Months of Delicate Talks In Kazakhstan Atom Deal
description: The deal that brought more than half a ton of bomb-grade uranium from Kazakhstan to the United States required months of delicate three-way negotiations and was made possible only after Washington got Russian approval, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Maryland's Joe Smith Stars by Any Nickname
description: He screens his phone calls, finally answers to a nickname and has insured his knees for $1 million. Joe Smith's evolution from naive freshman to hunted sophomore is so complete that he may never be a junior.

title: Ferrellgas Partners (FGP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings are in units.Year-ago results are pro forma and assumes partnership was formed Aug. 1, 1993.(Loss)

title: Strawbridge & Clothier (STRWA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: (Loss)

title: Don't Cave In on Myanmar
description: The Clinton Administration, after struggling messily for nearly two years with the dilemmas of human rights diplomacy, seems at last to have arrived at a consistent approach: Deny reality, declare things are getting better and lower the pressure on authoritarian regimes. Now, at least, tyrannies large and small, from China to Indonesia to Myanmar, can count on consistent treatment.

title: U.S. Opposes Lifting Desegregation Controls
description: The Clinton Administration, taking a position in a school desegregation case for the first time, told the Supreme Court today that it planned to oppose the State of Missouri's request to have the Kansas City public schools declared successfully integrated and no longer in need of Federal court supervision.

title: Alfred Jospe, 85, A Retired Director Of B'nai B'rith Unit
description: Rabbi Alfred Jospe, a retired national director of B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundations, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 85.

title: Vietnamese Hint the U.S. Could Use Port Again
description: Fearing China, Vietnam has begun to signal an interest in inviting American naval forces back to Cam Ranh Bay, the large port installation built by the United States during the Vietnam War.

title: German Metals Giant Plans To Reduce Its Share Value
description: Metallgesellschaft A.G. said today that huge losses had virtually wiped out its capital, forcing it to seek additional funds from its shareholders.

title: The Wedding Reception Did Double Duty With Soup Kitchen
description: To the Editor:

title: Wit and Craftsmanship Give Windows the Royal Treatment
description: IF curtains are like dresses for windows, then finials and their attendant hardware -- brackets, rods and rings -- are window jewelry, grace notes that lend fabric and glass a dash of style, ornament and fun.

title: Schumacher Gets Title
description: MICHAEL SCHUMACHER was confirmed as the Formula One world- champion driver yesterday despite his involvement in a controversial collision in the season's last race. But the officials who gave their approval want to make sure future championships aren't decided the same way.

title: Republicans in Hartford May Not Get All the Spoils
description: For the first time in 24 years, a Republican is preparing to take the Governor's office here, and many of the party faithful are clamoring for a chance to serve.

title: 5,000 Palestinians Rally in Gaza to Support Arafat
description: About 5,000 Palestinians gathered in Jericho today to show their support for the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, whose authority has been seriously frayed by challenges from Islamic fundamentalists and the Israeli Government over the last few weeks.

title: Election Harvest Crowds Thanksgiving Table; Relax, Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach for Iowa State
description: DAN McCARNEY was hired yesterday as coach at Iowa State after spending four seasons as the defensive coordinator at Wisconsin. McCarney, 41, replaced JIM WALDEN, who resigned Nov. 3 as his team was on its way to a 0-10-1 record. McCarney helped with the turnaround of the Iowa and Wisconsin programs. (AP)

title: Anacomp Inc.(AAC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 188,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter, and $ 841,000, or 2 cents a share, in the year. The year was also after a gain of $ 8 million, or 17 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 285,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 1,334,000, or 4 cents a share, in the year. The periods were also after extraordinary income of $ 4.2 million, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 6.9 million, or 17 cents a share, in the year, from tax loss carryforwards.The per share earnings for both years were after preferred dividends and discount accretion.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Common * American Sensors Inc., Toronto, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of two million shares. The lead underwriter will be Paine Webber Inc.

title: Defying Mayor, Council Offers Budget Cuts
description: Defying Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the City Council voted yesterday to adopt its own menu of spending cuts to close a $1.1 billion gap in New York City's budget. The Mayor bluntly dismissed the Council's move as illegal and suggested that he would move ahead with his own cuts anyway.

title: Russia's Nuclear Waste Gamble
description: For more than three decades, we now learn, Russia and the former Soviet Union have secretly pumped huge amounts of radioactive waste into the earth. The goal was to sequester the lethal wastes far from possible contact with humans. But already there are signs that some wastes are seeping beyond the original confines.

title: Chinese Woman Out
description: The world champion YANG AIHUA of China was banned for two years yesterday for failing a drug test, the international swimming federation, FINA, said. The federation confirmed that Yang tested positive for an excessive level of testosterone in a random sampling Sept. 30 before the Asian Games in Hiroshima, Japan. The ban means she will miss the Atlanta Olympics. (AP)

title: Handleman Co.(HDL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
NATO Jets Hit Missiles as Serbs Gain in Bosnia
description: As rebel Serbs entered the outskirts of a Muslim enclave in northwest Bosnia, NATO warplanes bombed three Serb-controlled missile sites in the area today in two raids that took the Atlantic alliance a step further into the Bosnian war.

title: Holyfield Receives Clearance to Fight
description: EVANDER HOLYFIELD, hospitalized for a heart condition after his heavyweight title loss to MICHAEL MOORER, has received medical clearance to fight again.

title: Harwood Simmons; Music Professor, 92
description: Harwood Simmons, a music professor and director of band music at Syracuse University, died on Nov. 14 at Crouse Irving Memorial Hospital in Syracuse. He was 92 and lived in Syracuse.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Kmart's $800 Million Cost-Cutting Plan
description: The Kmart Corporation has formed a group that so far has developed 70 cost-cutting proposals, including such mundane ones as shutting off office lights at night, that are intended to save as much as $800 million in two years.

title: Flaw Undermines Accuracy of Pentium Chips
description: An elusive circuitry error is causing a chip used in millions of computers to generate inaccurate results in certain rare cases, heightening anxiety among many scientists and engineers who rely on their machines for precise calculations.

title: Born in the Camps And Still Kicking
description: Viktor Ullmann's opera "Der Kaiser von Atlantis" can probably never be divorced from the circumstances of its creation, and perhaps it never should be. The piece, which was presented in a semi-staged version at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening, was composed at the Theresienstadt concentration camp in 1943. An allegorical portrait of Hitler, the piece was banned when camp authorities saw a rehearsal in 1944. Soon thereafter Ullmann, his librettist, Petr Kien, and the entire cast were sent to Auschwitz where most, including Ullmann died.

title: Japanese Adopt Motorola Plan
description: Motorola Inc. said today that Japan's Ministry of Posts and Technology had adopted Motorola's new paging technology as the national standard for the next generation of pagers.

title: Presenting Opposite Approaches
description: The double bill on Tuesday night at the Knitting Factory demonstrated two approaches to post-modern jazz: witty and concise compositions from Joey Baron alongside unfettered, sprawling pieces from Roscoe Mitchell. Mr. Mitchell is one of the two saxophonists in the Art Ensemble of Chicago, which is performing through tonight at the new Knitting Factory (74 Leonard Street in TriBeCa). In his early set, his music had more to do with gesture, timbre and stamina than with melody or swing.

title: Of Older People and Their Need for Love, Sex and Marriage
description: LATE LOVE A Celebration of Marriage After 50 By Eileen Simpson 208 pages. A Peter Davison Book/Houghton Mifflin. $21.95.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Dow Jones in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a plan by Asarco Inc. to sell its 23.6 percent stake in a Mexican mining business misstated the company's expected gain. Asarco foresees a pretax gain of about $200 million, not $420 million.

title: Exotic Houseplants (Not an Oxymoron)
description: THE hot-pink flowers and golden leaves of a bougainvillea named Raspberry Ice are aglow in the low autumn sun that is streaming through the greenhouse panes. "If you've got good sunlight, this is one of the easiest houseplants, yet it has a gracious, pendulous outline," said Rudy Nabel, leaning on an ancient wood counter.

title: U.S. Assets Of Briton Are Frozen
description: In a swift response yesterday to an accusation of illegal trading that occurred only 10 days ago, a United States district judge froze the assets in the New York brokerage account of a British businessman.

title: Gibson Suit On Trades Is Settled
description: Gibson Greetings Inc. and the Bankers Trust Company said yesterday that they had settled Gibson's lawsuit accusing the bank of improperly leading the company to engage in risky financial trades.

title: Lufthansa Seen In S.A.S. Deal
description: Lufthansa A.G. and Scandinavia Airlines System will soon sign an agreement to cooperate in a number of their operations, the Danish television network Channel One reported today.

title: Safer Driving or Flying?
description: To the Editor:

title: Versa Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Included unusual expenses of $ 750,000, related to costs incurred in the legal action take against the Toronto Blue Jays baseball club and others. It also included costs associated with Aramark Corp. share purchase offer.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The Miracle Harvest
description: The last time I was in Plymouth, I found myself eavesdropping on a tour group. These modern pilgrims were, not surprisingly, disappointed by the famous rock. Looming like a Gibraltar in our national mythology, Plymouth Rock was in fact a sad little boulder under a Victorian awning. Then a question was asked about Thanksgiving, the Pilgrims' other claim to fame: "What kind of a farmer has a harvest festival in late November?" Answer: "A bad one."

title: ALLY OF D'AMATO GETS PATAKI POST
description: Governor-elect George E. Pataki today named Joseph N. Mondello, the Nassau County Republican leader and a loyal ally of United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, as chairman of his transition team.

title: INSIDE
description: Stock Market Fears Ease

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 NATO JETS HIT 3 MISSILE SITES As rebel Serbs approached a Muslim enclave in northwest Bosnia, NATO jets bombed three Serbian missile sites in retaliation for attacks on NATO planes. A1 Bosnian Serb leaders have threatened "all-out war." A8

title: Just When They Need It, the Jets Begin to Live by the Big Play
description: Without a game-breaking player, the Jets are surging -- thanks to game-breaking plays. They are creating turnovers faster than any other team in football.

title: Police Disrupt Subway Service in Pursuit of a Robbery Suspect
description: City police officers chased a robbery suspect into a Manhattan subway tunnel yesterday and threw an emergency power switch, turning off electricity on several lines from Greenwich Village to Columbus Circle and inconveniencing more than 250,000 subway riders.

title: Penn Traffic Co.(PNF,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 58,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 3,025,000, or 27 cents a share, in the 9 months, on losses from early retirement of debt. The 9 months was also after a charge of $ 5,790,000, or 52 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net loss, which included extraordinary charges of $ 1,091,000, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 23,170,000, or $ 2.24 a share, in the 9 months, on losses from early retirement of debt.(Loss)

title: Amway Contributes $2.5 Million to G.O.P.
description: The Amway Corporation, the door-to-door sales company, has contributed $2.5 million to pay for a newly built broadcast center at the Republican Party's national headquarters, the party announced today.

title: Currents; Theater in a Nutshell
description: WANT to add to the value of your house? Lou Lenzi, the design director for Thomson Consumer Electronics, says adding a home theater can have roughly the same effect as an improved kitchen or a second bath. With this as a carrot, Thomson, the French parent of the RCA, Proscan and General Electric brands available in the United States, has begun selling built-in media-room equipment directly to architects and builders. Thomson asked the architect Michael Graves to make the ever-larger television screen and all that accompanies it, including a VCR and laser-disk player, look homey. He domesticated the system with folksy shutters and decorated the surrounding wall with an exaggerated wallpaper pattern. A rusticated base suggests a stone podium. His "Entertainment Wall," rendered below, may be produced in 1995. Component sets start at $2,000. Information: (800) 336-1900.

title: When These Old Graduates Miss a Game, It's an Upset
description: This Thanksgiving morning, Burt Beagle will be preparing for his annual trip from his Pelham Parkway apartment in the Bronx to nearby Murdock Avenue, where Mount St. Michael will take on Cardinal Hayes today in their 52d annual holiday high school football game.

title: Sports of The Times; Some '94 Thank-You Notes
description: IN a year when sports has too often meant no World Series and no start of the hockey season as well as the mugging of a figure skater, Thanksgiving is time to remember the people who make this little corner of the world a better place.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section yesterday about Hanukkah events on Dec. 1 -- a party for homeless people who are referred by community agencies, a party for children and a menorah lighting and dinner, all at T, the tea room, restaurant and shop on the lower level of the Guggenheim Museum's SoHo branch -- misstated the telephone number for reservations. It is (212) 925-3700.

title: Snowboard: A 'Rosebud' For the 90's
description: IT'S a Norman Rockwell vision: Thanksgiving weekend, the family ritual of gathering to take stock, give thanks and look to the future.

title: Rudolf Firkusny Tribute
description: A memorial tribute to the pianist Rudolf Firkusny is to be held on Dec. 2 at 5 P.M. in the Paul Recital Hall of the Juilliard School, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza. Among the scheduled speakers are Joseph W. Polisi, the president of Juilliard; Igor Firkusny, the pianist's son; the composer Philip Glass, and Kurt Masur, the music director of the New York Philharmonic. The pianist Joseph Kalichstein, the Juilliard String Quartet and Avner Arad, who studied with Mr. Firkusny, are to perform. The event is open to the public; seating will be first come first served. Mr. Firkusny died in July at the age of 82.

title: Moog Inc.(MOG.B,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net restructuring charge of $ 2.9 million, or 38 cents a share, and a gain of $ 505,000, or 6 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 357,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: TODAY'S HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL GAMES
description: C.H.S.F.L. CARDINAL HAYES (4-5) at MOUNT ST. MICHAEL (3-6), 10:30 A.M. Key Players: If the Mounties are going to get untracked offensively, quarterback Joe Ward, who has rushed for 553 yards on 100 carries and 10 touchdowns, will have to lead the way. Robert Hernandez (66 of 150 for 1,084 yards, 8 touchdowns) and running back Jonaxy Gonzalez (902 yards, 7 touchdowns) are the players on whom Hayes depends.

title: Executive Changes
description: THE KELLWOOD CO., St. Louis, promoted James C. Jacobsen, its executive vice president for administration and chief financial officer, to vice chairman; he remains chief financial officer. Hal J. Upbin, its executive vice president for corporate development, was promoted to president and chief operating officer. NEW WORLD COMMUNICATIONS GROUP INC., New York, appointed Arthur H. Bilger president and chief operating officer.

title: OPEC Move May Spur Sharp Rise in Oil Prices
description: Oil prices could rise by $2 to $3 a barrel within a year because of the decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to freeze production at current levels while world consumption rises, industry analysts said yesterday.

title: Plexus Corp.(PLXS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Grocer Shot to Death In Brooklyn Robbery
description: A 40-year-old Brooklyn grocer was shot to death and his cousin wounded yesterday in a holdup at a bodega in Brownsville, the police said.

title: Sam Roffe, 85, Dies; Maker of Ski Clothes
description: Sam Roffe, the founder and chairman of Roffe Inc., one of the nation's largest makers of ski apparel, died on Sunday at his home in Seattle. He was 85.

description: An Afternoon With a Soprano Of the New Generation Alice Tully Hall

title: Under Fire, Italy's Leader Says He'll Sell TV Holdings
description: Trying to seize the initiative in his battle with magistrates investigating him for corruption, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said tonight that he was ready to sell part of his vast business empire, including a majority share in his three national television stations.

title: Stocks Ride Out a Bumpy Session
description: The stock market showed surprising resilience yesterday, surviving a tumultuous session in which stock prices swung up, then down 22 times. But as traders grabbed shares at depressed prices, the market ended little changed, after plunging on Monday and Tuesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies A flaw in the Pentium, the top chip made by Intel, can cause inaccurate calculations in certain rare cases. Intel said the chip would not have to be recalled. But many scientists and engineers who depend on precise calculations are concerned. [ Page D1. ] Gibson Greetings and Bankers Trust settled a lawsuit over derivatives. Gibson agreed to pay Bankers Trust nearly $6.2 million, or about 30 percent of the $20.7 million that Bankers claimed it was owed in the trades between the two. [ D1. ]

title: Communists Plan to Form Government in Nepal
description: Nepal's Communists appeared today to be on the brink of forming a new Government after winning more seats than the ruling Nepali Congress Party in last week's inconclusive general election.

title: F.T.C. Seeks Data on Caremark Alliances
description: Broadening its investigation of relations between drug makers and managed health-care drug distributors, the Federal Trade Commission has asked a number of drug companies to describe contractual alliances with Caremark International, which operates a managed-care drug unit.

title: A Parting of Ways for Heinz And Morris the Cat's Creator
description: Morris the cat and Charlie the tuna are leaving home.

title: Kulicke & Soffa Industries(KLIC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BIOCHEM DROPS SALE OF NORTH AMERICAN VACCINE SHARES
description: Biochem Pharma Inc. said yesterday that it was dropping plans to sell 4.25 million shares of North American Vaccine Inc. Biochem Pharma, a maker of vaccines, diagnostic equipment and drugs based in Laval, Quebec, owns 10.9 million shares, or 38 percent, of North American Vaccine. North American Vaccine, based in Beltsville, Md., develops vaccines for childhood diseases. The company's shares fell 12 percent on Tuesday after the National Institutes of Health disclosed results of a study that suggested that the company's whooping cough vaccine was less effective than others already on the market. North American Vaccine's shares rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $10.875, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Bond Rally Continues On Flight From Stocks
description: Treasury securities continued to rally yesterday for a second consecutive session, benefiting from a flight by investors out of stocks into bonds.

title: Erick Hawkins, a Pioneering Choreographer of American Dance, Is Dead at 85
description: Erick Hawkins, a major figure in American modern dance who offered a radical new definition of the art form, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mexico City Journal; Don Manuel's Dream Tower: A 50-Story Folly?
description: No one has shaped the skyline of this vast city more than Manuel Suarez, a famously eccentric entrepreneur who was supposedly a protege of Pancho Villa and whose errant dream -- a 50-story domino of a building -- has loomed over Mexico City for 30 years.

title: Fatal Runway Collision Under U.S. Inquiry
description: Federal aviation officials were investigating yesterday why a twin-engine propeller plane taxied into the path of a Trans World Airlines jet taking off on Tuesday night from St. Louis, resulting in a collision that killed the two pilots aboard the smaller plane.

title: Gingrich's Life: The Complications and Ideals
description: It was September 1942 when 16-year-old Kathleen Daugherty married Newton C. McPherson Jr., a 19-year-old mechanic in a small town in Pennsylvania. In three days, the marriage fell apart; nine months later, she gave birth to a baby boy, whom she named Newton Leroy.

title: More Affordable Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Trent One of the Biggest Names Left in N.I.T.
description: The big-name schools are long gone. But at least the Preseason National Invitation Tournament has a big-time player going to the finals.

title: Mexican Lawman Accuses Ruling Party in His Brother's Death
description: The official heading the investigation into the assassination of one of Mexico's most powerful politicians said today that the killing was ordered by an influential group within the ruling party, but that Mexico's Attorney General and current party leaders had kept him from proving it.

title: Lechters Inc.(LECH,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included restructuring expense of $ 11 million, or 38 cents a share.c-Net income(Loss)

title: Many Turn Holiday Into Mini-Vacation
description: Spurred by bargain air fares and stable gasoline prices, a record number of Americans were expected to travel over Thanksgiving week, traditionally the busiest travel time of the year.

title: 250 Groups To Share In Grants For Arts
description: About 250 New York City arts organizations have qualified for matching grants from a $10 million fund set up by the state and city governments in July, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Apparel Workers Lose In World Trade Pact
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Seeks A Bridge for PC Systems
description: I.B.M., AT&T, Apple and Siemens will announce next Wednesday a plan to create a universal communication language for computers and computer networks.

title: Journal; Celebrity Turkey Shoot
description: Is it possible -- if almost too much to hope for -- that the same angry, depressed, back-to-business electorate behind the revolt of '94 is also throwing out incumbent celebrities?

title: Catherines Stores Corp.(CATH,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: The latest 9 months' results included write-off of 2 cents a share for deferred financing costs related to its previous bank agreement.

title: Bosnian Serbs Warn NATO Not to Impede Advance
description: Bosnian Serb leaders have threatened "all-out war" if NATO retaliates against their advance on the United Nations-designated "safe area" around Bihac, in the northwest.

title: Court Curbs Wall Street Journal in Fight on Whitewater Report
description: A panel of Federal appeals judges has denied The Wall Street Journal's request for access to the secret final report of the former Whitewater independent counsel, Robert B. Fiske Jr., and at the same time has barred the newspaper from disclosing the details of the decision.

title: Late Season's Greetings From PC Shopping Plans
description: Everyone knows Santa can deliver his gifts in a twinkle, and overnight delivery services are only hours slower. The real bottleneck in the holiday shopping season is the time it takes to go shopping.

title: Metro-Richelieu reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Council Creates an Agency To Watch New York Police
description: The New York City Council voted yesterday to create the first permanent, independent agency to monitor corruption in the Police Department.

title: Mayor Opens Investigation On Jails Chief
description: Eight months after appointing him, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has opened an investigation into some of the flamboyant executive actions of Commissioner of Correction Anthony J. Schembri amid growing calls from outside the administration for the Commissioner's resignation.

title: Sun Devils Stop Maryland
description: Joe Smith's arms do not extend to the 3-point arc. Playing on a tender ankle, the Maryland center scored 23 points, but Arizona State's lineup of whippets made 4 3-point bombs in the final 6 minutes to escape the No. 7 rated Terrapins, 97-90, in the Maui Invitational title game.

title: Theater for the Young
description: The George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., has received a $195,000 grant, one of six given nationally by the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund for the production of theater pieces for young audiences. The George Street Playhouse will use the grant to produce "Entries," a play by Bernardo Solano about a Hispanic young man's coming of age. Others receiving grants, which totaled $900,000, are Tears of Joy Theater in Vancouver, Wash.; American Conservatory Theater, San Francisco; the Coterie Theater, Kansas City, Mo.; the Metro Theater Company, St. Louis, and South Coast Repertory, Costa Mesa, Calif.

title: TORCH ENERGY TO BUY 25 PERCENT OF GULF CANADA
description: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., Canada's fourth-largest energy company, agreed yesterday to sell a minimum 25 percent stake to a United States investor group for about $219 million. The group, led by Torch Energy Advisors Ltd., would provide Gulf Canada with the capital needed to continue developing oil and gas fields. The agreement also gives a group of banks an opportunity to reduce their 70 percent stake in Gulf Canada. The banks received the stake in a restructuring of Olympia & York Developments Ltd., which had pledged the stake as collateral for a $2.5 billion loan. Olympia & York defaulted on the loan when it filed for bankruptcy.

title: Anderson Is Unhappy On All Fronts
description: His left arm was wrapped in cumbersome icepacks on Tuesday night, like a salmon filet prepped for shipping. Kenny Anderson had just played another night in pain.

title: The Pop Life
description: Dylan, Unplugged

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Walsh Is Calling Option Plays Now
description: Figure out what Bill Walsh is thinking? Defenses haven't been able to do it for years.

title: For Giuliani, a Checklist; For Pataki, Opportunities
description: WHEN the big day finally comes next week, and the pending power of Albany finally meets the reigning regent of New York City, what will they say to each other? The imagination roars.

title: Talking With Tony Kushner
description: The playwright Tony Kushner is to be interviewed by Anna Quindlen, a columnist for The New York Times, on Dec. 6 at 7:30 P.M., as part of the Tuesday Evening Lecture Series at St. Luke's School, 487 Hudson Street, at Grove Street, in Greenwich Village. Other speakers in the series are to be the television newswoman Lesley Stahl (Feb. 7) and the writer Gloria Steinem (April 18). Tickets are $30 a session. Information: (212) 924-5960 or (212) 279-4200.

title: Tony Administrators May Add an Award For Off Broadway
description: In a move that reflects the weakness of Broadway and the growing strength of Off Broadway, the administrators of the Tony Awards are considering offering a Tony to Off Broadway productions.

title: DIANA BID FOR GOVERNMENT TECHNOLOGY IS REJECTED
description: The Diana Corporation said yesterday that it offered to buy Government Technology Services Inc. in September for $16 a share, or $107 million, but was rebuffed. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Diana also said that it controlled 6.1 percent of Government Technology, a much larger company that resells computer equipment to government agencies and others. A spokesman for Diana, a distributor of meat, seafood and telecommunications equipment based in Milwaukee, said the company had not decided on its next move. Government Technology, based in Chantilly, Va., said it rejected Diana's offer because it was not firm enough. Shares of Government Technology rose $1.375, to $12.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Oakley's New Shoes Only Create More Pain
description: Charles Oakley's sneaker saga continued today as a specially designed shoe by Nike failed to alleviate the pain in his toe.

title: Currents; That Building Waved! How Did They Do That?
description: IN Sting's new music video for his single, "When We Dance," the English pop star sings an Elysian two-step among a host of angels in what appears to be a futuristic city of white marble with a vast floor of glass.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sloan's to Sell 6 Supermarkets
description: Sloan's Supermarkets Inc. said yesterday that it, along with two companies controlled by its chairman, had agreed to sell six supermarkets within a year in order to settle Federal antitrust concerns.

title:
PARENT & CHILD;
The Teacher Conference: A Team Effort
description: WHEN Connie Walker attended a 30-minute parent-teacher conference two weeks ago, her son Troy, a fifth grader at the Amanda Arnold Elementary School in Manhattan, Kan., went along.

title: Starving the Poor
description: The poor, particularly at election time, are routinely demonized for political gain. Their exploitation in this way has brought us to a cruel place in the political landscape, a place where Americans -- conservative, moderate and liberal -- are finding it frighteningly easy to blame the poor for their own fate, even though that means condemning millions of children to poverty, hunger and hopelessness.

title: After Three Weeks, Lottery Millionaires Confess to Wealth
description: When it dawned on Zdzislaw Wojtowicz last month that he had suddenly become a multi-millionaire, he went home to Jersey City and casually asked his wife, Henryka, what she would do if he happened to win the lottery.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WEIGHT LIFTING First Gold for Germany Marc Huster of Germany won his country's first gold medal at the world weight-lifting championships in Istanbul, Turkey yesterday. Competing in the 183-pound class, Huster lifted a combined total of 842 pounds in the snatch and the clean and jerk, breaking the record set five minutes earlier by Sergo Tchakhoian of Armenia, who lifted 837 pounds. Tchakhoian won a gold medal for his record-breaking lift of 386 pounds in the snatch, and Sunay Bulut of Turkey won the jerk with a lift of 463 pounds, another world record. (AP)

title: Durable Orders Off 1.5% In First Drop Since July
description: Orders for long-lived manufactured products, a closely watched predictor of economic activity, fell last month for the first time since July in what some economists regarded as a sign the business expansion might be slowing.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A romance made in Olympic gymnast's heaven: NADIA COMANECI introduced BART CONNER to her father in Onesti, Romania, yesterday, and Mr. Conner promptly asked him for his daughter's hand in marriage.

title: Bernard Garniez; French Literature Expert, 69
description: Prof. Bernard Garniez, an expert in 20th-century French literature, died last Friday at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan. A Manhattan resident, he was 69.

description: b-Net lossc-After an extraordinary charge of $ 4,943,000, or 99 cents a share, for early extinguishment of debt.(Loss)

description: Connecticut's first Republican Governor in two decades is reaching beyond party stalwarts to form his transition team. Page B6.

title: Currents; Design as Smooth as Skin
description: PAOLO CERMASI thinks the new LaPerla lingerie boutique that he designed suggests a romantic update of "a grandmother's bedroom." Hmmmm. Not unless Grandma is the model Jill Goodacre.

title: Dole and Clinton Strike a Deal on World Trade Pact
description: President Clinton today struck a deal with the prospective Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, that appeared to rescue a world trade agreement scheduled for a vote at a special session of Congress next week.

title: Markets Closed For Holiday
description: All banks and financial markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Thanksgiving. But most markets in other countries are open.

title: Hormel (Geo. A.) & Co.  (HRL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 127,529,000, or $ 1.66 a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting changes.(Loss)The company is doing business as Hormel Foods Corp.

title: City Ballet Starts With Samplings
description: Appetizers rather than a full-course dinner were on the New York City Ballet's table when the company opened on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NEW YORK BANCORP INC., Douglaston, Queens, said its shareholders had approved the acquisition of Hamilton Bancorp Inc. for $133 million in stock.

title: Schleppers
description: Several things distinguish New Yorkers from the rest of America's city dwellers, among them the way they walk. It is not so much that their pace is fast but that their dodges and feints (a dolly to the left of them, a dog walker with seven charges to the right) resemble broken-field running.

title: Making the Affordable Chilean Wines Even Finer
description: In the vast bottling room of Vina Concha y Toro S.A., the largest winery in Chile, roaring machines and uniformed workers turn out 600,000 bottles of wine a day for the United States and other countries with a thirst for Chile's inexpensive wines of quality.

title: Norma Donaldson Dies at 68; Singer Who Became an Actress
description: Norma Donaldson, whose sensuality and throaty voice entertained Broadway audiences, moviegoers and television viewers, died on Tuesday at Cedars Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 68 and lived in Hollywood Hills.

title: Sports of The Times; DiMaggio, 80 Today, Still Stars
description: THE ELDERLY man and his companion had driven off the New Jersey highway on a recent afternoon in order to use the facility of a restaurant. Once inside, the elderly man, not uncommonly, ignited a commotion among the patrons.

title: 'He Says, She Says' on a Royal Level
description: DIANA Her New Life By Andrew Morton Illustrated. 176 pages. Simon & Schuster. $23. THE PRINCE OF WALES A Biography By Jonathan Dimbleby Illustrated. 620 pages. William Morrow & Company. $24.

title: Lowe Will Keep A Citibank Account
description: The Citibank North America unit of Citicorp in New York has retained Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York on its domestic credit card account after a two-month review. The account, with billings estimated at $60 million, has been handled by Lowe since 1980.

title: Awkward Questions After the Nazis Won
description: The plot of "Fatherland," a movie having its premiere tomorrow on HBO, is woven around an ingenious premise.

Surveying a political landscape utterly transformed by the Congressional elections, President Clinton and Newt Gingrich gave the same reply when asked what they could achieve in the next two years: welfare reform. Their words are the same, their meaning worlds apart.

title: Bure and Mogilny Stay
description: Two of hockey's Russian stars, PAVEL BURE of the Vancouver Canucks and ALEXANDER MOGILNY of the Buffalo Sabres, have decided to sign with Moscow Spartak of the Russian League.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Did a vampire take a bite out of a movie? And how does car buying resemble a wrestling match?
description: IS it time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media? Yes, but that one doesn't count.

title: In This Election, G.O.P. Won Because More Rich People Voted; No Rush to the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: An Editorial Debate: Should We Make Research Embryos?; Yes, the Gains Could Be Great
description: When a panel of experts proposed in September that the Federal Government start funding research on human embryos, they ignited a controversy. Some people feel such research is inherently unethical, while many scientists think it has been needlessly curtailed. The panel's recommendations, which apply only to embryos created in the laboratory, not to those created in the womb, will be reviewed next week at the National Institutes of Health. The most inflammatory recommendation by far is that, in carefully defined circumstances, scientists should be able to create embryos solely for research and then destroy them when finished.

title: Article 924261 -- No Title
description: Seeking to stem a drop in birth rates that may be the sharpest in modern world history, the government of the eastern German state of Brandenburg has announced that it will pay parents $650 for every new child they have.

title: Limiting Welfare -- A special report.; Often-Cited Workfare Effort Provides Cautionary Lessons
description: Sandy Pitt and Sajan Mathew pounded on the door of a shuttered house on Union Avenue. They were searching for a 37-year-old welfare recipient who had given the address as his own.

title: Art in Review
description: Tony Oursler Metro Pictures 150 Greene Street (at Houston Street) SoHo Through tomorrow

title: There Will Be a Brief Recess While We Check Our Wardrobes
description: Vivian Berger, the vice dean of Columbia Law School, remembers a bright young student who was distraught because no firm would hire her. "I took one look at her and immediately knew the reason: she looked like a whore," Ms. Berger said. "Her clothes were very tight, and she was quite buxom."

title: Russian Aid Under Siege By G.O.P.
description: Aid to Russia, always a contentious issue before Congress, is under siege by the new Republican majority, even though President Clinton has already cut Russian aid sharply from last year.

title: Inflation Figures Go Up for 68th Straight Year
description: With wind nipping at their noses and fingertips, tens of thousands of New Yorkers lined the streets of Manhattan yesterday for the 68th annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade. Despite the chill, they roared approval at the blaring bands, prancing steeds, bulb-nosed clowns and, of course, the traditional pantheon of pumped-up heroes like Spiderman, Garfield, the Pink Panther, Snoopy, and, making his debut, Barney the dinosaur.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The evening was billed as an opportunity to learn how to break into modeling and acting, but there were few potential Cindy Crawfords, Naomi Campbells -- or for that matter, Elle MacPhersons -- who turned out to hear ELLE MacPHERSON the other evening. The supermodel was giving a talk sponsored by the Learning Annex at the Park Central Hotel on Seventh Avenue. But the audience of about 300 was mainly men, few of whom appeared headed for modeling careers.

title: Execution by Injection Can Be Botched, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spoken Word
description: "LAUGHING SCREAMING: MODERN HOLLYWOOD HORROR AND COMEDY," American Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue and 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. A three-lecture series about pushing the boundaries of good taste continues on Sunday at 2 P.M. with a talk by Larry Cohen, the director of the 1974 film "It's Alive," which will be shown. Also to be shown, at 4:30 P.M., will be the 1981 film "Porky's Fox," directed by Bob Clark. Free with museum admission: $5; $4 for the elderly; $2.50 for students and children. Information: (718) 784-4520.

title: Burnett Has an Eye On Heinz's Rivals
description: The Leo Burnett Company says it will probably consider working for marketers that sell pet foods and other products that compete against a longtime former client, the H. J. Heinz Company.

title: In This Election, G.O.P. Won Because More Rich People Voted
description: To the Editor:

title: Central America Nations to Be Urged to Seize Stolen U.S. Cars
description: In an effort to reduce auto thefts, the Clinton Administration is planning a major effort to persuade Central American governments to seize stolen cars smuggled from the United States and return them, a State Department official said this week.

title: Lorelei Lee Returns, Dizzy and Savvy as Ever
description: Whatever the feminist thinking on the subject, there is, frankly, no blonde like a dumb blonde.

title: The Bard Meets the Undead
description: Bored with this mortal coil? Try shuffling off to the New Orleans of "Interview with a Vampire," where vampire-heartthrob Lestat (Tom Cruise) asks vampire-designate Louis (Brad Pitt) just that question, evoking the pale specter of Hamlet not yet resolved that his thoughts should "be bloody, or be nothing worth."

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: Long Island CHIEFS TWO-PEAT: With 6 minutes 29 seconds remaining, Bill Martin booted a 32-yard field goal yesterday to lift MASSAPEQUA (10-0) over LAWRENCE (6-3-1), 11-8, and give the Chiefs the Nassau County Conference I championship for the second consecutive year. Massapequa will take on the winner of today's Connetquot-Sachem clash in the Long Island Class I championship next Friday at Hofstra Stadium at 7 P.M.

title: Revisiting the World Of Rebels and Redcoats
description: Let's get the invidious comparisons out of the way. "The American Revolution" is not "The Civil War." Momentous though it was, the war that began the United States does not grip the imagination like the war that might have ended it. For 20th-century Americans, the Revolution does not have the dramatic force, the emotional resonance, the painful relevance of the Civil War, and the six-hour history that begins on Sunday does not pretend otherwise.

title: Little Switch Pays a Big Dividend for Lions
description: Jim Kelly had thrown a bushel of passes to his running backs and the Buffalo Bills were outperforming the Detroit Lions in this matchup of back versus linebacker in the Silverdome today. So there was little surprise when, with 1 minute 35 seconds to play and Buffalo trailing by 28-21, Kelly began a Bills' drive from his 16 with a 9-yard pass, out of the shotgun, to a running back, Thurman Thomas.

title: Commander Says the U.N. Must Act Against the Serbs
description: The United Nations commander in Bosnia tonight called the Serbian advance on a "safe area" in northwest Bosnia "a very grave development, which we have to act upon," but declined to say what action he would recommend.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the family life of Representative Newt Gingrich, who is line to become Speaker of the House, misspelled the surname of a Georgia state senator whom he defeated for Congress in 1978. She is Virginia Shapard.

title: Fighting Rages as NATO Debates How to Protect Bosnian Enclave
description: Fierce fighting raged today around the Muslim enclave of Bihac in northwestern Bosnia when Serbian forces pursued a steady advance toward the center of the town and NATO allies failed to agree on how to save it.

title: Inside Art
description: 3 Recordings Later

title: Fed Raises Interest Rates on Dubious Grounds; Why Cut Labor Force?
description: To the Editor:

title: Asia Society Offers a Rare Glimpse
description: Anyone who was in New York City and on the alert five summers ago may remember an untrumpeted but astonishing exhibition of sculpture at the Asia Society. It included top-flight South Indian bronzes, Cambodian stone work and a small, sublime wooden Buddhist figure from Japan that alone was worth the price of admission.

title: Fed Raises Interest Rates on Dubious Grounds
description: To the Editor:

title: As Its Stars Age, Folk Music Stays Forevewr Young
description: IN folk music, there is almost always a message. So when Tom Paxton writes a new song with a chorus that ends, "I wish I could start all over again," Mr. Paxton just may be trying to tell us something.

title: Canada's Trade Efforts Raise Hackles at Home
description: Canada is pursuing fast-growing markets in Asia and the Pacific to reduce its dependence on the economy of its neighbor, the United States, though not without some public misgivings at home.

title: Home Video
description: Votes for favorite tapes are being counted at the Coalition for Quality Children's Video in Santa Fe, N.M. Fairy tales are big winners, as usual, along with myths and literature and other powerful incumbents among the children's categories, but newcomers have made gains as well. Firefighters are in this year. So are pilots and a hard-hat contingent at the controls of bulldozers and other pieces of heavy equipment.

title: A Point Guard Leaves in Order to Go Back Home
description: Rafer Alston has the rearview mirror from hell. In it, he sees his father hawking his Michael Jordan rookie card for cash, and his mother not coming to the card's defense. He sees his high school coach waving a basketball uniform, asking him to dive in, but his high school principal snatches it away. He sees his teacher calling roll, and he wants to say, "Here; I'm here," but the teacher calls Felipe Lopez's and Stephon Marbury's names instead. He sees himself rolling the dice, and coming up 7, but no money is in the pot. He sees his brother in prison, his twin sister pregnant and himself with no S.A.T. score.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: Football; Sharp Criticizes Ryan
description: First, Coach BUDDY RYAN placed Arizona Cardinals tackle LUIS SHARPE on injured reserve, ending the 13-year veteran's season. Then Sharpe said he would never play for Ryan again. "Absolutely not," he said. "This is it for me here."

title: Owners' Plan Has Payoff for Cardinals
description: If the 28 major league teams play baseball next year under the terms the owners are now proposing and their revenues and payrolls are what they had projected for this year, the Yankees will contribute the most money to the clubs' revenue-sharing pool, but the St. Louis Cardinals will hold the most curious position.

title: Power Struggle Is Delaying Approval of Hospitals Chief
description: More than seven months after he was named to head the struggling Westchester County Medical Center, Edward A. Stolzenberg can point to some impressive gains: The hospital has allied with 11 managed-care organizations, its revenues are up and the average time that a patient stays there is down.

title: Unable to Protect Product Trademarks, Manufacturers Copyright the Boxes
description: If Parfums Givenchy and other premium-product makers continue to prevail in their use of copyright law, consumers could find fewer cut-rate deals on prestige perfume, cosmetics, crystal ware and other luxury goods at their local discount stores.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend

title: Gotham to Expand With London Office
description: The Gotham Group, the boutique agency spun off in March from Lintas New York, is expanding its operations by opening a London office that will serve the Yardley of London account in Britain. Billings were estimated at $9.4 million.

title: Company A Gives Thanks: 8 Days to Go in Haiti
description: It was hard to tell who looked more thankful this afternoon, the soldiers of Company A or their turkey.

title: U.S. Banks Gain Ground In Germany's Markets
description: It is a confirmation of the growing presence of American banks here in the stronghold of German financial might when a directory assistance operator now answers a request for J. P. Morgan's telephone number by saying, "The bank, ja?" rather than asking on which street Herr Morgan lives.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Night of 100 Flashes

title: Art in Review
description: Rebecca Horn Marian Goodman Gallery 24 West 57th Street Manhattan Through December

title: Fresnes Journal; Sad Voyages to France: In One School, Many Sagas
description: Sabine Contrepois well remembers the day two years ago when she explained to her high-school class how the Vietnam War eventually spilled into Cambodia. Suddenly, Meak, an Asian girl in the front row, burst into tears.

title: Accounts
description: * Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, to Publicis Conseil, Paris, to handle advertising in Europe for the caffeine-free versions of its Diet Coke and Coke Light brands, previously at Lowe & Associes, Paris. It is the first Coca-Cola assignment for a Publicis agency. Billings were not disclosed. * Dow Jones & Co., New York, and Flextech P.L.C., London, to Ryan Drossman & Partners, New York, and CIA Medianetwork International, London, to introduce European Business News, a business-news cable and satellite television network. Both agencies already handle other accounts for Dow Jones. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Milton J. Shapp Is Dead at 82; Ex-Governor of Pennsylvania
description: Milton Jerrold Shapp, former Governor of Pennsylvania and a Philadelphia industrialist who was the first Jew to mount a campaign for the Presidential nomination of a major party, died on Thursday at Lankenau Hospital in the Philadelphia suburb of Wynnewood. He was 82.

title: Europeans Follow U.S. Shift to Bonds, for Now
description: Like their counterparts in the United States, investors in European markets have been bailing out of stocks this week and putting their money into bonds.

title: Sherrard Sees the Football And He Opens Some Eyes
description: When the locker room had cleared, and his teammates had patted him on the back and reporters had asked their last questions, Mike Sherrard could only laugh. The holidays had come early for him, his present being a larger part of the offense.

title: Art in Review
description: Tony Oursler Metro Pictures 150 Greene Street (at Houston Street) SoHo Through tomorrow

title: Health and Happiness Go Together for Nets
description: On the surface, the Nets have no reason to complain. They have a 5-7 record. They meet the Los Angeles Clippers on Friday night in Los Angeles having won five of their last seven games. They are coming off their first road victory -- by 103-98 over the Sacramento Kings on Wednesday night, a game in which they found their poise in the final minutes for the first time this season.

title: MILITARY PLANNING AN EXPANDED ROLE FOR THE RESERVES
description: Aiming to reduce the strain on active-duty troops, Defense Secretary William J. Perry has approved a plan to use reservists in many peacetime roles now performed by regular forces.

title: Art in Review
description: Marisa Merz Barbara Gladstone Gallery 100 Greene Street (near Prince Street) SoHo Through De. 10

title: NATO Gives U.N. Bosnia Action Plan
description: NATO, meeting in Brussels on a United States proposal to threaten more air strikes to halt an offensive by nationalist Serbs in northwestern Bosnia and Herzegovina, referred the plan to the United Nations.

title: Robert M. Cohart, 84, Professor And an Expert in Public Health
description: Dr. Robert M. Cohart, Winslow professor emeritus of public health at Yale University, died on Nov. 18. He was 84 and a resident of New Haven.

title: Shorter Hours For Markets
description: All banks and financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving. But most markets in other countries were open.

title: At Neiman Marcus, Mail-Order Frenzy Nears Peak
description: The caller from Mexico City wanted a model. Not a model car or plane but a model, as in the Cindy Crawford variety.

title: 3 Officials Are Demoted After Slaying at Mental Hospital
description: The director and two top officials of a Brooklyn psychiatric hospital have been demoted and transferred after a weekend escape of a patient who later returned to murder another inmate, the State Commissioner of Mental Health said yesterday.

title: Results Plus
description: PRO BASKETBALL Pacers Put a Halt to High-Scoring Warriors

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets This month's plunge in stock prices has hit cyclical stocks the hardest, showing that the market is worrying about the economy. But will the selloff continue as investors return from Thanksgiving? The answer may depend on how they react to economic data next week, including reports on gross domestic product and unemployment. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ Page D7. ]

title: Injury to Keep Emtman Out for Rest of Season
description: Indianapolis Colts defensive lineman STEVE EMTMAN has a herniated disk in his neck and will miss the rest of the season. Coach TED MARCHIBRODA said yesterday that Emtman would have surgery in the next week to 10 days, but will not return this year.

title: Keep in Mind
description: HANUKKAH CELEBRATION, where the story of the holiday is told through music and contemporary dance by the Avodah Dance Ensemble; for children 4 and older. Sunday at 2 P.M., at Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side. Tickets: $5, adults; $3.50, children. Information: (212) 598-0400.

title: Flexing Fiscal Muscles: Mayor and Council at Loggerheads
description: For 11 months, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has had near total dominion at City Hall, with the Democratic-controlled City Council resignedly giving its approval to the Republican's austere $31.6 billion budget and vision of a far smaller government.

title: People
description: * J.
